text: Modern Architecture: A Very Short Introduction

text: Chapter 1
label: Title

text: Introduction
label: Title

text: Somewhere between 1910 and 1970, architecture changed. Now that
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture is familiar—and we’ve seen how it became both
label: Paragraph

text: celebrated and vilified—it’s hard to imagine how novel it once seemed.
label: Paragraph

text: Expensive Western buildings became transformed from ornamented fancies,
label: Paragraph

text: which referred to the classical and medieval pasts, into strikingly plain
label: Paragraph

text: reflections of novel materials, technologies, and ideas. It’s equally hard to
label: Paragraph

text: remember how modem architecture promised transformation, seemingly
label: Paragraph

text: poised to turn dirty, overcrowded cities—characterized by packed slums
label: Paragraph

text: and Satanic mills—into spacious realms of generous housing and clean
label: Paragraph

text: mechanized production, set in parkland. At certain times and in certain
label: Paragraph

text: cultures, modern architecture stood for the liberation of the future from the
label: Paragraph

text: past.
label: Paragraph

text: The phrase ‘modern architecture’ describes a spectrum of buildings and
label: Paragraph

text: ideas. From Shakespeare’s times until the 19th century, ‘modern’ in English
label: Paragraph

text: meant ‘up to date’. The idea of progress became important in the 19th
label: Paragraph

text: century and that made the modern ‘progressive’: part of an apparently
label: Paragraph

text: predestined course from an impoverished past, to a still inadequate present,
label: Paragraph

text: towards an idealized future. More recently however, the term modern
label: Paragraph

text: largely came to describe a specific time in the 20th century when many
label: Paragraph

text: people, especially in the West, seemed persuaded that a better future was on
label: Paragraph

text: its way.
label: Paragraph

text: For some historians, modern architecture refers primarily to stark white
label: Paragraph

text: buildings from the 1920s and 1930s: crisp, hovering edifices which, so the
label: Paragraph

text: story goes, reflected honestly their internal functions on the outside,
label: Paragraph

text: illustrating how they were put together, highlighting the ‘shock of the new’.
label: Paragraph

text: For others, the idea of a modern architectural future had a longer history. It
label: Paragraph

text: dated back to the Paris World’s Fair of 1889, or John Ruskin’s 1849
label: Paragraph

text: exhortations about how medieval Gothic cathedrals expressed structure
label: Title

text: honestly in stone.
label: Paragraph

text: Just as it’s possible to argue about the beginnings of modern architecture, its
label: Paragraph

text: demise has been much debated. For various commentators, modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture is over. It was supplanted by ‘postmodernism’ in the 1980s and
label: Paragraph

text: 1990s, when architects became less interested in the expression of function,
label: Paragraph

text: and returned to historical motifs (like the 1991 extension to London’s
label: Paragraph

text: National Gallery, designed by Venturi, Scott Brown and Associates), or
label: Paragraph

text: striking shape-making of various kinds (like the sinuous Guggenheim
label: Paragraph

text: Museum, Bilbao, 1997, designed by Frank O. Gehry’s studio). For others,
label: Caption

text: modern architecture—as the expression of contemporary building
label: Paragraph

text: technologies, as the idea of making construction legible and transparent—
label: Paragraph

text: remains current, no matter that other disciplines insist on the demise of
label: Paragraph

text: modernity in their fields.
label: Paragraph

text: I’ll take a long and broad view of modern architecture here, examining what
label: Paragraph

text: Harold Rosenberg called ‘the tradition of the new’, arguing that it didn’t
label: Paragraph

text: just emerge fully formed in the 1910s and 1920s, or as the consequence of
label: Paragraph

text: 19th-century pioneers, but was instead the product of two centuries of
label: Paragraph

text: industrialization, and the global spread of industrial culture. I set out neither
label: Paragraph

text: to promote nor condemn modern architecture. Rather, my aim is to illustrate
label: Paragraph

text: how it was produced out of—and reflected—the cultures that constructed it.
label: Paragraph

text: I explore it in all its strangeness and thoughtfulness, as designed by some
label: Paragraph

text: curious, obsessive characters.
label: Paragraph

text: The organization of this book
label: Title

text: Certain famous modern architects were skilled self-publicists. Memorable
label: Paragraph

text: aphorisms, like Ludwig Mies van der Rohe’s ‘less is more’, and Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s ‘the house is a machine for living’, entered the lexicons of
label: Paragraph

text: popular quotation. Less widely known, but chortled-at by generations of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture students, is Louis Kahn’s 1971 conversation with a brick:
label: Paragraph

text: If you think of Brick, you say to Brick, ‘What do you want, Brick?’ And Brick says to you ‘I
label: Paragraph

text: like an Arch’. And if you say to Brick ‘Look, arches are expensive and I can use a concrete
label: Paragraph

text: lintel over you. What do you think of that Brick?’ Brick says ‘I like an Arch’.
label: Paragraph

text: This image of architect in communion with brick illustrates a point which
label: Paragraph

text: preoccupied modern architects: that different building materials imply their
label: Paragraph

text: own inherent logics. How particular materials go together, Kahn suggested,
label: Paragraph

text: make certain combinations of structure, wall, and building assembly seem
label: Paragraph

text: inevitable: brick wants to make arches; timber wants to make lattices of
label: Paragraph

text: beams and posts; steel wants to make frames; reinforced concrete wants to
label: Paragraph

text: make frames too, and also thin planes and big spans. You can persuade
label: Paragraph

text: those materials to behave otherwise, but why—Kahn implied—as a
label: Paragraph

text: thoughtful modern architect, would you do that? This was not new. In 1863,
label: Paragraph

text: Parisian architect Eugéne-Emmanuel Viollet-le-Duc wrote that any ‘change
label: Paragraph

text: of material must bring about a change of forms’. The contemporaneous
label: Paragraph

text: German writer Gottfried Semper argued that brick, wood, and iron should
label: Paragraph

text: be treated according to their ‘statical laws’. Both responded to Ruskin’s
label: Paragraph

text: ideas about honesty to materials and the honest visual expression of the
label: Paragraph

text: uses of a building. Their earnest morality persisted into modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. And the idea that materials have their own inherent logics
label: Paragraph

text: explains how I’ve organized this book.
label: Paragraph

text: Historians often gave architects more credit than they deserved for shaping
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture. Moder architects’ imaginations were hugely
label: Paragraph

text: extended by material innovations. Developments in steel and reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: concrete radically altered possibilities for shaping buildings, as did new
label: Paragraph

text: systems for electric lighting and handling air. These technical innovations,
label: Paragraph

text: in turn, emerged from new cultures of industrial production. Thus, my story
label: Paragraph

text: is organized around the technical innovations that opened up the cultural
label: Paragraph

text: and intellectual opportunities for modern architecture to happen.
label: Paragraph

text: This isn’t to say that architects were involved in the invention of new
label: Paragraph

text: technologies—most weren’t, and many disapproved at first—but, as Adrian
label: Paragraph

text: Forty has argued, architects’ special ability was to conjure up images for
label: Paragraph

text: new technologies that made them seem striking and appealing. Architects
label: Paragraph

text: didn’t create steel and reinforced concrete, or fluorescent tubes and air
label: Paragraph

text: conditioning, but they appreciated how those technologies could make the
label: Paragraph

text: world look and feel different. And they designed knowingly in relation to
label: Paragraph

text: imagery from other spheres, like modern art and industrial design. The
label: Paragraph

text: British modern architect Wells Coates wrote in 1931 that there was a choice
label: Paragraph

text: between ‘the use of the new ... materials as prisoners—the slaves—of old
label: Paragraph

text: habits, old social prejudices, old visual prejudices; or as the means to new
label: Paragraph

text: forms, new habits of life, a new vision’.
label: Paragraph

text: My story thus explores the architectural consequences of iron and steel,
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced concrete, brick, air conditioning, and electric light to illustrate
label: Paragraph

text: how modern architecture produced powerful cultural images expressing the
label: Paragraph

text: potential of the future. These new technologies were not adopted by
label: Paragraph

text: architects in a linear sequence but, to some extent, in parallel. So, each
label: Paragraph

text: chapter here—while organized broadly in chronological order—shifts back
label: Paragraph

text: in time to begin before the previous one ends.
label: Paragraph

text: Some definitions
label: Title

text: I define modernity here as the condition of living in an industrialized
label: Paragraph

text: society. Industrialized societies are those shaped by modern science and
label: Paragraph

text: consumer technologies: by mass production, mass markets, mass
label: Title

text: consumption, mass education, and mass media; by novelty and fashion; and
label: Paragraph

text: by accelerating globalization fuelled by the power of global finance.
label: Paragraph

text: Underpinning industrialized societies was an idea that perpetual scientific
label: Paragraph

text: progress operated hand in hand with economic growth, and also—
label: Paragraph

text: sometimes—amulti-party democracy. Alongside industry, work, and
label: Paragraph

text: changing patterns of domestic life, the category of modernity encompassed
label: Paragraph

text: ideas from art, literature, film, theatre, media, music, philosophy, and
label: Title

text: architecture: cultural endeavours reflecting modern societies, and shaping
label: Title

text: them through the reflections they offered. Modern technology, and the
label: Paragraph

text: cultures it produced, seemed poised to liberate people from rigid constraints
label: Paragraph

text: traditionally imposed by their gender, class, or ethnicity. But the same
label: Paragraph

text: progress could also seem alienating—disrupting traditional communities
label: Paragraph

text: and ways of life. Modernity thus mixed optimism about the social
label: Paragraph

text: opportunities of technology with deep unease about its consequences. The
label: Paragraph

text: peak of modernity occurred between the late 19th and mid-20th centuries in
label: Paragraph

text: the West. Indeed, modernity extended beyond the West in different places at
label: Paragraph

text: different times, sometimes associated with colonization in the 19th and 20th
label: Paragraph

text: centuries, and sometimes with postcolonial societies.
label: Paragraph

text: More recently, faith in perpetual progress was shaken. Science and
label: Paragraph

text: technology appeared fallible. Power structures linking the funding of
label: Paragraph

text: science and political parties with industry, finance, and military endeavours
label: Title

text: became more apparent. The operation of these power structures in service
label: Paragraph

text: of people of a particular class, ethnicity, and gender, from particular comers
label: Paragraph

text: of the globe, was highlighted. And the vast consumption of energy and
label: Paragraph

text: disposable goods was questioned in terms of sustainability. For these
label: Paragraph

text: reasons, it’s widely assumed that modernity—as an idea about progress—
label: Paragraph

text: ended during the latter part of the 20th century, or at least became much
label: Paragraph

text: more complicated. The term ‘postmodern’ was coined to describe what
label: Paragraph

text: followed.
label: Paragraph

text: I define modern architecture here as architecture produced out of the
label: Paragraph

text: condition of modernity. In particular, it’s architecture that contributed to
label: Paragraph

text: modernity, because the images of its buildings seemed to express what
label: Paragraph

text: modernity stood for.
label: Paragraph

text: Modern architecture’s champions referred to ‘the modern movement’,
label: Paragraph

text: associating it with radical movements in art. The term also implied
label: Paragraph

text: connections with radical political movements that its characters
label: Paragraph

text: occasionally hooked up with, in Russia and Italy in the 1910s, and Germany
label: Paragraph

text: and France in the 1920s. Only when tidied up by sympathetic historians in
label: Paragraph

text: retrospect, however, did it look like a coherent movement. There were
label: Paragraph

text: always multiple modern architectures and the term meant different things to
label: Paragraph

text: different people at different times. In his 1896 book Modern Architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: architect Otto Wagner associated the idea with the rational and honest
label: Paragraph

text: expression of materials, structure, and function, and with the purging of
label: Paragraph

text: unnecessary decoration—themes familiar as late as the 1970s. In the 1910s,
label: Paragraph

text: however, quite different architectures of ‘Art Nouveau’, characterized by
label: Paragraph

text: swirling floral motifs, would also have been called modern, alongside the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘expressionist’ crystalline shapes of Bruno Taut’s ‘Crystal Chain’ group. By
label: Paragraph

text: the late 1930s, however, these counted as modern less frequently. At that
label: Paragraph

text: time, modern architecture became more tightly defined around buildings
label: Paragraph

text: evoking glamorous technologies of the age: cars, ocean liners, and
label: Paragraph

text: aeroplanes. This was the so-called International Style, matching white
label: Paragraph

text: planes with flat roofs, open plans, extensive glazing, horizontal windows,
label: Paragraph

text: and blocks you could see below or through. By the late 1950s, multiple
label: Paragraph

text: modern architectures proliferated again, reconsidering what then became
label: Paragraph

text: seen as the ‘early modern’ architecture of the 1930s. Certain architects at
label: Paragraph

text: that time hoped to make modern architecture more humane, dramatic,
label: Paragraph

text: monumental, or systematically scientific. Despite these differences, the idea
label: Paragraph

text: of a single modern movement persisted. It sounded glamorous and sold
label: Paragraph

text: textbooks.
label: Paragraph

text: Modern architecture was also defined by how architects designed it. There
label: Paragraph

text: are three primary kinds of scaled architectural drawing: the elevation,
label: Paragraph

text: depicting a facade; the section, a vertical cut from roof to foundations
label: Paragraph

text: showing floors stacked up; and the plan, a horizontal cut showing the layout
label: Paragraph

text: of rooms on a floor. Where architects previously agonized over elevations,
label: Paragraph

text: often adapting plans and sections around decisions made about the facades,
label: Paragraph

text: modern architects prioritized the plan. They claimed that the layout of
label: Paragraph

text: rooms—the best functional arrangement for a house, library, or office—
label: Paragraph

text: should come first, and that elevations should be secondary. The most
label: Paragraph

text: famous modern architect, Le Corbusier, wrote that ‘the plan is the
label: Paragraph

text: generator’. Louis Sullivan’s catchy aphorism ‘form ever follows function’
label: Paragraph

text: was a slogan for this way of working. In the writings of Adolf Loos, it
label: Paragraph

text: became elevated to a moral imperative. By the 1930s, most modern
label: Paragraph

text: architects believed there was something truthful about designs prioritizing
label: Paragraph

text: function, and something dishonest about designs emphasizing a building’s
label: Paragraph

text: artistic decoration. Despite the rhetoric, however, modem architects
label: Paragraph

text: remained deeply concerned with the imagery of their buildings. Indeed,
label: Paragraph

text: numerous modern buildings can be understood as architectural images
label: Paragraph

text: dedicated to undermining the idea of architectural imagery.
label: Paragraph

text: From the 1930s, modern architecture increasingly became called
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Modernism’, making it sound like a cause. The term allowed historians to
label: Paragraph

text: characterize modern architecture as a style like other architectural styles
label: Paragraph

text: (Neo-Classicism or Gothic Revivalism, for example). It also helped them
label: Paragraph

text: link it to other modernisms in art and literature that similarly responded to
label: Paragraph

text: technological cultures, industrialization, and globalization. This appealed to
label: Paragraph

text: critics who made reputations out of classifying trends. But many modern
label: Paragraph

text: architects thought they were isolating honest, timeless ways to design—not
label: Paragraph

text: indulging in something as fleeting as a style—and vigorously rejected the
label: Paragraph

text: idea.
label: Paragraph

text: Modernism appears with and without a capital ‘m’. Some advocates of
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture used the capital letter to sort out buildings they felt
label: Paragraph

text: were special symbols of the movement from buildings that were merely
label: Paragraph

text: new. Others used it to elevate Modernism to the status of other nouns
label: Paragraph

text: capitalized in English, like Church or God. You won’t see Modern or
label: Paragraph

text: Modernism written with a capital ‘m’ again here. And I'll use modernism
label: Paragraph

text: sparingly. I don’t want to make modern architecture seem more important
label: Paragraph

text: than other architectures. Nor do I find obsessing about which famous
label: Paragraph

text: buildings fit into which stylistic categories particularly fruitful. When
label: Paragraph

text: studying architecture, it seems more interesting to think instead about
label: Paragraph

text: buildings themselves: how they work, what they do, and what they say.
label: Paragraph

text: Having reflected on the ‘modern’ in ‘modern architecture’, it’s worth
label: Paragraph

text: pausing on ‘architecture’. Nikolaus Pevsner, the prominent modern
label: Paragraph

text: historian, famously made a distinction between architecture and building:
label: Paragraph

text: ‘A bicycle shed is a building’, he wrote, ‘whereas Lincoln Cathedral is a
label: Paragraph

text: work of architecture’. Distinctions like this are widespread but obstructive.
label: Paragraph

text: All buildings—bicycle shed or cathedral, banal office building or
label: Paragraph

text: obsessively detailed museum—offer insights into the values of the people
label: Paragraph

text: and cultures which produced them, illustrating the ideas informing their
label: Paragraph

text: design, construction, and use. All are valid objects of scholarly attention.
label: Paragraph

text: I’ve included (big) sheds and bridges in this book, alongside churches and
label: Paragraph

text: high-rise towers, because they all yielded important architectural images of
label: Paragraph

text: modernity. If anything distinguishes the buildings I’ve included here from
label: Paragraph

text: others, it’s that they became famous because they proved inspiring or
label: Paragraph

text: troubling enough for people to have projected ideas about modernity onto
label: Paragraph

text: them.
label: Paragraph

text: Most histories of modern architecture bring the story up to date. But,
label: Paragraph

text: because I contend that modernity transformed into something else, my story
label: Paragraph

text: closes in the 1970s, accepting that architecture transformed with it. This end
label: Paragraph

text: point coincides with a time when building regulations introduced in the
label: Paragraph

text: West made the idea of truth to materials harder to achieve at the level of
label: Paragraph

text: architectural detail. While ideas from modern architecture remain doggedly
label: Paragraph

text: persistent, and numerous architects still practice as paid-up modernists, ours
label: Paragraph

text: is now the architecture of another time which will attract its own histories in
label: Paragraph

text: due course.
label: Paragraph

text: Histories of the future
label: Title

text: Modern architecture owed as much to its storytellers as its buildings. Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s 1923 book Towards a New Architecture—which became
label: Paragraph

text: admired in the Anglosphere in the 1930s—tried to establish moral and
label: Paragraph

text: visual principles for modern architecture. Meanwhile, certain historians
label: Paragraph

text: rewrote architectural history to make modernism its logical consequence,
label: Paragraph

text: including Hitchcock and Johnson, whose 1932 term ‘International Style’
label: Paragraph

text: I’ve already mentioned, and Pevsner, whose Pioneers of Modern Design,
label: Paragraph

text: 1936, sought to persuade sceptics inclined towards the past that modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture actually emerged from a long history. Sigfried Giedion
label: Paragraph

text: illustrated in 1941 how architecture could be understood in terms of time
label: Paragraph

text: and space. And in the 1960s, (Peter) Reyner Banham—historian of the
label: Paragraph

text: immediate future’—extended the category of architecture to include all
label: Paragraph

text: sorts of industrial structures, technologies, and gadgets. Robert Venturi’s
label: Paragraph

text: Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture, 1966, reminded readers that
label: Paragraph

text: history always infused modern architecture, and anticipated the
label: Paragraph

text: postmodernism that followed. It’s a curious quirk that modern architecture
label: Paragraph

text: —whose most extreme forms rejected the past—was so extensively
label: Paragraph

text: consolidated by its historians.
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural histories have strange conventions. Buildings are usually
label: Paragraph

text: designed in studios full of architects and technicians, with clients, builders,
label: Paragraph

text: engineers, and regulations that help to shape them. Nevertheless, historians
label: Paragraph

text: mostly attribute famous buildings to a single architect—usually male,
label: Paragraph

text: white, and Western, like most of the historians themselves—even if that
label: Paragraph

text: individual hardly spent any time on the project. I’ll use this pervasive
label: Paragraph

text: convention here, albeit guardedly, with this reminder not to forget who it
label: Paragraph

text: conceals. Another convention—as old as the book The Lives of the Artists
label: Paragraph

text: by architect Giorgio Vasari, 1550—depicts famous architects as visionary
label: Paragraph

text: geniuses working against the odds. This idea persists, and certain modern
label: Paragraph

text: architects became elevated into superheroes who could do no wrong. I'll
label: Paragraph

text: highlight one such anointed superhero in each chapter, recalling the
label: Paragraph

text: celebrity worship that still pervades architectural culture.
label: Paragraph

text: Few architectural history books stray from sites of financial and cultural
label: Paragraph

text: power. Most discuss buildings that were novel when they were constructed
label: Paragraph

text: becoming models for others that followed, built in places with the wealth
label: Paragraph

text: necessary to make them, the cultural sensibilities that prized their novelty,
label: Paragraph

text: and celebrated by local critics influential enough to get them widely
label: Paragraph

text: noticed. Architectural historians now worry about this, about repeatedly
label: Paragraph

text: retelling dominant but partisan stories. To compensate, they’ve worked to
label: Paragraph

text: make their histories more diverse and inclusive, to illustrate who has the
label: Paragraph

text: power to build what, when, where, how, and for whom, A very short book
label: Paragraph

text: like this inevitably has to omit far more than it includes, so I’ve focused
label: Paragraph

text: here on a small selection of buildings that also account for bigger cultural
label: Paragraph

text: ideas. I emphasize what modern architecture was like, why it was like that,
label: Paragraph

text: and how it was imagined, more than the global patterns of where and when.
label: Paragraph

text: This approach helps me to argue that buildings themselves should be the
label: Paragraph

text: primary source of architectural research: that every building—cathedral or
label: Paragraph

text: bicycle shed, glamorous gallery or your own home—contains architectural,
label: Paragraph

text: cultural, technical, and historical knowledge. It also emphasizes the
label: Paragraph

text: buildings that you need to know to talk knowledgably with others who
label: Paragraph

text: think they already know about modern architecture. Its consequence,
label: Paragraph

text: however, is to reinforce the Euro-American mainstream, omitting buildings
label: Paragraph

text: and characters from other contexts. I’ve tried to mitigate this by including
label: Paragraph

text: some less familiar projects and introducing some familiar examples in less
label: Paragraph

text: familiar ways. Ultimately though, I hope this book will encourage you to
label: Paragraph

text: read further, to go beyond buildings designed largely by white Western men
label: Paragraph

text: in the most powerful countries in the world to explore less-charted but
label: Paragraph

text: equally important moder architectures.

text: Chapter 2
label: Title

text: Iron and steel
label: Title

text: A bridge to modernity
label: Title

text: My story about modern architecture begins with an iron bridge completed
label: Paragraph

text: in 1779 (Figure 1). It’s only questionably modern and, for that matter, only
label: Paragraph

text: questionably architecture. But it illustrates the industrial cultures where
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture started to form.
label: Paragraph

text: 1. Iron Bridge, Ironbridge, Shropshire, UK, completed 1779. A
label: Caption

text: technological wonder of its time, which displayed and promoted a set
label: Paragraph

text: of emerging ideas about what later became called modernity. While
label: Paragraph

text: built from a new material—iron—it still subscribed to the traditional
label: Paragraph

text: image of a bridge built in masonry. (Fabricator: Abraham Darby III;
label: Caption

text: Architect: Thomas Pritchard.)
label: Caption

text: The bridge was made from five arched cast-iron ribs, spreading their load to
label: Paragraph

text: two masonry abutments, assembled without using nuts and bolts. The
label: Caption

text: bridge became so famous, because its construction was so novel, that the
label: Paragraph

text: town forming around it took its name. Ironbridge, sat in a mineral-rich
label: Paragraph

text: gorge in England’s West Midlands, became the crucible of the 18th
label: Paragraph

text: century’s Industrial Revolution.
label: Paragraph

text: The Iron Bridge was proposed by an architect, Thomas Pritchard—and it
label: Paragraph

text: bears his ornamental flourishes—but it was executed under the direction of
label: Paragraph

text: a fabricator, Abraham Darby III. The Darby family’s Coalbrookdale
label: Caption

text: foundry was then a world leader in iron production. The first Abraham
label: Paragraph

text: Darby had worked out how to use coked coal, rather than charcoal made
label: Paragraph

text: from timber, to raise temperatures in the blast furnaces where iron was
label: Paragraph

text: made. This yielded consistently higher quality iron at lower cost, made in
label: Paragraph

text: large furnaces that could run continuously. Coalbrookdale’s innovations in
label: Paragraph

text: the volume production of iron, and growing experience in fabricating iron
label: Paragraph

text: components, contributed not just to the bridge but to the whole Industrial
label: Paragraph

text: Revolution.
label: Paragraph

text: The Iron Bridge introduces four themes that recur throughout this book.
label: Paragraph

text: First, it indicates the beginnings of a shift in global culture, over two
label: Paragraph

text: centuries, from artisan manufacturing towards mass production. While the
label: Paragraph

text: components of the bridge were sourced nearby—using local ironstone, clay,
label: Paragraph

text: sand, limestone, coal, and water—it was assembled from a limited number
label: Paragraph

text: of repeated components. This anticipated a huge cultural shift. New
label: Paragraph

text: technologies enabled cheaper and quicker manufacturing, opening up
label: Paragraph

text: industrial production in fields—like textiles and furniture—that were
label: Paragraph

text: previously the province of artisans. This new industrial culture usually
label: Paragraph

text: separated design from making. Where seamstresses or joiners, for example,
label: Paragraph

text: made design decisions with their tools in hand, based on their experience of
label: Paragraph

text: working materials, designers began to emerge in various fields who
label: Paragraph

text: imagined artefacts and drew them for others to make. In consequence,
label: Paragraph

text: makers’ skills became increasingly channelled into the accurate
label: Paragraph

text: reproduction of given designs. While the figure of the architect emerged
label: Paragraph

text: well before mass production—out of ancient origins rediscovered in the
label: Paragraph

text: 15th century—the modern idea of the professional who draws buildings got
label: Paragraph

text: shaped in association with this emerging idea of design. The modern notion
label: Paragraph

text: of construction as an industry emerged with it, gradually replacing old
label: Paragraph

text: priorities of art and craft in building with new ideas about efficiency and
label: Paragraph

text: predictability.
label: Paragraph

text: Second, the Iron Bridge illustrates the emergence of the idea of a single
label: Paragraph

text: global culture. Early mass production, like that in the Severn gorge, quickly
label: Paragraph

text: exceeded the stock of local raw materials. The hunger of new factories,
label: Paragraph

text: from blast foundries to textile mills, and the hunger of their owners for
label: Paragraph

text: profit, meant that materials and workers were sought elsewhere as local
label: Paragraph

text: supplies dwindled. Associated ideas about raw materials being
label: Paragraph

text: commodities, and individual workers combining into a collective called
label: Paragraph

text: labour, started to form the modern habit of imagining the world in terms of
label: Paragraph

text: resources to be exploited.
label: Paragraph

text: The more the machines produced, and the greater the demand for their
label: Paragraph

text: cheaper products, the wider the distribution of those products. Transport
label: Paragraph

text: infrastructures were constructed to bring in material and labour resources,
label: Paragraph

text: and to ship out manufactured ones. For example, in a short time at the end
label: Paragraph

text: of the 18th century, the River Severn flowing through Ironbridge became
label: Paragraph

text: linked to other rivers via a canal network connecting British cities, joined
label: Paragraph

text: with ports linked to global shipping. By the middle of the 19th century,
label: Paragraph

text: these canals were supplanted by railways that could move more goods and
label: Paragraph

text: people at higher speeds. In the later 20th century, railways themselves
label: Paragraph

text: became overtaken by motorways, air transport, and containerization. Thus,
label: Paragraph

text: the transport infrastructures made necessary by industry expanded and
label: Paragraph

text: accelerated during the modern period. They produced in their wake a global
label: Paragraph

text: culture where industry flourished, and where global consumption and mass
label: Paragraph

text: travel seemed to shrink distances and cultural differences.
label: Paragraph

text: This alliance of trade, industry, and shipping fuelled Western countries’
label: Paragraph

text: colonization of parts of Africa, Asia, and the Americas during the 18th and
label: Paragraph

text: 19th centuries. For example, in northeast England, on the River Tyne rather
label: Paragraph

text: than the Severn, Lord Armstrong’s Elswick Works produced munitions,
label: Paragraph

text: ships, and hydraulic construction equipment. These were sold without
label: Paragraph

text: scruple to armies, militia, governments, and corporations including—
label: Paragraph

text: famously—both sides of the same conflict. Fuelled by technocratic
label: Paragraph

text: enterprises like Armstrong’s, colonialism opened up what became imagined
label: Paragraph

text: as the material and human resources of conquered lands to the new
label: Paragraph

text: industries. It brought enormous wealth to European and North American
label: Paragraph

text: captains of industry, and often significant suffering to the places and
label: Paragraph

text: peoples plundered. The novel goods and values exported by new industries
label: Paragraph

text: celebrated global commerce, market forces, and the idea of industry as
label: Paragraph

text: progress—which then seemed to become their inevitable consequence.
label: Paragraph

text: Just as the idea of a single global culture is latent in the reproduced
label: Paragraph

text: components of the Iron Bridge, so too are modern ideas of economy and
label: Paragraph

text: technology. Taken together, these constitute the third theme I argue that the
label: Paragraph

text: bridge illustrates. New industries—like Coalbrookdale Foundry—produced
label: Paragraph

text: massive social and cultural change in the 18th and early 19th centuries. The
label: Paragraph

text: population of England’s West Midlands, like much of Western Europe and
label: Paragraph

text: later the USA, shifted largely from rural agricultural work to urban
label: Paragraph

text: industrial work. Growing urban populations sustained industrial production
label: Paragraph

text: and encouraged the consumption of its outputs. The massive changes that
label: Paragraph

text: successive generations observed—the emergence of labour-saving devices,
label: Paragraph

text: for example, from the mangle to the fridge; or wonder drugs from
label: Paragraph

text: anaesthetics to antibiotics—became inextricably linked in people’s minds
label: Paragraph

text: with the idea of technology. And this association of technology with
label: Paragraph

text: progress, popularized through novel innovations, became inseparable from
label: Paragraph

text: modernity.
label: Paragraph

text: The reach of manufacturing industries and transport infrastructures
label: Title

text: increasingly extended into almost every facet of everyday life. And the
label: Paragraph

text: global economy on which the modem idea of progress relied became
label: Paragraph

text: increasingly pervasive. The word ‘economy’ once referred to the frugal
label: Paragraph

text: management of a household, to an ancient villa and its land, sustaining a
label: Paragraph

text: society of people living and working there, standing for the idea that just
label: Paragraph

text: enough was sufficient. But the substantial costs of industrial production,
label: Paragraph

text: and the extravagant profits to be made from it, made loan finance—once
label: Paragraph

text: condemned as the evil of ‘usury’—more culturally acceptable. The
label: Paragraph

text: financiers made the biggest profits of all. In the late 19th and early 20th
label: Paragraph

text: centuries, colonialism and transport globalized finance at least as much as
label: Paragraph

text: they globalized the new industries.
label: Paragraph

text: The Iron Bridge also introduces a fourth idea, about architectural
label: Paragraph

text: ‘imageability’. Whether or not it was the first iron bridge in the world—
label: Paragraph

text: that’s been debated—it was the first whose image became widely
label: Paragraph

text: distributed. At the time, its spindly see-through structure looked remarkable
label: Paragraph

text: to eyes accustomed to brick or stone. How could something so apparently
label: Paragraph

text: fragile be evidently so strong? The structure drew artists intrigued to depict
label: Paragraph

text: it. An exhibition celebrating the bridge’s bicentenary in 1979, held at
label: Paragraph

text: London’s Royal Academy, collected over fifty images made between 1750
label: Paragraph

text: and 1830. Pictures of the bridge, sat in its picturesque gorge, symbolized
label: Caption

text: the wonder of technology. And new media technologies—like engraving
label: Paragraph

text: and printing—allowed the widespread distribution of its imagery, lending it
label: Paragraph

text: global significance. Like many famous works of modern architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: images of the Iron Bridge seemed to surpass the structure’s own physical
label: Paragraph

text: presence. Its depiction, in paintings and engravings, acquired a currency
label: Paragraph

text: beyond the original, admired by a much bigger audience than had seen the
label: Paragraph

text: bridge first hand, making it a striking symbol of the idea of the new.
label: Paragraph

text: The Iron Bridge also illustrates imageability in another way. Made in iron,
label: Paragraph

text: assembled from multiple components, it’s constructed in the same form as a
label: Paragraph

text: masonry arch. Effectively, it took what was then the known image of a
label: Paragraph

text: bridge—the arch—and reproduced it in a new material. Arches suit how
label: Paragraph

text: brick and stone behave in compression (when loaded with weight from
label: Paragraph

text: above), distributing loads evenly from central keystones to the ground. Iron,
label: Paragraph

text: meanwhile, has different properties. Made into chain links and cables, it
label: Paragraph

text: performs better in tension (where forces tend to pull it apart). This was
label: Paragraph

text: exploited in 1801 in the inventor James Finlay’s design for Jacob’s Creek
label: Paragraph

text: Bridge in Westmorland County, Pennsylvania, suspending a deck from iron
label: Caption

text: trusses and establishing the basic components of the modern suspension
label: Paragraph

text: bridge. Later structures, like engineer Thomas Telford’s Menai Bridge in
label: Paragraph

text: North Wales, 1820, and Isambard Kingdom Brunel’s Clifton Suspension
label: Title

text: Bridge in Bristol, UK, 1834, consolidated a new logic for iron construction
label: Paragraph

text: and a new image for iron bridges derived more directly from the logic of
label: Paragraph

text: the material. While Ironbridge’s Iron Bridge was innovative, it was
label: Paragraph

text: nevertheless constrained in its designers’ imaginations by their prevailing
label: Paragraph

text: idea of what a bridge ought to look like.
label: Paragraph

text: This raises an important point—that there remain deeply embedded cultural
label: Paragraph

text: assumptions about the imagery of certain types of buildings and structures.
label: Paragraph

text: Children learn culturally coded images so they can distinguish a living
label: Paragraph

text: room from a street, for example, or a house from an office, and people think
label: Paragraph

text: they know what buildings look like after that. But these codes become so
label: Paragraph

text: powerful that designers take time to challenge them. More significantly,
label: Paragraph

text: they become so powerful that people find it hard to accept new architectural
label: Paragraph

text: images when familiar ones are challenged.
label: Paragraph

text: I want to mention one last way that the Iron Bridge anticipated modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. Recent surveys of the bridge showed how its repeated
label: Paragraph

text: components were adjusted individually, during manufacturing, to fit their
label: Paragraph

text: neighbours. There is, it’s been shown, tens of millimetres’ difference
label: Paragraph

text: between seemingly identical components. The ideal of mass production in
label: Paragraph

text: architecture has always been that: an ideal. Despite ongoing enthusiasm for
label: Paragraph

text: industrialization, particular builders usually constructed modern buildings
label: Paragraph

text: on particular sites for particular clients, from the drawings of particular
label: Paragraph

text: designers. During the 20th century, it grew less common for architects to
label: Paragraph

text: design every detail of buildings and more common for them to specify
label: Paragraph

text: mass-produced components, like prefabricated doorsets, roof trusses, or
label: Paragraph

text: kitchen units. Only rarely, however, were whole buildings mass produced.
label: Paragraph

text: Nevertheless, the image of mass production remained insistent in modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, to the point where bespoke buildings were sometimes made to
label: Paragraph

text: look prefabricated to assert their modernity. Commentators keen on
label: Paragraph

text: industrial production argued repeatedly over more than a century that
label: Paragraph

text: prefabrication was the imminent future of architecture, without it being
label: Paragraph

text: fulfilled on any scale.
label: Paragraph

text: Iron and modern science
label: Title

text: It’s remarkable that iron manufacturing ever became widespread. Iron is
label: Paragraph

text: extracted from mineral, from iron ore, at a boiling point of 1,535 °C,
label: Paragraph

text: involving fierce heat and light. This doesn’t produce pure iron but an
label: Paragraph

text: impure substance—named ‘pig iron’ after the shape of the casting beds
label: Paragraph

text: once used—which is hard and brittle. This then gets remelted, during which
label: Paragraph

text: time it is carefully ‘decarburized’ to control the level of carbon and
label: Paragraph

text: impurities like sulphur, improving the strength of the material, before being
label: Paragraph

text: left once again to cool.
label: Paragraph

text: It’s sometimes claimed that the engineering innovations of the Industrial
label: Paragraph

text: Revolution emerged from modern science. But, until the mid-19th century,
label: Paragraph

text: the history of iron manufacturing was largely the history of trial and error.
label: Paragraph

text: Telford’s and Brunel’s bridges, for example, were worked out from instinct
label: Paragraph

text: and experience, preceding any comprehensive theory of structures. Thomas
label: Paragraph

text: Newcomen’s and James Watt’s 18th-century work developing steam
label: Title

text: engines—despite the latter’s theoretical research into chemistry late in life
label: Paragraph

text: —emerged from the workshop and not from calculation. Likewise, the
label: Paragraph

text: Darby family’s endeavours at Coalbrookdale were based on testing and
label: Paragraph

text: observation. Early 19th-century engineering aspired to scientific authority,
label: Paragraph

text: however, and science encouraged the culture in which engineering
label: Paragraph

text: flourished.
label: Paragraph

text: The modern idea of science—seeking mathematical descriptions of natural
label: Paragraph

text: phenomena out of systematic experiments—emerged in the West in the 16th
label: Paragraph

text: and 17th centuries. It was popularized by the reputations of figures like
label: Paragraph

text: Nicolaus Copernicus (1473-1543), who proposed in 1549 that the Earth
label: Paragraph

text: revolved around the sun and not vice versa, and Isaac Newton (1642-1727),
label: Paragraph

text: whose physics linked astronomical observations with Earth-bound ones,
label: Paragraph

text: producing theories of optics and calculus. Theories like these emphasized
label: Paragraph

text: rational analysis, encouraging a gradual shift from a God-fearing medieval
label: Paragraph

text: society, where humans imagined themselves subservient to the natural
label: Paragraph

text: world, towards a 20th-century secular condition where science and
label: Paragraph

text: technology made humans feel they could control the world.
label: Paragraph

text: After the construction of the Iron Bridge, there were rapid improvements in
label: Paragraph

text: making iron stronger and more predictable. Henry Cort patented the
label: Paragraph

text: puddling process in 1783, stirring molten iron to draw in oxygen and burn
label: Paragraph

text: out carbon. In 1832, John Gibbons tried different geometries of blast
label: Paragraph

text: furnace, significantly increasing production capacity. By the mid-19th
label: Paragraph

text: century, wrought iron became a reliable construction material, albeit that
label: Paragraph

text: mass-produced components were still tested by hand and eye to ensure their
label: Paragraph

text: soundness. It was only towards the end of that century that the design of
label: Paragraph

text: iron structures became more scientific, when engineers learnt to calculate
label: Paragraph

text: stresses and deflections accurately.
label: Paragraph

text: The St Geneviéve Library in Paris was designed by architect Henri
label: Paragraph

text: Labrouste between 1838 and 1850, at the point between early experiments
label: Paragraph

text: in mass producing iron components and their widespread use in building,
label: Paragraph

text: between trial and error and applied science. The twin iron vaults of its lofty
label: Paragraph

text: reading room were tied to thick stone piers lining the perimeter, connected
label: Paragraph

text: by arched openings containing tall bookstacks with windows above (Figure
label: Caption

text: 2). In conjunction with the building’s spare decoration, the vaults
label: Paragraph

text: anticipated the light and airy qualities of modern buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: 2, St Geneviéve Library, Paris, France, 1850. Slender iron vaults
label: Caption

text: contained by masonry walls, built at a time poised between trial and
label: Paragraph

text: error in engineering and the emergence of reliable structural
label: Title

text: calculations. Its architect, Henri Labrouste, sought a new resolution
label: Paragraph

text: between novel technologies of construction and the idea that
label: Paragraph

text: architecture could be a vital expression of culture.
label: Paragraph

text: St Geneviéve Library was controversial in mid-19th-century Paris. It
label: Paragraph

text: rejected the prevailing idea, promoted by that city’s famous architecture
label: Paragraph

text: school, L’Ecole des Beaux-Arts, that architecture should involve the artful
label: Paragraph

text: composition of decorative forms derived from scholarly study of the orders
label: Paragraph

text: of classical architecture. The library instead appeared strikingly plain.
label: Paragraph

text: Structure and decoration were effectively separated out. Decoration was
label: Paragraph

text: applied to panels set into, and between, the primary structure, expressing
label: Paragraph

text: the structural design of the building visually. These ideas chimed with
label: Paragraph

text: emerging architectural thinkers, notably John Ruskin, whose book Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Painters (first published anonymously in 1843) argued that art should be
label: Paragraph

text: honest to the realities of nature; expanded in his Seven Lamps of
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture, 1849, which promoted truth—including the honest expression
label: Paragraph

text: of structural forces—as essential to beauty and life. For these reasons—of
label: Paragraph

text: material, structure, and decoration—the St Geneviéve library was later
label: Paragraph

text: claimed as a progenitor of modern architecture. But it also stood for
label: Paragraph

text: emerging modernity in another way.
label: Paragraph

text: Labrouste knew the novelist Victor Hugo, who remains famous for The
label: Paragraph

text: Hunchback of Notre Dame, written at the time of the July Revolution in
label: Paragraph

text: France in 1830 and published in 1831. Hugo asked Labrouste to comment
label: Paragraph

text: on a draft chapter criticizing scholarly Beaux Arts architecture. Set in Notre
label: Caption

text: Dame Cathedral in 1482, the chapter follows an encounter between
label: Paragraph

text: archdeacon Claude Frollo and a character who turns out to be King Louis
label: Paragraph

text: XI. At a key moment, Frollo glances down at a printed book on the table
label: Paragraph

text: and then up through a window to the towers of the Cathedral. ‘This’ (the
label: Paragraph

text: book), he reflects wistfully, ‘will kill that’ (the Cathedral). Hugo’s novel
label: Paragraph

text: was set when the invention of the printing press, by Johannes Gutenberg in
label: Paragraph

text: 1436, allowed the widespread distribution of books. But Hugo made a
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary point. He claimed, via Frollo, that architecture was
label: Paragraph

text: understood before printing, before mass production, not just in terms of
label: Paragraph

text: shelter or as a container of human activities but instead as a form of
label: Paragraph

text: knowledge. And that knowledge—carved in stone in the great buildings of
label: Paragraph

text: human culture—was a kind of cultural currency that could be read by the
label: Paragraph

text: people whose lives those great buildings touched. Architecture, he
label: Paragraph

text: suggested, was a force for social integration because it expressed shared
label: Paragraph

text: symbols. Hugo’s character argued that architecture was losing its uniting
label: Paragraph

text: power to the page, prophesizing that the spread of Copernican and
label: Paragraph

text: Newtonian science, through printing, would encourage the culture of
label: Paragraph

text: industrialization to take over every facet of human life. Hugo thus took aim
label: Paragraph

text: at the Beaux Arts architects who derived their designs from book learning,
label: Paragraph

text: copying, and recopying forms from the Greeks and Romans, forgetting, he
label: Paragraph

text: thought, how to think for themselves. They made empty copies of ancient
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, he implied, in a city where Notre Dame showed how
label: Paragraph

text: architecture once embodied the latest knowledge, and where it could do that
label: Paragraph

text: again.
label: Paragraph

text: The historian Neil Levine argued that Labrouste’s design for his strange,
label: Paragraph

text: plain library—with its spindly iron vaults and resistance to Classical style—
label: Paragraph

text: was an optimistic response to Hugo’s criticism: an attempt to make
label: Paragraph

text: architecture a cultural force again, this time reflecting the 19th century’s
label: Paragraph

text: emerging knowledge. The library’s plain stone facades were carved with
label: Paragraph

text: 810 names in twenty-seven panels, presenting a roll call of thinkers
label: Caption

text: collected in the library (all male), organized in chronological order from the
label: Paragraph

text: Old Testament figure Moses to the Swedish scientist Bezelius, who died in
label: Paragraph

text: 1848 when the names were carved. The architecture of the library thus
label: Paragraph

text: echoed and celebrated the printed page. If the book had killed ancient
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, as Hugo supposed, then St Geneviéve Library suggested that
label: Paragraph

text: architecture could be made afresh out of the new scientific world of the
label: Paragraph

text: book. The names on the library’s fagades described the huge intellectual
label: Paragraph

text: shift from medieval European cultures dominated by a single Christian
label: Title

text: God, to the so-called rational thought of 19th-century modern science and
label: Paragraph

text: technology. Designed at the beginning of the so-called Second Republic in
label: Paragraph

text: France, the names also described a parallel, connected shift towards ideas of
label: Paragraph

text: modern industrial democracy, away from the absolute monarchies of the
label: Paragraph

text: European past. The library’s vaults—made in iron, the technological
label: Paragraph

text: material of the moment—were physically and metaphorically tied to stone
label: Paragraph

text: walls whose carved names expressed the intellectual forces that iron
label: Paragraph

text: seemed to represent. The vaults stood for their architect’s premonition that a
label: Paragraph

text: meaningful modern architecture was possible, derived from modem science
label: Paragraph

text: and the technical culture of industrial production.
label: Paragraph

text: The library highlighted an apparent tension emerging at that time between
label: Paragraph

text: engineering and architecture, between new technologies of construction and
label: Paragraph

text: an older idea of architecture as an expression of culture. How, it seemed to
label: Paragraph

text: ask, might the organization and imagery of architecture embrace the culture
label: Paragraph

text: of modernity? This fraught question preoccupied certain architects well into
label: Paragraph

text: the next century.
label: Paragraph

text: Space and industrial culture
label: Title

text: Railways arrived in European and American cities in the mid-19th century,
label: Paragraph

text: and their promoters’ lofty terminus stations—frequently boasting dramatic
label: Paragraph

text: iron vaults—became understood in retrospect as further addressing this
label: Paragraph

text: question, shifting attention from architecture’s facades to its interior spaces.
label: Paragraph

text: St Pancras Station, London, 1868, is a famous example. Its train shed’s
label: Paragraph

text: arched trusses—designed by engineer William Barlow—soared 75 metres
label: Paragraph

text: over the tracks without intermediate columns. Still influenced by older
label: Caption

text: ideas about civic decorum, however, this striking display of iron’s potential
label: Paragraph

text: was enclosed within masonry walls and concealed from the street by the
label: Paragraph

text: ten-storey Midland Grand Hotel: a Gothic Revival fairy tale decorated with
label: Caption

text: gables and fancy balconies, designed by architect George Gilbert Scott.
label: Caption

text: Architecture and engineering, trainshed and station building, were
label: Paragraph

text: frequently separated—physically and intellectually—in such railway
label: Paragraph

text: terminals. But it was the iron sheds that most captured peoples’
label: Paragraph

text: imaginations. It’s no coincidence that painter Edouard Manet chose the
label: Paragraph

text: trainshed of a Parisian station, buzzing with activity and filled evocatively
label: Paragraph

text: with steam, to depict the emerging atmosphere of modernity—rather than
label: Paragraph

text: the conventional station building—in his painting Gare Saint-Lazare, 1873.
label: Caption

text: At that time, engineers—not architects—were most comfortable with the
label: Paragraph

text: structural opportunities, imagery, and space-enclosing potential of iron.
label: Paragraph

text: Some, like Gustave Eiffel and Joseph Paxton, came from working-class
label: Paragraph

text: backgrounds and transcended rigid class structures through
label: Paragraph

text: entrepreneurship and technical cunning. Paxton and Eiffel cultivated the
label: Paragraph

text: image of self-made practical people that just got on with things, in
label: Paragraph

text: opposition to scholarly gentleman architects who, the implication was,
label: Paragraph

text: dithered and delayed. They reimagined iron not just as a material for roofs
label: Paragraph

text: within masonry walls, but as structural framing that could define the spaces
label: Paragraph

text: of buildings. Indeed, they helped define the idea of ‘space’ as the end result
label: Paragraph

text: of modern architecture: a notion still forming as recently as the 1920s.
label: Paragraph

text: Paxton was a gardener turned engineer. He earned his reputation as the
label: Paragraph

text: Duke of Devonshire’s fixer, transforming the Duke’s park at Chatsworth,
label: Paragraph

text: UK, with hydraulic fountains, water displays, and a new village to replace
label: Paragraph

text: one previously disrupting the Duke’s view. Paxton’s iron-framed glass
label: Caption

text: house there—the Great Conservatory, 1837—inspired the commission for
label: Paragraph

text: another at London’s Kew Gardens, 1849, housing a giant waterlily ‘found’
label: Paragraph

text: in the colony of British Guiana. When a pet project of Queen Victoria’s
label: Paragraph

text: consort, Prince Albert—for a temporary Great Exhibition of technological
label: Paragraph

text: wonders and colonial ‘curiosities’ in London’s Hyde Park—ran into
label: Paragraph

text: difficulties in 1851, Paxton proposed a giant greenhouse to contain the
label: Paragraph

text: exhibits: a ‘Crystal Palace’ made from mass-produced components—
label: Title

text: conceived for speed and efficiency of construction (Figure 3).
label: Paragraph

text: 3. Crystal Palace, London, UK, 1851. A temporary display-case for
label: Caption

text: globalized modernity, constructed with great ingenuity in iron and
label: Paragraph

text: glass. It illustrated vividly the emerging connections between global
label: Paragraph

text: finance and colonial exploitation, between ideas about progress and a
label: Paragraph

text: universal free market, and industrial production and the idea of the
label: Title

text: state.
label: Paragraph

text: Paxton devised a system of structural iron elements holding the largest
label: Paragraph

text: sheets of glass then available, fixed into timber ‘Paxton gutters’ supported
label: Paragraph

text: on a grid of iron trusses, columns, and beams. Those trusses were raised
label: Paragraph

text: into place using horse power, aided by counter-weighted blocks. Special
label: Paragraph

text: wagons were designed, whose wheels fitted into the gutters, on which
label: Paragraph

text: glaziers lay to fix the panes quickly. Bolt holes in the ironwork were
label: Paragraph

text: machined in the foundry to save filing them smooth on site. And special
label: Paragraph

text: machines were designed to produce several grooved and bevelled sash-bars
label: Paragraph

text: at once out of a single plank of timber. The shell of the Crystal Palace—
label: Paragraph

text: then the largest enclosed space in the world—was erected in just four
label: Paragraph

text: months. Opening panels were added at high level to extract rising hot air,
label: Paragraph

text: and a timber slatted floor allowed cool air to be drawn in to replace it at low
label: Paragraph

text: level, with the Paxton gutters profiled to collect condensation. These
label: Paragraph

text: climate control measures were carefully considered but they couldn’t
label: Paragraph

text: mitigate the overheating and overlighting problems of putting an exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: in a large greenhouse in summer, and various exhibitors—including
label: Paragraph

text: Armstrong’s Elswick Works and Coalbrookdale Foundry—hung giant
label: Title

text: drapes to shade their exhibits. Attracting visitors in vast numbers, the
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition illustrated modern ideas and helped establish a new popular
label: Paragraph

text: enchantment with technological progress. The Crystal Palace stood for
label: Paragraph

text: fresh mythologies celebrating rational science and technical innovation, and
label: Paragraph

text: a gradual shift away from traditional religious mythologies. Moreover, it
label: Paragraph

text: served as a display case for the emerging products of modern globalized
label: Paragraph

text: trade, illustrating vividly the burgeoning connections between global
label: Paragraph

text: finance and colonial exploitation, ideas about progress and a universal free
label: Title

text: market, and industrial production and the idea of the state.
label: Paragraph

text: Refining ideas about mass production already latent in the Iron Bridge, the
label: Paragraph

text: Crystal Palace also anticipated the modern idea of space. Visitors circulated
label: Paragraph

text: inside its grid of slender columns and spidery trusses, with countless
label: Paragraph

text: glimpses appearing and disappearing in a perpetual interlacing of structure.
label: Paragraph

text: In long perspective, the grids of columns and glazing bars stretched almost
label: Paragraph

text: to infinity. The palace’s volume thus exemplified the mathematical
label: Paragraph

text: conception of space: as a grid measured in equal increments on x, y, and z
label: Paragraph

text: axes, as a field extending to infinity in all directions.
label: Paragraph

text: If moving around the Crystal Palace felt strikingly new, then the first
label: Paragraph

text: experiences of climbing the curving latticework of Eiffel’s Tower must have
label: Paragraph

text: seemed something else again. Gustave Eiffel, son of a German forester,
label: Paragraph

text: began as an apprentice engineer before founding a design-build firm
label: Paragraph

text: serving the railway boom, opening metal workshops in a Parisian suburb.
label: Paragraph

text: He made a reputation building large-span iron bridges: at Oporto, Portugal,
label: Paragraph

text: 1875; and the world’s largest arch, plus a series of pylons, at Garabit in
label: Paragraph

text: France’s Massif Central, 1884. Eiffel also engineered the Statue of Liberty
label: Paragraph

text: —shipped to New York as a gift from France, 1881—developing a
label: Paragraph

text: mathematical solution for the tricky structural problem of raising Liberty’s
label: Paragraph

text: torch-bearing arm outwards from her body.
label: Paragraph

text: Eiffel’s tower was the centrepiece of another temporary exhibition of
label: Paragraph

text: technological wonders—the 1889 Paris World’s Fair—housed in pavilions
label: Paragraph

text: around its base. Designed for rapid construction, it tapped his previous
label: Paragraph

text: experience. The tower was effectively a giant bridge pylon without the
label: Paragraph

text: bridge, sat on foundations made using pressurized waterproof caissons,
label: Paragraph

text: invented for building footings in rivers, allowing it to be constructed on
