text: steel glazing bars—and panels of brickwork. To emphasize honestly that the
label: Paragraph

text: brick was infill and not supporting structure, it was set forward from the
label: Paragraph

text: frame as a visually separate plane. This assembly was topped with a flat
label: Paragraph

text: roof hidden behind the steel capping beam, with hidden gutters. The facades
label: Caption

text: were understood as a straightforward visual consequence of the spaces
label: Paragraph

text: inside, and the means of construction. Windowless end elevations—a grid
label: Paragraph

text: of welded steels and brick infill panels—were likened by Mies fans to the
label: Paragraph

text: abstract modern paintings of Piet Mondrian.
label: Paragraph

text: 6. Minerals and Metals Research Building, Illinois Institute of
label: Caption

text: Technology (IIT), Chicago, USA, 1947. The first in a sequence of
label: Caption

text: buildings laid out on a grid on the IIT campus, seeking to perfect the
label: Paragraph

text: ideal image for modern steel campus buildings. (Architect: Ludwig
label: Caption

text: Mies van der Rohe.)
label: Paragraph

text: Wishnick Hall, and Alumni Memorial Hall, 1946, and the Metallurgical and
label: Paragraph

text: Chemical Engineering Building, 1947, tested variations of the formula,
label: Paragraph

text: exploring different corner and capping details, welding together
label: Paragraph

text: combinations of I-section, rectangular hollow section, and flat plate steels
label: Paragraph

text: to achieve subtly different effects. Extended through multiple projects at
label: Paragraph

text: IIT, Mies’s office engaged in the obsessive refinement of an architectural
label: Paragraph

text: system, seeking to isolate ideal forms for campus buildings. Differences
label: Paragraph

text: between successive buildings are barely discernible to non-specialists, but
label: Paragraph

text: fans understood their development as a rigorous, spiritual quest to pare
label: Paragraph

text: architecture down to basic forms and proportions. ‘Less is more,’ Mies
label: Paragraph

text: proclaimed.
label: Paragraph

text: IIT’s architecture school, S.R. Crown Hall, 1956 (Figure 7), is frequently
label: Paragraph

text: acknowledged as the pinnacle of the group, although it’s an exception,
label: Paragraph

text: disobeying the grid, and owing less to its neighbours than a spectacular, if
label: Paragraph

text: largely uninhabitable, house designed by Mies’s office for Edith Famsworth
label: Caption

text: at Plano, Illinois, 1951. That house was conceived as a glass-walled box
label: Paragraph

text: almost hovering above the ground, its rooms subdivided only with
label: Paragraph

text: furniture, with a supporting steel frame placed outside the walls. Crown
label: Paragraph

text: Hall’s fully glazed upper storey, like Farnsworth House, comprised a large
label: Paragraph

text: single space, interrupted only by two stairs and a handful of timber screens.
label: Paragraph

text: It sat on a half-buried basement containing a library, workshop, and
label: Paragraph

text: teaching rooms, with the steel frame again placed outside the building,
label: Paragraph

text: supporting a secondary order of smaller steels holding the glazing.
label: Paragraph

text: 7. S.R. Crown Hall, ITT, Chicago, USA, 1947, The exception that
label: Caption

text: proved the rule on the IIT campus: an apparently hovering glass box,
label: Paragraph

text: its supporting steel frame placed outside the walls, containing a single
label: Paragraph

text: studio space, with ‘servant spaces’ in the basement below. Historians
label: Paragraph

text: have understood it as a modern reinvention of the classical temple,
label: Paragraph

text: poised above the ground on a plinth. (Architect: Ludwig Mies van der
label: Caption

text: Rohe.)
label: Paragraph

text: Crown Hall was a modern abstraction of a classical Greek temple, with a
label: Paragraph

text: stepped base, columns, and intricately judged proportions. Its single studio
label: Paragraph

text: room symbolized rational modern space. That room’s ceiling—dropped to
label: Paragraph

text: hide the upper glazing bars of the perimeter window frames—was inscribed
label: Paragraph

text: with a grid, seemingly extending into the infinite distance. The glass walls
label: Paragraph

text: were clear at the top and obscured with milky film below, focusing the
label: Paragraph

text: students’ view on the sky and trees—understood as universal symbols of
label: Paragraph

text: the natural world—rather than the messiness of passers-by. The fact of so
label: Paragraph

text: many students sharing a large room, their desks arranged in orderly rows,
label: Paragraph

text: produced a monastic calm where Mies’s curriculum was obsessively
label: Paragraph

text: pursued. Some saw the studio as a blank canvas accentuating the vibrancy
label: Paragraph

text: of human life within. Others understood its abstract qualities, and its
label: Paragraph

text: tendency to make its inhabitants self-police their behaviour, as rigid and
label: Paragraph

text: autocratic.
label: Paragraph

text: It’s seldom done in histories of modern architecture to note that the exposed
label: Paragraph

text: steelwork of Mies’s IIT buildings, paired with thin brickwork panels and
label: Paragraph

text: single-glazed windows, made the buildings perishingly cold in Chicago’s
label: Paragraph

text: freezing winters, and unbearably hot in summer. It’s also rare to mention
label: Paragraph

text: that, because steel and brickwork expand and contract at different rates,
label: Paragraph

text: many brick panels cracked, and flat roofs, hidden behind steel for visual
label: Paragraph

text: effect, regularly leaked. For Mies fans—like the admirers of other famous
label: Paragraph

text: modern architects—these were merely defensible consequences of genius.
label: Paragraph

text: Until recently, architectural histories also rarely acknowledged that the
label: Paragraph

text: blocks over which Mies laid his planning grid were no empty lot. They
label: Paragraph

text: were cleared as slums by the largely white city and Institute authorities in
label: Paragraph

text: the 1940s, having previously housed a notable middle-class black
label: Paragraph

text: community whose cultural life was expressed in a vibrant jazz scene. Some
label: Paragraph

text: have reinterpreted their demolition as racially motivated social cleansing.
label: Paragraph

text: Historian Tim Samuelson has illustrated how the Mecca Apartments, a
label: Paragraph

text: welcoming home for black immigrants to Chicago, immortalized in the
label: Paragraph

text: Mecca Flat Blues (1924), was cleared to make way for Crown Hall. An
label: Paragraph

text: alternative interpretation of Mies’s campus planning grid is thus possible
label: Paragraph

text: here—in conjunction with interpretations of Crown Hall as autocratic—not
label: Paragraph

text: just as a symbol of technical objectivity but also as a symbol of
label: Paragraph

text: authoritarian power.
label: Paragraph

text: Mies in the sky
label: Title

text: Mies’s talent for making architectural images in steel was strikingly
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrated by his office’s high-rise buildings from the 1950s and 1960s.
label: Paragraph

text: These drew inspiration from an early project.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1921, Mies entered an architectural competition for a site on
label: Paragraph

text: Friedrichstrasse in Berlin with a design for a skyscraper. He made two
label: Paragraph

text: striking photomontages celebrating the literal transparency of all-glass
label: Paragraph

text: facades: one showing floor to ceiling glazing enigmatically reflecting the
label: Caption

text: sky in daylight; the other illustrating its see-through qualities when lit from
label: Paragraph

text: within at night. Although they didn’t win Mies the competition, these
label: Paragraph

text: images later became famous, anticipating the modern tower block.
label: Paragraph

text: The first steel towers built to the designs of Mies’s office were twin
label: Paragraph

text: apartment blocks overlooking Lake Michigan, turned at 90 degrees to each
label: Paragraph

text: other, connected with a slender low-level canopy, known as 860-880 Lake
label: Paragraph

text: Shore Drive. Internal ‘cores’ provided the buildings’ structural stability,
label: Paragraph

text: accommodating the elevators and vertical services. Individual flats, eight
label: Caption

text: per floor, were laid out around the cores, designed as open spaces, with
label: Paragraph

text: fitted furniture and sliding screens substituting for most walls and doors.
label: Paragraph

text: Structurally, a grid of primary steel columns was placed inside the outer
label: Paragraph

text: edges of the towers’ floors, encased in concrete for fireproofing.
label: Paragraph

text: Prefabricated secondary steel elements were then fixed to the facade,
label: Paragraph

text: expressed as vertical I-sections, four per structural bay. These steels
label: Paragraph

text: supported aluminium-framed windows and provided so-called lateral
label: Paragraph

text: bracing, reinforcing the building against wind loads. A small break in the
label: Paragraph

text: secondary steels at every floor level illustrated visually on the fagade that
label: Paragraph

text: these secondary steels weren’t continuous, and therefore weren’t primary
label: Paragraph

text: supports for the building. But, to the consternation of Mies fans, every fifth
label: Paragraph

text: I-section was fitted directly over a concrete-encased primary steel column.
label: Paragraph

text: These steels thus had no structural purpose, added instead to maintain the
label: Paragraph

text: rhythm of the fagade. For good modernists accustomed to Mies’s dictum
label: Paragraph

text: that ‘less is more’, and Sullivan’s ‘form ever follows function’, these steels
label: Paragraph

text: remained unnecessary. They were functionally redundant adornments,
label: Paragraph

text: serving only the visual image of the tower, and they became objects of
label: Paragraph

text: controversy among modern architects.
label: Paragraph

text: Just as Mies imagined the Minerals and Metals Building as a prototype for
label: Paragraph

text: campus architecture, Lake Shore Drive was envisaged as a prototype for
label: Paragraph

text: steel-framed towers. The formula was refined in a series of projects
label: Paragraph

text: accommodating diverse functions: further apartments on Commonwealth
label: Paragraph

text: Promenade in Chicago, 1956; courtrooms at the Dirksen Federal Building
label: Caption

text: in Chicago’s Loop, 1964; and offices for distillers Seagram in New York,
label: Paragraph

text: 1958. The same elements recurred: ‘shell-and-core’ planning (an internal
label: Paragraph

text: core containing services and elevators, surrounded by floorplates), and
label: Paragraph

text: ‘curtain’ facades characterized by I-section steels.
label: Paragraph

text: The Seagram building, designed with Philip Johnson, was a refined and
label: Paragraph

text: expensive variation on the theme (Figure 8). Liquor baron Samuel
label: Caption

text: Bronfman, the client, was egged on by his daughter, Phyllis Lambert, who
label: Paragraph

text: trained as an architect at IIT. Rather than stepping back from the street like
label: Paragraph

text: most New York skyscrapers, maximizing the building’s volume within strict
label: Paragraph

text: zoning laws, Seagram was a straightforward rectangular block. Facade I-
label: Paragraph

text: sections were special castings in bronze rather than stock steel sections.
label: Paragraph

text: Key interior surfaces were clad in marble and travertine. A band of artificial
label: Paragraph

text: lighting around the perimeter of each ceiling heightened the drama of the
label: Paragraph

text: building’s stacked floorplates when seen from below at night. Glazed
label: Paragraph

text: internal office partitions were designed to emphasize the open plan layout.
label: Paragraph

text: Venetian blinds were fitted with only three settings—open, closed, and half-
label: Paragraph

text: closed—to present an orderly image to the street. A modern art programme
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned murals, tapestries, and canvases from luminaries including
label: Paragraph

text: Pablo Picasso and Mark Rothko. And a plain granite plaza outside, lifted
label: Caption

text: three steps from the street, made a calm garden. Seagram became the
label: Paragraph

text: archetypal steel and glass tower. It became both typical and exceptional: a
label: Paragraph

text: refined building for a specific client on a specific site, and simultaneously a
label: Paragraph

text: universal symbol of corporate modernity, imitated worldwide.
label: Paragraph

text: 8. Seagram Building, New York, USA, 1958. A ‘shell and core’ tower
label: Caption

text: with ‘curtain’ walls, characterized by I-section columns, providing
label: Paragraph

text: office space for a firm of distillers. It was a key building in its
label: Paragraph

text: architect’s sequence of architectural experiments to find the ideal form
label: Paragraph

text: for the modern tower. Both typical and exceptional, it is both a refined
label: Paragraph

text: building for a specific client on a specific site, and a universal symbol
label: Paragraph

text: of corporate modernity, imitated globally. (Architect: Ludwig Mies van
label: Paragraph

text: der Rohe.)
label: Paragraph

text: The details of Mies’s towers—like columns placed for visual effect as
label: Paragraph

text: cladding over structural ones, and decorative steel casings fitted around
label: Paragraph

text: structural columns—didn’t always express their structural logic directly.
label: Paragraph

text: But they did always illustrate its idea. Mies’s towers, like most modern
label: Paragraph

text: buildings were ‘representational’: they didn’t represent ideas about the past
label: Paragraph

text: like previous architectures had, but engaged instead in self-representation,
label: Paragraph

text: expressing—and sometimes subtly enhancing—the imagery of their own
label: Paragraph

text: constructional logic to evoke ideas about modernity.
label: Paragraph

text: Shaping modern culture in steel
label: Title

text: In 1831, Victor Hugo had anticipated a modern architecture reflecting
label: Paragraph

text: scientific culture, arguing for special buildings, which people could identify
label: Paragraph

text: with as symbols of the age. Mies believed that his work fulfilled this
label: Paragraph

text: promise. Indeed, his fans likened the I-section steels of Lake Shore Drive to
label: Paragraph

text: the tracery of medieval Gothic cathedrals. ‘True architecture,’ Mies
label: Paragraph

text: claimed, ‘is always objective and is the expression of the inner structure of
label: Paragraph

text: our times, from which it comes’. He didn’t just think he was designing
label: Paragraph

text: individual buildings for individual sites and clients. He thought he was
label: Paragraph

text: isolating the universal forms of architecture itself, paring down the logic of
label: Paragraph

text: steel—and building types like campus buildings and high-rise towers—to
label: Paragraph

text: their essential images. Mies imagined himself not as inventing a style, but
label: Paragraph

text: as identifying the authentic, timeless architectural expression of the future.
label: Paragraph

text: Once the job of isolating these forms was done, Mies imagined he would
label: Paragraph

text: pass the images and techniques to others for repeating and refining. He
label: Paragraph

text: imagined he was designing bespoke prototypes for others to mass produce.
label: Paragraph

text: Indeed, he lavished attention on the first campus buildings and towers
label: Paragraph

text: designed in his office but—once he felt the archetypes were established—
label: Paragraph

text: left later versions to his associates.
label: Paragraph

text: Easily imagined as a kit of columns and beams, like the construction toy
label: Paragraph

text: Meccano, iron and steel nurtured ideas about a perfected modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. Philosopher Walter Benjamin noted in 1935 how the imagery
label: Paragraph

text: of iron architecture was derived ‘dialectically’ out of the conflict between
label: Paragraph

text: old symbolic codes developed for stone and wood, and new forms of
label: Paragraph

text: structural technology. Iron and steel frames encouraged the integration of
label: Paragraph

text: structure with services, and ideas of ‘space’ with industrial production,
label: Paragraph

text: assembling buildings from sophisticated engineered components to express
label: Paragraph

text: ideas about technological modernity. The emphasis on the rational
label: Paragraph

text: structural calculation of components shifted design attention from the whole
label: Paragraph

text: building to the part, just as scientific cultures shifted Western thinking from
label: Paragraph

text: traditional holistic religious views to a greater focus on the individual. Such
label: Paragraph

text: shifts were as latent in the Iron Bridge and Eiffel Tower as they were at
label: Paragraph

text: Crown Hall and Seagram. The job of the architect-genius, as Mies
label: Paragraph

text: ‘modestly’ understood himself in later life, was to work through the cultural
label: Paragraph

text: and social consequences of new logics of production, to determine the true
label: Paragraph

text: architectural forms of modernity. For him, the material best suited to those
label: Paragraph

text: labours was steel.

text: Reinforced concrete
label: Title

text: Reinforced concrete and the sale of expertise
label: Title

text: The reinforced concrete entrepreneur Francois Hennebique designed a four-
label: Paragraph

text: storey villa for his family in the Parisian suburb of Bourg-la-Reine in 1904
label: Paragraph

text: (Figure 9), demonstrating his firm’s talents with the material that made his
label: Paragraph

text: fortune. Architectural critics were snobbish about the house’s eccentricities,
label: Paragraph

text: but it remains an object of fascination because of Hennebique’s global
label: Paragraph

text: domination of reinforced concrete construction at the start of the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century.
label: Paragraph

text: 9. Villa Hennebique, Bourg-la-Reine, Paris, France, 1904. A show-off
label: Caption

text: house designed by an entrepreneur for his family, displaying novel uses
label: Paragraph

text: for reinforced concrete. It reflected Hennebique’s global domination of
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced concrete construction at the beginning of the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: (Designer: Francois Hennebique.)
label: Caption

text: Reinforced concrete lends itself to a structural form called the cantilever—
label: Paragraph

text: where a slab or bear is hung outwards from one side, suspended without
label: Paragraph

text: columns, counter-weighted by a mass of structure behind. The Hennebique
label: Caption

text: villa incorporated every kind of cantilever possible at that time. Its floors
label: Paragraph

text: stepped down to the rear as a series of terraces, covered with soil and
label: Paragraph

text: densely planted as ‘hanging gardens’, illustrating concrete’s substantial
label: Paragraph

text: load-bearing capacity. By contrast, the terrace balustrades showed how
label: Paragraph

text: delicate concrete elements could become. Looming above the house,
label: Paragraph

text: cantilevered out from it, was a sculptural concrete water tower, which
label: Paragraph

text: neighbours nicknamed ‘the minaret’. The villa’s external walls followed an
label: Paragraph

text: innovative construction method, where concrete was poured in situ between
label: Paragraph

text: 3-centimetre-thick precast concrete slabs. These slabs provided permanent
label: Paragraph

text: formwork for structural concrete poured in behind, replacing the sacrificial
label: Caption

text: timber shuttering normally used to make temporary moulds for concrete
label: Paragraph

text: construction. They served to conceal the concrete poured on site, whose
label: Paragraph

text: finish could be unreliable, giving a more reliable precast finish, and were
label: Paragraph

text: hand tooled to reveal the flint aggregate used in the mix, so they looked like
label: Paragraph

text: stone from a distance.
label: Paragraph

text: Hennebique didn’t invent reinforced concrete but commercialized it
label: Paragraph

text: ingeniously. The ancient Romans had used concrete 2,000 years before,
label: Paragraph

text: working out how to make mortar by mixing kiln-dried lime with sand and
label: Paragraph

text: water, adding stone dust to produce a paste that set hard when it dried in the
label: Paragraph

text: air. They subsequently found that, by adding a natural compound of iron
label: Paragraph

text: oxide and silica alumina, mortar could harden in large quantities
label: Paragraph

text: independently of the air. We now call this cement. Large quantities of
label: Paragraph

text: cement poured around broken bricks and fragments of stone were employed
label: Paragraph

text: to make the first concrete walls in Rome in the 2nd century BCE (although
label: Paragraph

text: the name concrete, describing cement combined with masonry aggregate,
label: Paragraph

text: didn’t emerge until the 19th century). The most significant Roman
label: Paragraph

text: invention—when concrete started to find its own architectural logic—was
label: Paragraph

text: the vaulted concrete floor, an important invention for the Roman empire
label: Paragraph

text: because of its scarcity of timber. And the most spectacular survival of
label: Paragraph

text: Roman concrete is the soaring dome of the Pantheon in Rome, (probably)
label: Paragraph

text: completed in 125 cE.
label: Paragraph

text: Historically, concrete was strong in compression but poor in tension. It
label: Paragraph

text: proved itself as a material for walls, vaults, and domes—which carry loads
label: Paragraph

text: in compression—but not for beams and spans—reliant on tension. And
label: Paragraph

text: because the outcome of each concrete pour could be temperamental,
label: Paragraph

text: depending on the precise mix, the temperature and humidity when it was
label: Paragraph

text: poured, as well as the builder’s skill in achieving a reliable outcome,
label: Paragraph

text: concrete wasn’t widely used between Roman and Victorian times.
label: Paragraph

text: The structures required by 19th-century industries and infrastructures
label: Paragraph

text: revived interest in concrete, however. As skills in working the material
label: Paragraph

text: gradually improved, inventors tried combining it with iron. Iron was
label: Paragraph

text: stronger in tension but weaker in compression—the opposite properties to
label: Paragraph

text: concrete—and the combination of materials held promise. In 1854, a
label: Paragraph

text: plasterer called William Boutland Wilkinson from Newcastle-upon-Tyne,
label: Paragraph

text: UK, patented a method for inserting iron barrel hoops as tension rods at the
label: Paragraph

text: crown of concrete vaults. In 1875, William Henry Lascelles, a London
label: Caption

text: building contractor, filed a patent for strengthening concrete panels with
label: Paragraph

text: iron rods, and strengthening concrete floors with wire mesh. In 1877,
label: Paragraph

text: Thaddeus Hyatt, a New York manufacturer, published an account of fifteen
label: Paragraph

text: years’ experimentation with reinforced concrete, establishing that iron
label: Paragraph

text: reinforcement added to the bottom of a concrete beam would cope with
label: Paragraph

text: tension, while concrete at the top would handle compression, countering
label: Paragraph

text: what engineers call ‘bending moments’ to produce rigid structural elements.
label: Paragraph

text: He also established that iron covered with concrete would remain
label: Paragraph

text: undamaged in fire, promoting ‘ferro-concrete’ as a fireproof material.
label: Paragraph

text: Experiments and patents multiplied towards the end of the 19th century.
label: Paragraph

text: Hennebique’s own innovations weren’t extraordinary. He substituted steel
label: Paragraph

text: reinforcement for iron, and spaced steel straps closer together near the ends
label: Paragraph

text: of beams where structural loads were greater. It was his patents filed in
label: Paragraph

text: 1892, however, that established his fortune. His genius lay in recognizing
label: Paragraph

text: the commercial opportunities those patents established. As soon as they
label: Paragraph

text: were signed, Hennebique sold his contracting concern and established a
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced concrete construction consultancy. It provided engineering
label: Paragraph

text: drafting services, licensing only reliable contractors to construct its designs.
label: Paragraph

text: And it guarded its intellectual property jealously, challenging infringements
label: Paragraph

text: with legal action. In 1892, the Hennebique firm employed two engineer-
label: Paragraph

text: draughtsmen in Paris, growing by 1894 to fifty-six engineers supplying
label: Paragraph

text: drawings to fifty-five licensed contractors, and by 1909 to sixty-two
label: Paragraph

text: drafting offices around the world. If a client wanted a steel-reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: concrete-framed building at the beginning of the 20th century, they had
label: Paragraph

text: little choice but to use a patented system, among which Hennebique’s was
label: Paragraph

text: most prominent. The firm’s magazine Le Beton Armé (Reinforced Concrete)
label: Caption

text: promoted its technical expertise and extended concrete’s aura of innovation.
label: Paragraph

text: Hennebique thus established the idea of the professional construction
label: Paragraph

text: consultancy, which was as important to the emergence of modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture as any of the buildings discussed in this book.
label: Paragraph

text: Hennebique’s house thus indicated how reinforced concrete could
label: Paragraph

text: symbolize the new, prefiguring the emergence of a technically oriented
label: Paragraph

text: construction industry. It anticipated the higher status and value that
label: Paragraph

text: gradually became accorded to design skills over craft skills. It also
label: Paragraph

text: illustrates how entrepreneurial modern architects and engineers learnt they
label: Paragraph

text: could monetize intellectual property and professional expertise—be it
label: Paragraph

text: technical prowess or visual innovation—as much as designing buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: Ethics of production and living
label: Title

text: Beginning as a gloopy liquid but setting hard, reinforced concrete is a
label: Paragraph

text: troublesome commodity. In philosophy, ‘concrete’ refers to something
label: Paragraph

text: immediately present. However, as Adrian Forty has shown, many thinkers
label: Paragraph

text: have struggled with the contradictory qualities of this demanding material.
label: Paragraph

text: Famous for making dramatic forms, concrete has no form of its own,
label: Paragraph

text: merely shaped by the formwork into which it is poured. Seemingly
label: Paragraph

text: substantial, cement only becomes strong when combined with aggregate
label: Paragraph

text: and steel. While the ingredients of concrete are natural, it grew to
label: Paragraph

text: symbolize the human-made world. And, while it’s been imagined as
label: Paragraph

text: timeless, concrete frequently came to represent the new because of its
label: Paragraph

text: difference from other materials. It was attributed a moral rightness because
label: Paragraph

text: its finished surfaces bear ‘honest’ traces of how they were worked. Less
label: Paragraph

text: legible than steel’s kit of parts, however, concrete became a curious
label: Paragraph

text: architectural symbol of technological modernity.
label: Paragraph

text: American architect Albert Kahn matched Francois Hennebique for
label: Paragraph

text: commercial nous, remarking that ‘architecture is 90% business and 10%
label: Paragraph

text: art’. His office, mixing architects and engineers, designed no-nonsense
label: Paragraph

text: buildings for industry, developing early expertise in reinforced concrete.
label: Paragraph

text: Concrete stood for an ethic of production in the early factories his
label: Paragraph

text: organization designed.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1909, Kahn’s office designed the Automobile Assembly Building for
label: Paragraph

text: motorcar pioneer Henry Ford’s Highland Park plant in Detroit, Michigan
label: Caption

text: (Figure 10). It was laid out around the production line for Ford’s ‘Model T’;
label: Paragraph

text: the vehicle, produced between 1908 and 1927, which opened up motoring
label: Paragraph

text: to ordinary Americans. Early cars were made using traditional
label: Paragraph

text: coachbuilding techniques, where the vehicle stayed in one place, worked on
label: Paragraph

text: by a sequence of skilled trades. Ford instead refined a method of keeping
label: Paragraph

text: trades and machines static while cars moved between them, calculating
label: Paragraph

text: assembly processes around the space needed for each task and the time
label: Paragraph

text: taken to execute it—which became elevated into the so-called Fordist
label: Paragraph

text: theory of industrial production. Ford’s thinking promoted the methodical
label: Paragraph

text: process of goods through a workshop and the consignment of tasks to
label: Paragraph

text: individual workers, rather than relying on their initiative, promoting the
label: Paragraph

text: rational analysis of processes to identify efficiencies.
label: Paragraph

text: 10. Automobile Assembly Building, Highland Park, Detroit, USA,
label: Caption

text: 1909. A reinforced concrete-framed factory laid out around the
label: Caption

text: production line for Henry Ford’s famous ‘Model T’ car. It illustrated
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Concrete came to stand for Fordist industrial production in Detroit,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: socialist collective living. Twenty years after Highland Park, in 1929, the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: architects Moisei Ginzburg and [gnatii Milinis (Figure 11). The Russian
label: Paragraph

text: Revolution of 1917 had overturned the autocratic regime of the Tsar and—
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: worker’s councils called Soviets. By the time that the Narkomfin was
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Marxist lines.

text: 11, Narkomfin Communal House, Moscow, Russia, 1929. A radical
label: Caption

text: experiment in communist social engineering: a ‘social condenser’
label: Title

text: housing bureaucrats of the Ministry of Finance, including twenty-four
label: Paragraph

text: collectivized flats whose residents ate, relaxed, and socialized together,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Commissioned as a prototype, the Narkomfin was a radical exercise in
label: Paragraph

text: social engineering. Designed for bureaucrats of the Ministry of Finance, it
label: Paragraph

text: replaced two bourgeois villas on Moscow’s Garden Ring Road. Dressed in
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture’s Gropius-inspired ‘teenage uniform’, it boasted white
label: Paragraph

text: painted concrete walls with flat roofs and ribbon windows, seemingly
label: Paragraph

text: hovering above the ground on columns. It was most striking for its radical
label: Paragraph

text: organization. Devised by a state research agency headed by Ginzburg, it
label: Paragraph

text: maximized shared facilities, like those for cooking and dining, adding a
label: Paragraph

text: library, gymnasium, and laundry, plus a créche with professional childcare
label: Paragraph

text: so women could play a fuller role in society. The flats were grouped into a
label: Paragraph

text: single slab, connected with a bridge to another block containing most of the
label: Paragraph

text: communal spaces, while a laundry and créche stood as separate buildings in
label: Paragraph

text: the garden. The aim was to socialize private aspects of domestic life into
label: Paragraph

text: the public sphere.
label: Paragraph

text: Different flat types were included. Two so-called ‘transitional’ flats weren’t
label: Paragraph

text: dependent on communal facilities. However, twenty-four ‘collectivized’
label: Paragraph

text: units were provided for individuals or couples: compact double-height
label: Paragraph

text: volumes, accommodating only sleeping, showers, and toilets. These had no
label: Paragraph

text: kitchens, and living space was minimal, because residents were expected to
label: Paragraph

text: spend most of their home lives as part of the collective—eating, relaxing,
label: Paragraph

text: and exercising together—sharing ideals and daily practicalities.
label: Paragraph

text: The Narkomfin was never the fully communal society its champions
label: Paragraph

text: envisaged because of the multiple flat types. Indeed, a rooftop penthouse
label: Paragraph

text: was added at a late stage for the minister of finance, separate from the
label: Paragraph

text: collective, and Ginzburg added an enlarged version of the ‘transitional’ unit
label: Paragraph

text: for himself. Moreover, the prototype was barely repeated because Soviet
label: Paragraph

text: communism changed around it. The Narkomfin was celebrated in 1928, but
label: Paragraph

text: Stalinist authorities declared by 1930 that workers preferred conventional
label: Paragraph

text: domestic arrangements, and Ginzburg was required to disown the building
label: Paragraph

text: as an elitist experiment.
label: Paragraph

text: Together, the Narkomfin and Highland Park show how concrete structures
label: Paragraph

text: came to stand for radically opposing ideas of communism and high
label: Paragraph

text: capitalism in the 20th century. They indicate how concrete—at once liquid
label: Paragraph

text: and solid, formless and formed, natural and human-made—became
label: Paragraph

text: associated with divergent attempts to rethink social order and mechanized
label: Paragraph

text: production. They illustrate how the material was not only contradictory in
label: Paragraph

text: itself, but also had divergent ideas about modernity projected onto it.

label: Title

text: The second superhero of modern architecture I’1l introduce was an intense
label: Paragraph

text: French-speaking Swiss man, Charles-Edouard Jeanneret (1887-1965), who
label: Paragraph

text: wrestled with reinforced concrete as a way of wrestling with what
label: Paragraph

text: architecture could do. He moved to Paris in 1917, after art school, and after
label: Paragraph

text: designing a series of almost-modem houses in his hometown of La Chaux-
label: Paragraph

text: de-Fonds. He painted together with the artist Amédée Ozenfant (whose
label: Paragraph

text: family knew the Hennebiques) and they labelled themselves ‘purists’,
label: Paragraph

text: publishing an art manifesto together, After Cubism, 1918, demanding a
label: Paragraph

text: reclamation of order after the fragmentation of Cubism. They depicted
label: Paragraph

text: everyday objects in flattened compositions, borrowing projection
label: Paragraph

text: techniques from engineering drawing. Jeanneret reinvented his architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and himself, becoming ‘Le Corbusier’—combining a historic family
label: Paragraph

text: surname, Le Corbesier, with the French word for raven, corbeau, a haughty
label: Paragraph

text: bird he thought he looked like—believing that, by doing so, he was
label: Paragraph

text: identifying himself with the deep origins of human civilization.
label: Paragraph

text: Flora Samuel has observed that concrete was, for Corbusier, a natural
label: Paragraph

text: material, and he imagined being under concrete as being cocooned within
label: Paragraph

text: the earth. He was as contradictory as the material itself. He took himself
label: Paragraph

text: very seriously but was mercilessly self-mocking. He celebrated the
label: Paragraph

text: straightforwardness of technology and the ‘engineer’s aesthetic’, but
label: Paragraph

text: designed with a painter’s instinct for form, colour, and proportion. He
label: Paragraph

text: rejected symmetry but employed it selectively. He praised the machine age
label: Paragraph

text: while believing—as William Curtis put it—in ‘an equilibrium between the
label: Paragraph

text: mechanized and the rustic, the secular and the sacred [and] the local and the
label: Paragraph

text: universal’. His thinking blended practicality with a yearning for primeval
label: Paragraph

text: mysticism. He identified modernity as the source of The New Spirit (the
label: Paragraph

text: name of a magazine he co-published with Ozenfant in the 1920s), seeking
label: Paragraph

text: inspiration from history, understanding pure geometries—the cylinder,
label: Paragraph

text: pyramid, cube, block, and sphere—as the true inheritance of the classical
label: Paragraph

text: past, claiming architecture to be ‘the magnificent, knowledgeable and
label: Paragraph

text: correct play of volumes under light’. Corbusier employed a substantial
label: Paragraph

text: studio but was quick to claim his own genius, believing himself—in the
label: Paragraph

text: terms of Friedrich Nietzsche, the philosopher of destiny—one of a select
label: Paragraph

text: group of ‘world historical individuals’. When devotees copied his
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, he reinvented it. Condemned as a villain for his ideas on urban
label: Paragraph

text: planning, Corbusier nevertheless remains a hero for his buildings, which
label: Paragraph

text: significantly extended architecture’s organizational and expressive
label: Paragraph

text: potential.
label: Paragraph

text: The late 1910s and 1920s saw major technological and cultural
label: Paragraph

text: achievements in Europe and America. These followed a rush for technical
label: Paragraph

text: advantage during the First World War, and responded to its horrors.
label: Paragraph

text: Movements in modern art were matched by modern novelists ‘making it
label: Paragraph

text: new’ like Virginia Woolf, James Joyce, and Marcel Proust. Meanwhile,
label: Paragraph

text: cultural theorists like Walter Benjamin and Siegfried Kracauer tried to
label: Paragraph

text: account for the experiences of modern life, especially the alienation they
label: Paragraph

text: believed it produced. Increasing dissemination of still photography
label: Paragraph

text: paralleled a cinema boom which made moving, and then talking, pictures
label: Paragraph

text: widespread. Radio and gramophones brought news and entertainment into
label: Paragraph

text: prosperous homes. Glamorous ocean liners made international shipping
label: Paragraph

text: faster and more luxurious. Motor cars were an increasingly regular sight.
label: Paragraph

text: Air travel became possible for the rich, and daring pioneer aviators became
label: Paragraph

text: newsworthy. Medical innovations like penicillin and insulin seemed poised
label: Paragraph

text: to transform public health, which became a prominent preoccupation. And
label: Paragraph

text: the emergence of jazz and swing was matched with waltz, polka, and
label: Paragraph

text: twostep. As the 1920s drew to a close, a recognizable cultural and
label: Paragraph

text: technological ‘avant garde’ was emerging, and it started forming public
label: Paragraph

text: opinion.
label: Paragraph

text: A house begun in 1928 and finished in 1931—Villa Savoye, at Poissy,
label: Paragraph

text: outside Paris—is sometimes portrayed as the definitive architectural
label: Paragraph

text: reflection of the jazz age. The architecture of planes lent itself more
label: Paragraph

text: logically to reinforced concrete than steel for Corbusier, and Villa Savoye
label: Paragraph

text: fulfilled a series of his early experiments. Corbusier’s planar compositions
label: Paragraph

text: related to, but differed from, Wright’s and Rietveld’s, in which walls and
label: Paragraph

text: furniture elements ‘pinwheeled’ outwards from a centre, being contained
label: Paragraph

text: instead within boxes. Villa Savoye extended ideas that were first explored
label: Paragraph

text: in an unbuilt house project—Maison Citrohan, 1922, intended for mass
label: Paragraph

text: production like France’s Citréen car, famously promoted as a ‘machine for
label: Paragraph

text: living’—which were then tested in a sequence of houses around Paris, co-
label: Paragraph

text: designed with Corbusier’s cousin Pierre Jeanneret, including: Maison La
label: Caption

text: Roche-Jeanneret, 1924; Maison Cook, 1926; and Villa Stein-de-Monzie,
label: Caption

text: 1928. Villa Savoye was never a good house to live in, frequently cold and
label: Paragraph

text: damp, and it became a ruin after the Savoye family were deported by the
label: Paragraph

text: Nazis in the Second World War. But its image proved long-lasting enough
label: Paragraph

text: that the French government eventually restored it as a cultural treasure.
label: Paragraph

text: Villa Savoye was constructed in concrete frame infilled with blockwork and
label: Paragraph

text: tile, rendered-over and painted white to give the impression of continuous
label: Paragraph

text: concrete planes (Figure 12). Perched on a ridge in a rolling landscape, it’s
label: Paragraph

text: almost square in plan. First-floor living spaces apparently float above the
label: Paragraph

text: ground on a column grid. Recessed beneath, painted dark green to
label: Paragraph

text: emphasize the floating illusion, the ground floor is shaped around the
label: Paragraph

text: tuming circle of a car—that definitive mass-produced symbol of modern
label: Paragraph

text: life. The column grid is almost, but not quite, regular, with a few columns
label: Paragraph

text: artfully shifted off-grid. The grid thus establishes the house’s rational
label: Paragraph

text: credentials, while its rogue columns simultaneously highlight its artfulness.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The second flight of the ramp led to a roof terrace with a highly modelled
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: There are as many interpretations of Villa Savoye as there are numerous
label: Paragraph

text: academic texts about it. It’s been seen as a fulfilment of two formulas for
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture promoted by Corbusier in the 1920s. The first was the
label: Paragraph

text: cinematic idea of ‘architectural promenade’—extending Schmarsow’s
label: Paragraph

text: theories, and discussed in Corbusier’s 1923 book Towards a New
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture—claiming that space is primarily appreciated by moving
label: Paragraph

text: around it. In this context, Villa Savoye’s ramp can be understood as a
label: Paragraph

text: promenade device, unfolding the house’s sequence of rooms. The second
label: Paragraph

text: formula it exemplified was Corbusier’s ‘five points for a new architecture’,
label: Paragraph

text: published in The New Spirit in 1926, attempting a scientific categorization
label: Paragraph

text: of modern architecture’s ‘teenage uniform’ into key elements:
label: Paragraph

text: 1. The replacement of loadbearing masonry walls with a grid of reinforced concrete columns,
label: Caption

text: called piloti;
label: Paragraph

text: 2. The free plan, imagining walls as planes in space liberated from their structural function by
label: Caption

text: interior columns;
label: Paragraph

text: 3. The free facade, recognizing that structural columns liberate elevations from bearing loads;
label: Caption

text: 4. The horizontal window, made possible because non-loadbearing elevations allow openings to be
label: Caption

text: placed differently, supposedly lighting rooms evenly, and;
label: Paragraph

text: 5. Roof gardens, compensating for the green space that a building consumes by replacing it on top
label: Caption

text: as a flat roof.
label: Paragraph

text: Villa Savoye exemplified these points. Perched on piloti, with its roof
label: Paragraph

text: garden highlighted by the sculptural windbreak, its columns were
label: Paragraph

text: conspicuously detached from the walls, illustrating the ‘free plan’. And the
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal window strips emphasized how the walls above didn’t transfer
label: Paragraph

text: their loads to the ground but instead to the columns behind. Although
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier later moved away from these ‘five points’, architecture students
label: Paragraph

text: love a formula, and they’ve remained doggedly persistent.
label: Paragraph

text: Villa Savoye has also been read as a ship, a machine, an Arcadian
label: Paragraph

text: landscape, a macho fantasy, and a bourgeois villa in socialist clothing.
label: Paragraph

text: Others have seen it as a reinvention of a Greek temple: sat on a hilltop, with
label: Paragraph

text: its facade divided—tike temple fronts—into three parts, with elevations
label: Paragraph

text: judiciously proportioned (according to a system Corbusier devised called
label: Paragraph

text: ‘regulating lines’). Like the ritual route to a temple’s sanctuary, climbing
label: Paragraph

text: Villa Savoye’s ramp has been seen as symbolizing an ascent to the gods.
label: Paragraph

text: The critic Sigfried Giedion emphasized that the house coincided with the
label: Paragraph

text: increasing acceptance of Albert Einstein’s theories of relativity—published
label: Paragraph

text: in 1905 and 1916—reimagining space and time as a single interdependent
label: Paragraph

text: continuum. Giedion linked architectural promenade—imagining buildings
label: Paragraph

text: as experiences unfolded in space and time—to relativity, as an illustration
label: Paragraph

text: of the idea of time being inseparable from space. Later historians, interested
label: Paragraph

text: in theories of the body, emphasized instead the cleanliness demanded by the
label: Paragraph

text: house, and its fixation with the naked figure.
label: Paragraph

text: Commentaries on Villa Savoye were conducted in building as well as
label: Paragraph

text: writing. Although Irish designer Eileen Gray’s house E.1027 was finished
label: Paragraph

text: before Villa Savoye, in 1929, she knew it from prepublished drawings.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Built for their use together, perched above the sea at Roquebrune-Cap-
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The International Style
label: Title

text: By the 1930s, enough buildings had been built with enough in common for
label: Paragraph

text: critics to claim a distinctive modern architecture. Two influential books set
label: Paragraph

text: out genealogies, or studies in family resemblance.
label: Paragraph

text: The International Style, published in 1932, catalogued an exhibition at New
label: Paragraph

text: York’s Museum of Modern Art (MoMA), presenting photographs and plans
label: Paragraph

text: of buildings that more or less complied with Corbusier’s ‘five points’. His
label: Paragraph

text: work was shown alongside that of Mies and Gropius, their reputations only
label: Paragraph

text: emerging at that time. Other buildings given comparable emphasis were
label: Paragraph

text: designed by architects who became less effective self-publicists and have
label: Paragraph

text: been largely forgotten including: Uno Ahren, Ludwig Kysela, J.J.P Oud,
label: Caption

text: Lily Reich (the only woman), Nicolaiev & Fissenko, and Manora Yamada.
label: Paragraph

text: The show emerged from European road trips taken by MoMA’s director
label: Paragraph

text: Alfred Barr with critic Henry-Russell Hitchcock and a history graduate,
label: Paragraph

text: Philip Johnson (who later retrained as an architect and collaborated with
label: Paragraph

text: Mies on the Seagram offices).
label: Paragraph

text: Barr, Hitchcock, and Johnson argued that the buildings they depicted shared
label: Paragraph

text: an aesthetic resemblance. They presented them as progenitors of a
label: Paragraph

text: distinctive architectural style. Style in architecture was effectively a 19th-
label: Paragraph

text: century idea, popularized by German writer Alois Riegel. It described a
label: Paragraph

text: predominantly visual approach to buildings where certain shapes and forms
label: Paragraph

text: characterize the architectures of particular historical epochs—no matter that
label: Paragraph

text: individual buildings get produced in different places at different times by
label: Paragraph

text: different people under different social, cultural, and political conditions.
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Classical’, ‘Baroque’, ‘Gothic’, and ‘Gothic Revival’ styles have been
label: Paragraph

text: defined, for example, spanning extensive time periods and geographies.
label: Paragraph

text: Styles are thus ideas projected back onto architectures of the past by
label: Paragraph

text: historians. The International Style claimed modern architecture as a style
label: Paragraph

text: like other styles, characterizing it as functional, following three principles:
label: Paragraph

text: [an] emphasis on volume—space enclosed by thin planes or surfaces as opposed to the
label: Paragraph

text: suggestion of mass and solidity; regularity as opposed to symmetry or other kinds of obvious
label: Paragraph

text: balance; and, lastly, dependence on the intrinsic elegance of materials, technical perfection
label: Paragraph

text: and fine proportions, as opposed to applied ornament.
label: Paragraph

text: The idea that modern architecture could be depicted as a style was disputed
label: Paragraph

text: by establishment architects of the time, who subscribed to older styles,
label: Paragraph

text: offended by what they saw as modernism’s blunt crudeness. Modern
label: Paragraph

text: architects, on the other hand, disliked the show’s emphasis on aesthetics
label: Paragraph

text: over function, thinking it over-simplified their work, believing instead that
label: Paragraph

text: their designs demonstrated timeless technical and social principles. Indeed,
label: Paragraph

text: they suspected that characterizing modern architecture as a style sowed the
label: Paragraph

text: seeds of its destruction, making it transitory, opening up space for
label: Paragraph

text: something else to follow.
label: Paragraph

text: Art historian Nikolaus Pevsner arrived in Britain from Germany shortly
label: Paragraph

text: after MoMA’s show, sacked from Gottingen University by the Nazis for his
label: Paragraph

text: Jewishness. He brought enthusiasm for modernism—which he understood
label: Paragraph

text: as the true architectural expression of the age—and a desire to promote it to
label: Paragraph

text: a sceptical British public, reflected in his book The Pioneers of Modern
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

text: and John Ruskin—who examined how mechanized industry was changing
label: Paragraph

text: society, and argued that art and architecture should change in response.
label: Paragraph

text: Pevsner identified provisional responses to this problem in the flowing,
label: Paragraph

text: naturally inspired shapes of Art Nouveau and the so-called Arts and Crafts
label: Paragraph

text: movement led by Morris—which sought to return to the handmade crafts of
label: Paragraph

text: preindustrial architecture—and also in 19th-century engineering structures
label: Paragraph

text: like railway sheds. But these were only transitional responses to
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: or failing to understand the full implications of industrial production. Only
label: Paragraph

text: in the work of Gropius and the Bauhaus, he argued—in buildings like those
label: Paragraph

text: collected in The International Style—had the proper architectural
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: These influential texts gave modern architecture momentum in the 1930s
label: Paragraph

text: and 1940s. But they also over-simplified it. They admitted modernism into
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Cities of tomorrow
label: Title

text: Modernity transformed Western cities through industrialization in the 19th
label: Paragraph

text: and early 20th centuries. Populations shifted from agricultural labour to
label: Paragraph

text: industrial production, from dispersal on the land to concentrations around
label: Paragraph

text: new work in offices and factories. Established cities grew substantially, and
label: Paragraph

text: more were built. Much of this growth was unplanned and opportunistic,
label: Paragraph

text: driven by market forces and short-term necessities. Early industrial cities
label: Paragraph

text: were frequently characterized by cramped living conditions, polluted air
label: Paragraph

text: and water, little sanitation, bad health and hygiene, poor sunlight, and a lack
label: Paragraph

text: of green space. Infrastructures were often provided only in retrospect—
label: Paragraph

text: railways, for example, retrofitted to shift goods and commuters, or paved
label: Paragraph

text: roads to accommodate motor traffic—choking urban life and public space.
label: Paragraph

text: City ‘slums’ became widely condemned, often by well-to-do philanthropists
label: Paragraph

text: who associated bad conditions with moral depravity among the poor.
label: Paragraph

text: Improvements were demanded, and the gradual provision of sewers, water,
label: Paragraph

text: gas, and electricity infrastructures transformed city life. But their
label: Paragraph

text: installation was often piecemeal and disruptive, highlighting a lack of
label: Paragraph

text: organized planning for urban growth.
label: Paragraph

text: Around the turn of the 20th century, various ideal city layouts were
label: Paragraph

text: proposed, speculating about how cities could be planned for the machine
label: Paragraph

text: age, how urban space might be different if organized properly around the
label: Paragraph

text: new infrastructures. They coincided with the emergence of town planning
label: Paragraph

text: as a profession, out of a long tradition of planned cities, spanning from the
label: Paragraph

text: symbolic grid of historic Beijing, and the axes of Ancient Rome, to the
label: Paragraph

text: crescents and circuses of Georgian Bath; from the boulevards cut through
label: Paragraph

text: 19th-century Paris by Baron Haussmann to the gridirons of Manhattan and
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago.
label: Paragraph

text: British inventor Ebeneezer Howard published a proposal for ‘Garden Cities
label: Paragraph

text: of To-morrow’ in 1898, inspired by ideas about social reform and the
label: Paragraph

text: authenticity of nature. He envisaged circular-plan ‘slumless, smokeless’
label: Paragraph

text: towns of 32,000 people dispersed across an agricultural landscape,
label: Paragraph

text: supposedly combining the best of town and country. Industry, retail, and
label: Paragraph

text: residential areas would be separated into concentric zones to promote
label: Paragraph

text: public health. No Garden Cities were built following Howard’s formula, but
label: Paragraph

text: some ‘garden villages’ and ‘garden suburbs’ were constructed in the 1910s,
label: Paragraph

text: comprising picturesque cottages with gardens, designed by Arts and Crafts
label: Paragraph

text: architects. Their romantic imagery was later exploited by property
label: Paragraph

text: developers in the 1920s and ’30s who mass produced cheap copies as
label: Paragraph

text: suburban sprawl. Howard’s Garden City prompted Frank Lloyd Wright’s
label: Paragraph

text: speculative Broadacre City proposal for the USA, 1932: a car-oriented, low-
label: Paragraph

text: density vision giving each family an acre of land for a house and
label: Paragraph

text: smallholding, revisited during the Cold War for its potential to disperse the
label: Paragraph

text: American population against the threat of nuclear attack.
label: Paragraph

text: Notoriously, Corbusier’s studio also produced a sequence of speculative
label: Paragraph

text: ideal city designs. His (unbuilt) Ville Contemporaine, or Contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: City, 1922, fused the philanthropic ambitions of the Garden City with the
label: Paragraph

text: formal axes of Haussman’s Paris and the grids of Manhattan and Chicago.
label: Paragraph

text: Ville Contemporaine proposed a new form of community. Its key functions
label: Paragraph

text: were to be concentrated into cruciform towers built from mass-produced
label: Paragraph

text: parts. A grid of highways would enclose these towers, freeing up land in
label: Paragraph

text: between for parks, celebrating the health-giving potential of sunlight and
label: Paragraph

text: fresh air in contrast to 19th-century density and pollution, echoing Ruskin’s
label: Paragraph

text: ideas about the moral importance of nature. Traffic was to be separated
label: Paragraph

text: from pedestrians, with urban motorways divided from pedestrian routes
label: Paragraph

text: through green space. The centre of Ville Contemporaine would comprise a
label: Paragraph

text: seven-level road-rail interchange topped with an airport. Its innovations
label: Paragraph

text: were vertical rather than horizontal, its section orchestrated from skyscraper
label: Paragraph

text: to surface to subway train, experienced by elevator, escalator, windscreen,
label: Paragraph

text: and aeroplane window.
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier and Pierre Jeanneret collaged Ville Contemporaine into Paris,
label: Paragraph

text: crudely, in their ‘Plan Voisin’ (also unbuilt), 1925, a proposal to replace
label: Paragraph

text: certain so-called ‘insalubrious’ districts (Figure 14). Presented in striking
label: Paragraph

text: drawings and models—sponsored by Avions Voisin, makers of luxury cars,
label: Paragraph

text: and intended to capture politicians’ and industrialists’ imaginations—the
label: Paragraph

text: proposal was exhibited at Paris’s Exhibition of Decorative Arts in a mock-
label: Paragraph

text: up of a ‘dwelling type’ from one of the city blocks. It indicated once again a
label: Paragraph

text: grid of mass-produced towers which, in an apparent act of social cleansing,
label: Paragraph

text: were reserved for a ‘white-collar’ bureaucratic and cultural elite, with
label: Paragraph

text: labourers and factories nowhere to be seen. Developing Ville
label: Paragraph

text: Contemporaine, Plan Voisin proposed a rational, scientific, secular city
label: Paragraph

text: whose centralized planning would tame uncontrolled market-led spraw]—
label: Paragraph

text: promoting values often associated with socialism and communism. But
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier and Jeanneret saw no contradiction in claiming the project’s
label: Paragraph

text: urban form and factory-made housing blocks instead as symbols of the new
label: Paragraph

text: capitalist order of Fordist mass production.

text: Ten years later, in 1935, Corbusier updated his urban ideas in the book
label: Paragraph

text: Radiant City. In 1928, he had co-founded a group called the International
label: Paragraph

text: Congress of Modern Architecture (CIAM: Congrés Internationaux
label: Title

text: d’ Architecture Moderne), which included Gropius, Meyer, Mies, and
label: Paragraph

text: Rietveld. The group held its fourth meeting on a liner cruising from
label: Paragraph

text: Marseilles to Athens, where they agreed principles for ‘the functional city’.
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier wrote up these principles as the so-called ‘Athens Charter’ to suit
label: Paragraph

text: his own ends. It repeated familiar tropes: densifying accommodation into
label: Paragraph

text: slabs around green space; liberating the ground from traffic for parkland;
label: Paragraph

text: and separating out uses (like housing from industry and transport). In
label: Paragraph

text: Radiant City, however, Corbusier added an extendable grid plan, organizing
label: Paragraph

text: the city’s functions according to the metaphor of a human body. The
label: Paragraph

text: business and administrative centre would be placed at the top of the plan as
label: Paragraph

text: the ‘head’ of Radiant City. Residential areas below would form the ‘lungs’,
label: Paragraph

text: set out in grid squares separated by major highways, with housing blocks
label: Paragraph

text: enclosing giant courtyards and gardens. The cultural centre comprised the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘heart’, beneath which was heavy industry, the ‘feet’. This time, everyone—
label: Paragraph

text: workers and managers—shared similar housing as part of an egalitarian
label: Paragraph

text: technocratic society supposedly balancing urban and rural, work and family,
label: Paragraph

text: capitalism and centralized planning.
label: Paragraph

text: The closest that Radiant City came to realization was at the new city of
label: Paragraph

text: Chandigarh in India. When India and Pakistan were partitioned after
label: Paragraph

text: independence in 1947, so was the state of Punjab. Its capital, Lahore, was
label: Paragraph

text: allocated to Pakistan, and Indian Punjab decided to build a new capital.
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier was appointed masterplanner after the original American
label: Paragraph

text: architect died in 1951, and his designs for Chandigarh followed Radiant
label: Paragraph

text: City principles. Its Parliament, High Court, and Secretariat buildings (also
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Corbusier) are at the head, with various grid-plan ‘sectors’
label: Paragraph

text: below containing housing, culture, commerce, and industry, separated by
label: Paragraph

text: highways. It may have been counter-intuitive at that time to design a car-
label: Paragraph

text: oriented city for a population then with few cars, and to appoint a Western
label: Paragraph

text: architect for a postcolonial capital, but Chandigarh has now become a
label: Paragraph

text: highly liveable city.
label: Paragraph

text: The ideals of Ville Contemporaine—planning cities around infrastructure
label: Title

text: with access for all to hygiene and green space; concentrating urban life into
label: Paragraph

text: dense blocks; separating uses, and separating pedestrians from traffic; plus
label: Paragraph

text: the underlying conceit that an ideal city could be planned at all—remained
label: Paragraph

text: largely polemical in the early 20th century. Garden City, Radiant City, and
label: Paragraph

text: their counterparts were provocations: against slums, unplanned spraw],
label: Paragraph

text: deprivation, and insanitary conditions; for the potential of modern
label: Paragraph

text: technology, and planned infrastructure, to alleviate urban problems. In
label: Paragraph

text: postwar times, however, after the extensive destruction of European, Soviet,
label: Paragraph

text: and Asian cities, Corbusier’s provocations started to look plausibly
label: Paragraph

text: buildable, inspiring numerous postwar reconstructions. Corbusier never
label: Paragraph

text: took Plan Voisin as seriously in 1925 as certain Western and Soviet planners
label: Paragraph

text: did after 1945. Some of them actually did collage likenesses of Ville
label: Paragraph

text: Contemporaine into the remains of historic cities. And they frequently did it
label: Paragraph

text: too quickly and cheaply. The results were widely vilified. Indeed, disorder,
label: Paragraph

text: density, and the restriction of planning—condemned in the early 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century—became reappraised in the early 21st as symbolizing urban
label: Paragraph

text: spontaneity, vigour, and human freedom.
label: Paragraph

text: Brutal images
label: Title

text: The significant artistic and cultural outpouring following the First World
label: Paragraph

text: War was decisive in the emergence of modern architecture, including the
label: Paragraph

text: early projects of Gray, Rietveld, Mies, and Corbusier. But the aftermath of
label: Paragraph

text: the Second World War was different. Widespread destruction—and stark
label: Paragraph

text: memories of genocide—meant that the project of rebuilding seemed more
label: Paragraph

text: raw in 1945 than it had in 1918. In places most affected, there was less
label: Paragraph

text: desire to rethink, more an impetus simply to put life back together and forge
label: Paragraph

text: a new normal. In urban design, this involved reaching for interwar
label: Paragraph

text: templates that held promise. These included the idea of town planning and,
label: Paragraph

text: sometimes, the formula of Ville Contemporaine. It also involved the
label: Paragraph

text: widespread adoption of modern architecture. The rise of conflict—
label: Paragraph

text: particularly the rise of fascism—emerged, at least partly, out of ordinary
label: Paragraph

text: people’s disaffection with elites. Authorities wanted to highlight that the
label: Paragraph

text: postwar world could be different, that renewed communities could be built
label: Paragraph

text: out of the ashes. And prewar experiments in modern architecture were
label: Paragraph

text: already there, ripe for reconstruction, as readymade symbols of the new.
label: Paragraph

text: Reinforced concrete—open to resculpting, always ambiguous enough to
label: Paragraph

text: have new meanings projected onto it—became an important medium for
label: Paragraph

text: refreshed architectural experiment.
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s architecture caught the imagination of critics once more in the
label: Paragraph

text: postwar years, despite his ambiguous wartime record (which involved
label: Paragraph

text: collaborating with the Nazi-sympathizing regime of Vichy France and also
label: Paragraph

text: being rejected by it). The reinvention of both his work and modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture became symbolized by his studio’s so-called Unité
label: Paragraph

text: d’ Habitation in Marseille—an untranslatable name, something like Unitary
label: Paragraph

text: Living Block—commissioned as a government prototype in late 1945 and
label: Paragraph

text: inaugurated in 1952 (Figure 15).

text: The Marseille Unité was imagined as a fragment of Radiant City: a
label: Paragraph

text: neighbourhood for 1,600 people in one sixteen-storey slab. It largely
label: Paragraph

text: contained flats, which were slotted together in an ingenious interlocking
label: Paragraph

text: section. One floor of each flat ran the full width of the building, permitting
label: Paragraph

text: cross-ventilation in summer, with an additional half-floor opening-up a
label: Paragraph

text: double-height living space. Internal corridors on every third level provided
label: Caption

text: access, supervised by kitchen windows, with parcel lockers for each flat and
label: Paragraph

text: hatches for delivering communally manufactured ice (preceding the
label: Paragraph

text: widespread use of fridges). The flats’ living spaces opened onto balconies
label: Paragraph

text: that doubled as shading devices, named brises soleil. Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: collaborator Charlotte Perriand detailed bespoke fittings including kitchen
label: Caption

text: units and polished timber handles. A glazed ‘street’ on the seventh floor
label: Caption

text: hosted community shops, including a convenience store, newsagent, and
label: Paragraph

text: hairdresser. A rooftop school opened onto a recreation deck containing a
label: Paragraph

text: pool and exercise facilities. A concierge supervised the entrance, and lift
label: Paragraph

text: attendants were proposed.
label: Paragraph

text: While Corbusier primarily imagined the Unité as an idea about community,
label: Paragraph

text: architectural critics focused instead on its appearance, shocked by its rough
label: Paragraph

text: concrete finishes. No attempt was made to hide the grain traced by
label: Paragraph

text: individual boards of the concrete formwork, to reduce the number of so-
label: Paragraph

text: called ‘blow holes’ pockmarking the surface, to polish-out marks where wet
label: Paragraph

text: concrete slopped around the top of each ‘lift’ of formwork, or to repair
label: Paragraph

text: imperfections. Corbusier argued these decisions were economic—
label: Paragraph

text: disingenuously, given that he was allowed to exceed standard state budgets
label: Paragraph

text: —and reflected human characteristics:
label: Title

text: The defects shout at one from all parts of the structure! Luckily, we have no money! ...
label: Paragraph

text: Exposed concrete shows ... incidents of the shuttering, the joints of the planks, the fibres and
label: Paragraph

text: knots of the wood. [In] men and women do you not see the wrinkles and birthmarks, the
label: Paragraph

text: crooked noses ... ?
label: Paragraph

text: The commission was a sop to Corbusier when the French government was
label: Paragraph

text: awarding big projects, including the rebuilding of war-damaged towns like
label: Paragraph

text: St Dié and Le Havre, to other architects, The latter went to Auguste Perret,
label: Paragraph

text: for whom Corbusier had worked in the 1920s and who sought to refine
label: Paragraph

text: concrete surfaces as ‘poured stone’ in the tradition of Hennebique. The
label: Paragraph

text: Unité rejected Perret’s perfectionist values, and Corbusier instead revelled
label: Paragraph

text: deliberately in crude, gloopy concrete—named béton brut in French—
label: Paragraph

text: claiming he was elevating economic necessity into a symbol of the age.
label: Paragraph

text: Critics were also exercised by the Marseille Unité’s sculptural imagery.
label: Paragraph

text: Gone were the delicate piloti of modernism’s early ‘uniform’, pumped up
label: Paragraph

text: instead as massive splayed legs. Gone were the sheer white planes with thin
label: Paragraph

text: sills and drips, flattening elevations in an illusion of machine production,
label: Paragraph

text: replaced with deep brises soleil in primary colours. Gone was the curved
label: Paragraph

text: plane of Villa Savoye’s sundeck, superseded by a roofscape of enigmatic
label: Paragraph

text: concrete objects: funnels, a shell vault, blocks, and steps. The Unité
label: Paragraph

text: illustrated a renewed concern for form, texture, and colour, echoing the
label: Paragraph

text: swelling shapes of Corbusier’s latest artworks inspired by full-bodied naked
label: Paragraph

text: figures, and the so-called ‘primitive’ art of folk cultures. Architects who
label: Paragraph

text: subscribed to the ‘teenage uniform’ became troubled by what they saw as
label: Paragraph

text: the Unité’s gratuitous ‘formalism’, and the ambiguity of its shapes.
label: Paragraph

text: Those shapes pursued what we would now call ‘intertextuality’. They
label: Paragraph

text: played games with visual clues, hinting at forms—artistic, natural, and
label: Paragraph

text: industrial—which themselves hinted at other forms. The Unité’s imagery
label: Paragraph

text: shared visual sources with interwar modernism, like factories, trains, and
label: Paragraph

text: boats. But there was also another layer of subtler, stranger visual codes at
label: Paragraph

text: work which were altogether harder to place. These included echoes of
label: Paragraph

text: prehistoric sculptures and paintings—imagined as being timeless and before
label: Paragraph

text: style, and associated with classlessness—acknowledging the war’s
label: Paragraph

text: disruption of traditional hierarchies and cultural codes. They also included
label: Paragraph

text: references to wartime concrete bunkers and bomb shelters, and to Picasso’s
label: Paragraph

text: painting and sculpture (the artist spent a day with Corbusier discussing the
label: Paragraph

text: Marseille drawings). The Unité illustrated the idea that altered images of
label: Paragraph

text: modernity seemed necessary to express a revised postwar understanding of
label: Paragraph

text: society and technology. Following mechanized warfare, incendiary bombs
label: Paragraph

text: —and especially the Nazi Holocaust and atomic bombs dropped on
label: Title

text: Hiroshima and Nagasaki, 1945—technology no longer seemed such an
label: Paragraph

text: innocent emblem of progress. Numerous modern architects with little
label: Paragraph

text: opportunity to build in wartime, or rejected by fascist regimes that favoured
label: Paragraph

text: romanticized nationalistic imagery, had spent time strategizing for postwar
label: Paragraph

text: reconstruction at all scales: from Corbusier’s ideal cities to Jane Drew’s
label: Title

text: designs for ideal kitchens. And, for Corbusier, the Unité’s béton brut, brises
label: Paragraph

text: soleil, sculptural forms, and vivid colours fulfilled the promise of such
label: Paragraph

text: strategies, yielding a revised imagery for postwar modern architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: proposing a kind of technological prehistory.
label: Paragraph

text: Intertextual imagery also characterized the other most striking postwar
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier project: the Chapel of Notre Dame du Haut, Ronchamp, 1949, on
label: Caption

text: a hilltop surveying the Vosges mountains, replacing a chapel destroyed in
label: Paragraph

text: war. Corbusier, with Protestant ancestry and rakish tastes, was an odd
label: Paragraph

text: appointment for the Catholic establishment, but he was championed by
label: Paragraph

text: Dominican monk Father Couturier who edited the magazine Sacred Art.
label: Paragraph

text: The chapel seemed radically new but also strangely familiar (Figure 16). A
label: Paragraph

text: weighty, swelling roof over-sailed the chapel’s massively thick south wall,
label: Paragraph

text: punctured with numerous deep windows of apparently random size and
label: Paragraph

text: placement. It also over-sailed the concave east elevation, containing an
label: Paragraph

text: outdoor altar and pulpit, with an icon of the Virgin Mary skewered on a rod
label: Caption

text: in a window above. Three curved towers, two back-to-back and one at right
label: Caption

text: angles, loomed over the roof, which sloped to a giant spout washing
label: Paragraph

text: rainwater into a pool containing a concrete pyramid and cone. The cave-like
label: Paragraph

text: interior, whose floor inclined with the hillside, was reached through an
label: Paragraph

text: outsize pivoting door enamelled with a bright allegorical mural. The
label: Paragraph

text: placement of key interior elements—altar, cross, pulpit, pews—reflected the
label: Paragraph

text: geometry of the bulging ceiling. And the darkness within was punctured by
label: Paragraph

text: shafts of illumination from the various openings, supplemented by ethereal
label: Paragraph

text: light emanating from a thin strip of perimeter glass where the roof was
label: Paragraph

text: lifted slightly above the walls.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption
