label: Caption

text: The chapel was engineered to achieve the forms Corbusier wanted, rather
label: Paragraph

text: than following the logic of its materials. Its seemingly weighty roof was
label: Paragraph

text: actually constructed like an aeroplane wing from slender struts. The walls
label: Paragraph

text: were not solid concrete, as they first appear, but instead concrete frame
label: Paragraph

text: infilled with rubble from the previous chapel, or reinforcement mesh onto
label: Caption

text: which cement was sprayed, all covered over with white render.
label: Paragraph

text: The chapel pursued Corbusier’s enigmatic ideas about order and balance.
label: Paragraph

text: Charles Jencks likened its shape to ‘a nun’s cowl, a monk’s hood, a ship’s
label: Paragraph

text: prow, praying hands ... [all] suggested ... and denied at the same time’. Its
label: Paragraph

text: towers have been imagined as standing stones, Neolithic funerary
label: Paragraph

text: monuments, and vessels. Its forms have been read in the erotic terms of the
label: Paragraph

text: naked body, as bellies, buttocks and breasts, and its sprayed concrete as
label: Paragraph

text: human skin. The multiple meanings of its shapes echo Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: paintings, made concrete in search of poetic potential for postwar modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. To his champions, the chapel represented a profoundly
label: Paragraph

text: evocative rumination on human spirituality, its strange forms articulating
label: Paragraph

text: enigmatically the ineffable mysteries of existence.
label: Paragraph

text: As with other kinds of intertextuality in film and literature, the more you
label: Paragraph

text: know—in this instance about art, architecture, theology, and philosophy—
label: Paragraph

text: the more the chapel gives back. This is not to say that ‘clever’ readings are
label: Paragraph

text: right and ‘unknowing’ readings are wrong. Rather, it works on the levels of
label: Paragraph

text: both raw experience and academic sophistication, done with sufficient
label: Paragraph

text: ambiguity to keep offering fresh interpretations.
label: Paragraph

text: Like the Unité, the chapel again broke the tentative conventions of modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. British architect James Stirling suggested that it prompted a
label: Paragraph

text: ‘crisis of rationalism’, its striking ‘plastic’ forms requiring committed
label: Paragraph

text: modernists to revisit the principles of their work. Ronchamp and the Unité
label: Paragraph

text: took concrete from a straightforward expression of modernity—replacing
label: Paragraph

text: loadbearing walls with frames and planes—to something altogether more
label: Paragraph

text: complex, simultaneously modern and prehistoric. Both buildings spawned
label: Paragraph

text: imitations, from close copies to comparable intertextual exercises.
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier built five more Unités in France and Germany, but it was the
label: Paragraph

text: Marseille block that became the model for swathes of Cold War housing in
label: Paragraph

text: both the free-market West and communist East. Despite being widely
label: Paragraph

text: copied, it was rarely understood well by its imitators. Raw concrete, which
label: Paragraph

text: fared adequately in Marseille’s hot dry climate, survived less well in
label: Paragraph

text: climates with damaging cycles of freeze and thaw. The Unité’s community
label: Paragraph

text: facilities—shops, recreation roofscape, concierge, and lift attendants—
label: Paragraph

text: rarely figured in the copies, producing housing silos that were often
label: Paragraph

text: isolating, failing to mitigate anti-social behaviour. The Unité model thus
label: Paragraph

text: became condemned as a failure.
label: Paragraph

text: In postwar decades, béton brut, and the intertextual form-making associated
label: Paragraph

text: with it, symbolized a decisive rejection of the terror wrought by fascism. It
label: Paragraph

text: described a new beginning—imagined partly in relation to ancient
label: Paragraph

text: beginnings—which aspired to recombine community, technology, and
label: Paragraph

text: architecture with a renewed sense of purpose. Today, however, that
label: Paragraph

text: aspiration has been largely forgotten. Béton brut got tainted by the
label: Paragraph

text: reputation of failed high-rise housing. And that failure continues to colour
label: Paragraph

text: how people think about concrete architecture, and—indeed—modem

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: form. The term was popularized by Banham (again), but first coined in
label: Paragraph

text: Japan by architect Fumihiko Maki, who was part of the so-called
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: for Brutalism. Simultaneously, Tange was conducting academic research
label: Paragraph

text: with colleagues at the University of Tokyo’s Urban Lab, investigating the
label: Paragraph

text: densification of that city in response to a perceived lack of building sites
label: Paragraph

text: there. Statistical modelling was used to analyse commuting patterns,
label: Paragraph

text: transport, and traffic congestion, testing migration theory in relation to
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: called ‘systems thinking’. Systems thinking understood everything—from
label: Paragraph

text: aeroplanes to traffic flows to human bodies and natural landscapes—as
label: Paragraph

text: complex, interrelated systems that could be measured and analysed

text: mathematically. Motivated by the earliest computers fed with punch cards,
label: Paragraph

text: it prompted its followers to think systematically—like computers—
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: sprawl as problems to be solved. This approach tapped into a renewed
label: Paragraph

text: technological optimism in the late 1950s and early 1960s. Prompted by
label: Paragraph

text: early televisions and fridges installed in prosperous homes, by the Soviets’
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: 2300 BcE. In Ancient Rome, fired clay bricks were first used for
label: Paragraph

text: strengthening the corners of buildings and openings in walls, then for whole
label: Paragraph

text: buildings from the Age of Augustus (63 BCE-14 CE). The use of cement
label: Paragraph

text: paste mortars to bind bricks together has been traced to 500 BcE in Ancient
label: Paragraph

text: Greece, although modern mortars—mixed with Portland Cement—became
label: Paragraph

text: widespread only in mid-19th-century Europe.
label: Paragraph

text: Until the 19th century, brickmaking in northern Europe was largely
label: Paragraph

text: seasonal. Farmers shaped clay bricks in wooden moulds when there was
label: Paragraph

text: little other work in winter. The firing of those bricks, requiring temperatures
label: Paragraph

text: between 900 °C and 1,100 °C, involved as much luck as judgement. Each
label: Paragraph

text: brick’s hardness depended on its proximity to the flames and the heat of the
label: Paragraph

text: fire. The hardest, most burnt, bricks were waterproof, called ‘foundation’,
label: Paragraph

text: ‘cellar’, or ‘arch’ bricks, reflecting where they were used. The least baked
label: Paragraph

text: ‘salmon’ bricks were soft, set aside for internal partitions. And regular
label: Paragraph

text: baked bricks, ‘commons’, were employed for external walls.
label: Paragraph

text: These basic brick types persisted after production was industrialized in the
label: Paragraph

text: mid-19th century. Steam-powered manufacturing, particularly in the USA,
label: Paragraph

text: added so-called ‘wire cut’ bricks—trimmed from clay extruded by
label: Paragraph

text: machines—and sharp-edged ‘dry press’ bricks—made from clay forced into
label: Paragraph

text: moulds at high pressure. The most important industrial innovations,
label: Paragraph

text: however, were in brick firing. Early kilns were made and broken for each
label: Paragraph

text: firing, but the first permanent Hoffman kiln was constructed in Germany in
label: Paragraph

text: 1858 with multiple chambers and air ducts to control temperatures
label: Paragraph

text: accurately. Reliable firing improved the predictability of brickmaking, and
label: Paragraph

text: increased the range of hardnesses available. At the same time, modern
label: Paragraph

text: excavation techniques yielded a greater variety of clays in different colours
label: Paragraph

text: and textures. This extended the possibilities available to architects for
label: Paragraph

text: expressing brick surfaces, supplementing variety in the ‘pointing’ of mortar
label: Paragraph

text: joints (e.g. mortar smeared flush with the bricks, or raked out to create
label: Paragraph

text: shadows, or expressed as broad or fine lines).
label: Paragraph

text: Brick became so important to the advocates of ‘another tradition’ in modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture that their alternative history became more-or-less a collection
label: Paragraph

text: of famous brick buildings from the period of modernity. That history tended
label: Paragraph

text: to start with 19th-century Arts and Crafts architecture in Britain;
label: Paragraph

text: specifically the Red House, Bexleyheath, 1859, designed by Philip Webb
label: Caption

text: for writer, artist, and industrialist William Morris, sometimes promoted as a
label: Paragraph

text: progenitor of the modern free plan. It emphasized Frank Lloyd Wright’s
label: Paragraph

text: brick houses like the Robie House, 1909, and included the ‘expressive’
label: Paragraph

text: Wright-inspired brickwork of Klint and Klint’s Grundtvig Church,
label: Paragraph

text: Copenhagen, Denmark, 1927, and Willem Dudok’s Hilversum Town Hall,
label: Caption

text: the Netherlands, 1931, alongside Haring’s cowshed and barn. Their story
label: Paragraph

text: was that the simplistic visual prescriptions of the International Style
label: Paragraph

text: overtook modern architecture’s original purpose: to rethink architecture for
label: Paragraph

text: the age of modernity and industrial production. They argued that this
label: Paragraph

text: alternative lineage—contrasting Gut Garkau with Corbusier’s almost
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary project for a Radiant Farm—showed how modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture shouldn’t be understood as the refinement of a static set of
label: Paragraph

text: forms towards perfection, as in Mies’s work, but should be understood
label: Paragraph

text: instead as an ongoing negotiation with diverse localities, peoples, and
label: Paragraph

text: cultures. It should illustrate a continuing dialogue with ever-changing shifts
label: Paragraph

text: in modernity, they felt, not be frozen as a static repertoire of forms.
label: Paragraph

text: In Chapters 2 and 3, I showed how technical innovations in iron, steel, and
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced concrete produced new possibilities for organizing architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and new architectural images, and I highlighted architectural theories
label: Paragraph

text: emerging in relation to the new imagery. The role of brick in modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture was different, however. It was a familiar rather than novel
label: Paragraph

text: material, and its inherent organizational logic was already well known. The
label: Paragraph

text: adoption of brick into modern architecture represented instead a challenge
label: Paragraph

text: to the hard-line view of modernity as a rejection of history, understanding
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture differently as a continuation of history.
label: Paragraph

text: The local and the national
label: Title

text: Critics found a definitive example of this moder brick imagery on the
label: Paragraph

text: island of Saéynatsalo in rural Finland, in a civic building completed in 1951
label: Caption

text: for a small community centred on a plywood mill, which incorporated a
label: Paragraph

text: town hall, library, and shops (Figure 21). Its architect, Alvar Aalto, is
label: Paragraph

text: remembered as the leading light of Scandinavian modern design, combining
label: Paragraph

text: warm materials with simple shapes to make objects imagined as available to
label: Paragraph

text: all. Aalto designed mass-produced stools, chairs, light fittings, and
label: Paragraph

text: glassware in this spirit as well as buildings. His work became characterized
label: Paragraph

text: as ‘expressionist’, discussed in terms of ‘organic’ geometries.
label: Paragraph

text: 21. Saynatsalo Town Hall, Finland, 1951. Steps lead from the street to
label: Caption

text: a courtyard surrounded by low roofs, and a council chamber above
label: Paragraph

text: expressed with a distinctive ‘butterfly’ roof. The imagery of the
label: Paragraph

text: complex refers both to modernity and history, to so-called high culture
label: Paragraph

text: and low culture, recalling the everyday spaces of local farmers and (no
label: Paragraph

text: less) the Greco-Roman idea of human civilization. (Architect: Alvar
label: Caption

text: Aalto.)
label: Paragraph

text: Sdayndtsalo Town Hall was located on a hillside in a forest clearing. It
label: Paragraph

text: appeared initially unassuming, arranged around a courtyard with low roofs.
label: Paragraph

text: The council chamber, rising above the low roof ridges, was expressed as a
label: Paragraph

text: tower with a distinctive ‘butterfly’ roof that accentuated its height and
label: Paragraph

text: emphasized its civic role. The courtyard was wrapped with a glazed cloister,
label: Paragraph

text: reached by a grand stair leading up from the street. The buildings were
label: Paragraph

text: constructed from pressed red bricks which Aalto instructed the bricklayers
label: Paragraph

text: to set slightly out-of-line, giving the walls an undulating rustic quality,
label: Paragraph

text: playing shadows across their surface in low northern sunlight. The roof of
label: Paragraph

text: the council chamber, reached by a brick-lined and brick-floored staircase,
label: Paragraph

text: was supported with timber trusses shaped like upturned hands.
label: Paragraph

text: The complex was intense for its diminutive size, accentuated by Aalto-
label: Paragraph

text: designed fixtures including handles, handrails, and light fittings. Doors
label: Caption

text: were understood not just as openings but as thresholds between realms.
label: Paragraph

text: Windows were imagined as frames to the forest. Sequences of spaces were
label: Paragraph

text: conceived as journeys through light and dark, compressing people through
label: Paragraph

text: smaller spaces and releasing them into larger ones. The experience of the
label: Paragraph

text: building was carefully choreographed and its details thoughtfully calibrated.
label: Paragraph

text: Its orderly plan and section were derived from functional needs, and also
label: Paragraph

text: carefully adapted to local culture, climate, and the topography of the site.
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto made plenty of intertextual references. He did this differently to
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier, looking more to architectural traditions and the ancient classical
label: Paragraph

text: past than to industrial forms and artistic shape-making. Saéyndtsalo Town
label: Paragraph

text: Hall’s organization around a courtyard recalled local farmsteads and the
label: Paragraph

text: cloisters of historic monasteries. Sat into a slope, it can be read as both a
label: Paragraph

text: classical temple on a plinth and a fragment of a picturesque Italian hill
label: Caption

text: town. Vertical timber slats fixed to doors and windows hinted at both the
label: Caption

text: fluting of columns in classical architecture and the tree trunks of the
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding forest. The red brick, here, referred more to humble industrial
label: Paragraph

text: buildings than grand public ones, and to long traditions of brickmaking.
label: Paragraph

text: Thus, the building played artful double games. Its imagery combined
label: Paragraph

text: references to both modernity and history, to so-called high culture and low
label: Paragraph

text: culture, recalling the everyday spaces of local farmers and (no less!) the
label: Paragraph

text: Greco-Roman tradition of human civilization. It evoked a northern romance
label: Paragraph

text: about Mediterranean life, alongside an idea of the forest as psychological
label: Paragraph

text: retreat that remains prominent in Finnish culture. Critics understood the
label: Paragraph

text: building as a synthesis of global modernism with local sensibilities,
label: Paragraph

text: claiming it as an image of modern Finnishness and Scandinavianness.
label: Paragraph

text: Identity claims like these relate to a strand of architectural history which
label: Paragraph

text: seeks national characteristics reflected in buildings, trying to isolate, say,
label: Paragraph

text: authentically Finnish, or Australian, or Korean architectures. Such histories
label: Paragraph

text: have usually celebrated premodern buildings—valorizing traditional
label: Paragraph

text: construction techniques that worked local materials in response to local
label: Paragraph

text: climates. They tend to identify indigenous characteristics and understand
label: Paragraph

text: them to be threatened by globalized finance and industry, and by the
label: Paragraph

text: international industrial building materials which have grown to dominate
label: Paragraph

text: construction.
label: Paragraph

text: Political historian Benedict Anderson argued in his book Imagined
label: Paragraph

text: Communities, 1983, that ideas of nation and nationalism were themselves
label: Paragraph

text: products of modernity. Anderson linked the modern importance of the
label: Paragraph

text: nationstate to the overthrow of absolute monarchies in the 18th and 19th
label: Paragraph

text: centuries in the West. He attributed ideas of the nation to the simultaneous
label: Paragraph

text: rise of print media and literacy. He connected them to a loss of shared
label: Paragraph

text: religious values coinciding with the rise of modern science and new
label: Paragraph

text: economic interests at the time of the Industrial Revolution. It was no
label: Paragraph

text: coincidence, Anderson argued, that the creation of republics in the Western
label: Paragraph

text: hemisphere between 1776 and 1838 paralleled the emergence and
label: Paragraph

text: widespread consumption of national languages, distributed by burgeoning
label: Paragraph

text: printing presses.
label: Paragraph

text: This new notion of nation, associated with ideas of patriotism, took root
label: Paragraph

text: rapidly. In the 19th century, the construction of museums telling national
label: Paragraph

text: stories, the first mappings of national territories, and the collection of
label: Paragraph

text: census data, consolidated formations of nation. Emerging stories about
label: Paragraph

text: national identities usually included some groups and excluded others,
label: Paragraph

text: making claims about who belonged and who didn’t. Anderson argued that
label: Paragraph

text: conceptions of nation associated people with others they hadn’t yet met by
label: Paragraph

text: encouraging them to imagine themselves together as a collective. The
label: Paragraph

text: power of the idea became illustrated by people’s willingness to risk their
label: Paragraph

text: lives for it in war.
label: Paragraph

text: Claims about national architectures have always been freighted with
label: Paragraph

text: difficult questions: what—and therefore who—gets included in, and
label: Paragraph

text: excluded from, particular national histories; how does architecture get used
label: Paragraph

text: politically to claim certain ideas of nationhood and reject others? In some
label: Paragraph

text: postcolonial countries, and in minority nations asserting their identity, the
label: Paragraph

text: project of cataloguing and producing national architectures has been seen as
label: Paragraph

text: vital in curating national identity. Examples include the early 20th-century
label: Paragraph

text: buildings of Antoni Gaudi, linked to Catalan identity, or Oscar Niemeyer’s
label: Paragraph

text: projects symbolizing modern Brazil. Bombastic claims to national
label: Paragraph

text: architectures have also been made by fascist regimes, who used buildings to
label: Paragraph

text: aggrandize power and emphasize military might. These included, for
label: Paragraph

text: example, the puffed-up projects of Albert Speer for Nazi Germany,
label: Paragraph

text: associated with that regime’s sinister nationalist rhetoric of ‘blood and soil’.
label: Paragraph

text: The dark shadows cast by Speer’s architecture—and what it stood for—
label: Paragraph

text: illustrate the risks of any claims to national architectures. Yet, among the
label: Paragraph

text: champions of the ‘other tradition’, attempts persisted to claim a role for
label: Paragraph

text: local identities, cultures, and histories in modernity. They hoped to illustrate
label: Paragraph

text: that the emergence of global cultures didn’t necessarily involve the
label: Paragraph

text: rejection of local ones. This thinking crystallized in the 1990s around the
label: Paragraph

text: term ‘critical regionalism’—coined by Liane Lefaivre and Alexander
label: Paragraph

text: Tzonis, and popularized by Kenneth Frampton—which described the idea
label: Paragraph

text: of indigenous modern architectures sensitive to site, culture, history, and
label: Paragraph

text: identity. However, champions of critical regionalism have had to work very
label: Paragraph

text: hard to claim that such architectures—like Saynatsalo Town Hall—are
label: Paragraph

text: somehow more authentic because they respond to a local sense of place
label: Paragraph

text: while simultaneously navigating dangerous associations with bombastic
label: Paragraph

text: nationalisms.
label: Paragraph

text: Monumentality and order: Louis I. Kahn
label: Title

text: The most striking images of modern brickwork were found in the buildings
label: Paragraph

text: of Louis I. Kahn (1901-74; no relation to Albert Kahn), the third superhero
label: Paragraph

text: of modern architecture I’ll introduce. If Mies was modernism’s obsessive
label: Paragraph

text: perfectionist, and Corbusier its establishment iconoclast, then Kahn was its
label: Paragraph

text: zen mystic. Kahn wrote—reminiscent of Taoist philosophy—that a great
label: Paragraph

text: building ‘must begin with the unmeasurable, must go through measurable
label: Paragraph

text: means when it is being designed, and in the end must be unmeasurable’.
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn’s aura of spirituality was captured in aphorisms like this, which
label: Paragraph

text: pervaded his accounts of his buildings and his teaching. Like Team 10’s
label: Paragraph

text: members, Kahn emphasized modern architecture’s insistence on the
label: Paragraph

text: expression of structure, material, and function, while also challenging the
label: Paragraph

text: idea of an International Style as dry and prescriptive. Also like Team 10,
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn sought to reconnect modem architecture with older ideas about
label: Paragraph

text: human culture and social life. But, while Team 10 looked to anthropology
label: Paragraph

text: and ‘structuralist’ ideas for inspiration, seeking timeless patterns in human
label: Paragraph

text: behaviour, Kahn looked to architectural history and to mystical ideas about
label: Paragraph

text: the origins of human imagination. He believed that timeless insights
label: Paragraph

text: remained present in the mysterious flickers of creative intuition, and in the
label: Paragraph

text: traces of ancient civilizations found in historic ruins. ‘What was has always
label: Paragraph

text: been,’ he wrote, ‘what is has always been, and what will be has always
label: Paragraph

text: been’.
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn was born Itze-Leib Schmuilowsky on a Baltic island now called
label: Paragraph

text: Saaremaa, then in Russia but now in Estonia. His family emigrated to
label: Paragraph

text: America in 1906—to Philadelphia—changing their names to suit their
label: Paragraph

text: English-speaking environment. From a poor background, scarred by
label: Paragraph

text: childhood burns, Kahn was reputedly a shy teenager. But his prodigious
label: Paragraph

text: talents for drawing and piano playing became noticed. He trained as an
label: Paragraph

text: architect in his beloved adopted city, at the University of Pennsylvania,
label: Paragraph

text: whose curriculum was inspired by the classicism of Paris’s Ecole des
label: Paragraph

text: Beaux-Arts. Following a year travelling in Europe in 1928, sketching
label: Paragraph

text: ancient sites in Italy, Kahn embraced modem architecture. But it was
label: Paragraph

text: another grand tour—a few months at the American Academy of Rome in
label: Paragraph

text: 1950/1—that apparently transformed his thinking. Kahn had become
label: Paragraph

text: prominent in the US architectural profession by the 1950s: a charismatic
label: Paragraph

text: presence in the T-Square Club for architects in Philadelphia, chair of a
label: Paragraph

text: Federal Public Housing Agency committee, teaching at Yale University. But
label: Caption

text: it was only in his 50s that Kahn became famous, claiming finally to have
label: Paragraph

text: found his architectural identity.
label: Paragraph

text: The building Kahn credited with this self-discovery was superficially
label: Paragraph

text: unremarkable: a bath house for the Trenton Jewish Community Center in
label: Caption

text: Ewing Township, New Jersey, 1959, which became a diminutive prototype
label: Paragraph

text: for subsequent projects (Figure 22). It was designed in collaboration with
label: Paragraph

text: Anne Tyng, whose deep appreciation of geometry had a decisive influence
label: Paragraph

text: —although, like many women of modern architecture, her substantial
label: Paragraph

text: contribution went unrecognized for many years. The plan of the bath house
label: Paragraph

text: formed a cross comprised of five squares. The central square was an
label: Paragraph

text: unroofed courtyard, an ‘unprogrammed?’ space initially containing a shallow
label: Paragraph

text: circular basin. The four surrounding squares were topped with their own
label: Paragraph

text: sloping ‘hipped’ roofs. These roofs, with square holes open to the sky at
label: Paragraph

text: their centres, sat on dumpy square columns containing small spaces. The
label: Paragraph

text: roofs did not quite touch at the comers, and appeared poised slightly above
label: Paragraph

text: the columns.
label: Paragraph

text: 22, Trenton Bath House, Ewing Township, New Jersey, USA, 1959, A
label: Caption

text: simple structure, built from bare blocks with mortar smeared across
label: Paragraph

text: their surface, topped with cheap felt roof tiles. The original circular
label: Paragraph

text: basin at the centre of this ‘unprogrammed’ space was subsequently
label: Paragraph

text: paved over. The Bath House produced an improbably monumental
label: Paragraph

text: effect and became the prototype for a series of ‘archaic’, geometric,
label: Paragraph

text: monumental buildings designed by Louis I. Kahn’s office indebted to
label: Paragraph

text: architectural history. (Architects: Louis I. Kahn, in collaboration with
label: Caption

text: Anne Tyng.)
label: Paragraph

text: The Trenton bath house seemed humble, built from bare concrete blocks (a
label: Paragraph

text: sibling of clay brick), with mortar smeared flush with their surface rather
label: Paragraph

text: than neatly raked out, topped with cheap felt roof tiles. But its effect was
label: Paragraph

text: improbably monumental. What Kahn meant when he said he’d discovered
label: Paragraph

text: himself, Neil Levine remarked, is that he’d found a new way to integrate
label: Paragraph

text: structure and space by reinterpreting architectures of the distant past. The
label: Paragraph

text: roofs were imagined as the poor but noble cousins of ancient domes. For
label: Paragraph

text: architects in the know, they referred to the Pantheon in Rome, 126 cE, with
label: Paragraph

text: its open ‘oculus’ at the centre. The columns recalled the significance of the
label: Paragraph

text: column to architecture’s classical origins. The result, nevertheless, was
label: Paragraph

text: inescapably modern. Vincent Scully later claimed an ‘archaic force’ for
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn’s newly found architecture, arguing that it accepted ‘no preconditions,
label: Paragraph

text: fashions, or habits of design without questioning them profoundly’. The
label: Paragraph

text: bath house, he believed, rethought architecture from first principles. Levine
label: Paragraph

text: reflected on its ‘abject poverty’ and ‘the opposition between the archetypal
label: Paragraph

text: sources of the forms [and] their finish, or lack thereof ... that made the
label: Paragraph

text: structure so provocative’.
label: Paragraph

text: Yale University Art Gallery—also designed with Tyng, 1953—developed
label: Paragraph

text: the approach in a substantial commission. The concrete-framed building
label: Paragraph

text: had a pared-down plan layout. It appeared superficially Mies-ian, its
label: Paragraph

text: external walls expressed straightforwardly as planes of brick and glass.
label: Paragraph

text: Where Mies’s college buildings demonstrated an obsession with lightness,
label: Paragraph

text: however, the Yale gallery revelled in heaviness. It crossed Mies’s
label: Paragraph

text: preference for purity with Corbusier’s massive postwar concrete, done more
label: Paragraph

text: precisely than gloopy béton brut. The gallery’s floor slabs were over a
label: Paragraph

text: metre deep, their ceilings expressed as a striking pattern of triangular
label: Paragraph

text: indentations, or ‘coffers’. These ‘coffered slabs’ made the structure more
label: Paragraph

text: efficient by using less concrete, and they provided space for building
label: Paragraph

text: services: the pipes, cables, ducts, stairs, and toilets needed to make the
label: Paragraph

text: building work. The mass of these ceilings dominated the interiors,
label: Paragraph

text: producing a weighty sense of calm. Their insistent triangular geometry—
label: Paragraph

text: matched with one rectangular and one circular stairwell, punched through
label: Paragraph

text: the floorslabs—tapped the ancient power of primary shapes. The gallery’s
label: Paragraph

text: plan was a geometrical diagram so sophisticated that it came right round
label: Paragraph

text: again to simplicity. To architects, it demonstrated the pure integration of a
label: Paragraph

text: building’s driving geometric idea with optimized structure and servicing.
label: Paragraph

text: The Yale gallery got noticed by the global architectural media. But Kahn’s
label: Paragraph

text: international reputation was consolidated through two laboratory buildings
label: Paragraph

text: completed in 1965: the Medical Research Towers, later Alfred Newton
label: Paragraph

text: Richards Building, on the University of Pennsylvania campus; and the Salk
label: Caption

text: Institute, on the edge of the Pacific Ocean at La Jolla in Torrey Pines,
label: Caption

text: California. The Richards Laboratories, constructed in reinforced concrete
label: Caption

text: and clad in brick, proposed an elegant solution to the containment of all the
label: Paragraph

text: building services needed to make labs work—which became widely copied.
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn’s plans and sections expressed and separated-out ‘servant’ space (the
label: Paragraph

text: pipes, cables, ducts, stairs, and toilets) from ‘served’ space (the laboratories
label: Paragraph

text: themselves, conceived like artists’ studios with panoramic corner
label: Paragraph

text: windows). The concrete floor was again hollow, so pipes and ducts could
label: Paragraph

text: run through it. The structure was expressed on the facgades with a beam that
label: Paragraph

text: stepped up between the main vertical columns and the corner, expressing
label: Paragraph

text: the structural load path in the beam, while serving to enlarge the scientists’
label: Paragraph

text: comer windows. Kahn imagined this as an elegant fusion of lighting and
label: Paragraph

text: structural engineering with architectural expression. The underlying
label: Paragraph

text: diagram of the building, again, was admirably refined.
label: Paragraph

text: These ideas were extended at the Salk Institute, famous for its astonishing
label: Paragraph

text: courtyard—paved starkly in travertine, a stone favoured by the Romans—
label: Paragraph

text: whose smooth surface was interrupted only by a line of water leading the
label: Paragraph

text: eye to the ocean horizon beyond. This courtyard’s radical simplicity
label: Paragraph

text: highlighted shadows cast on the surrounding structures by intense
label: Paragraph

text: Californian sun. Kahn reflected gnomically that ‘the sun never knew how
label: Paragraph

text: great it was until it hit the side of a building’. He felt scientists needed both
label: Paragraph

text: their labs in ‘stainless steel and glass’ and separate studies with ‘the oak
label: Paragraph

text: table and rug’, expressing these rooms of differing qualities clearly in plan
label: Paragraph

text: and section. ‘The room is the place of the mind,’ Kahn ruminated,
label: Paragraph

text: memorably describing plans like those of the Richards Laboratories and
label: Paragraph

text: Salk Institute as ‘a society of rooms’.
label: Paragraph

text: Light and shade in Ahmedabad
label: Title

text: Notions about the plan as a society of rooms, about the integration of space,
label: Paragraph

text: structure, geometry, lighting, and services, about ancient models for
label: Paragraph

text: institutions, and the dignity of monumental architecture, were summarized
label: Paragraph

text: in one of Kahn’s last projects: the Indian Institute of Management in
label: Paragraph

text: Ahmedabad, commissioned in 1962, and completed the year Kahn died,
label: Paragraph

text: 1974 (Figure 23). Kahn collaborated with Indian architect Balkrishna
label: Paragraph

text: Doshi, who perceived in the American’s work a yogic pursuit of ideas about
label: Paragraph

text: the eternal and the soul. Doshi had suggested Kahn’s appointment to the
label: Paragraph

text: Sarabhai family, who’d already commissioned designs from Corbusier in
label: Paragraph

text: Ahmedabad. At Doshi’s encouragement, Kahn committed to brick as a local
label: Paragraph

text: material, working with it as the primary structure rather than as a finish to
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced concrete frames like at Yale and the Richards Labs. It was when
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn began this project that he famously asked a brick what it wanted to
label: Paragraph

text: be, projecting the modern idea about seeking logics inherent in novel
label: Paragraph

text: building materials back onto this traditional material, and pursuing a new
label: Paragraph

text: imagery for it.
label: Paragraph

text: 23. Indian Institute of Management, Ahmedabad, India, 1974, An
label: Caption

text: intense conjunction of structure and space, combining material and
label: Paragraph

text: structural logics, engaging light, shadow, monumentality, and order,
label: Paragraph

text: fusing pure geometries and ancient architectural images through
label: Paragraph

text: creative intuition into an architecture that seemed simultaneously new,
label: Paragraph

text: archaic, and timeless. (Architect: Louis I. Kahn.)
label: Paragraph

text: The group of Institute buildings responded to Ahmedabad’s tropical
label: Paragraph

text: climate, to the ancient origins of universities in the architectural form of the
label: Paragraph

text: monastery, and to the suggestion that learning happens through human
label: Paragraph

text: encounters as much as it does through formal teaching. To this end, staff
label: Paragraph

text: and student dormitories were integrated with the institution; imagined
label: Paragraph

text: themselves as places of learning. Kahn championed the value of encounter,
label: Paragraph

text: describing the complex as ‘a realm of spaces ... connected by ways of
label: Paragraph

text: walking ... high spaces together with low spaces, and various spaces where
label: Paragraph

text: people can ... find the places where they can do what they want to do’.
label: Paragraph

text: A shallow entrance ramp and stair, slowing and dignifying arrival, arrived
label: Paragraph

text: adjacent to the library, envisaged as the symbolic heart of the institute. The
label: Paragraph

text: teaching building was located in a comer of the plan, its shady cloisters
label: Paragraph

text: leading past an (unrealized) open amphitheatre to a proposed dining room.
label: Paragraph

text: Further cloisters, arranged on 45-degree diagonals, led from the tree-shaded
label: Paragraph

text: plaza at the top of the ramp to rows of dormitories. These were triangular
label: Paragraph

text: four-storey houses arranged around so-called tea rooms: cool
label: Paragraph

text: ‘unprogrammed’ places for impromptu conversations. Each house had
label: Paragraph

text: twenty individual rooms with linked ‘servant’ towers containing kitchens
label: Caption

text: and toilets. Further tree-shaded courts were laid out between. The plan was
label: Paragraph

text: highly ordered but the experience of moving through it was rich and
label: Paragraph

text: intense, animated by surprising diagonal glimpses and movement between
label: Paragraph

text: intense sun and deep shade. These sequences echoed Team 10’s thinking
label: Paragraph

text: about maintaining ‘labyrinthine clarity’ in dense, complex buildings, about
label: Paragraph

text: the importance of thresholds in enlivening architectural experiences, and
label: Paragraph

text: exploiting the social potential of ‘in-between’ spaces. Kahn’s sources were
label: Paragraph

text: largely Western: monastic courtyards, the historic quadrangles of Oxford
label: Paragraph

text: and Cambridge universities, and dramatic 18th-century etchings of Roman
label: Paragraph

text: ruins made by Giovanni Battista Piranesi. Nevertheless, as William Curtis
label: Paragraph

text: has remarked, the building became understood in relation to Indian sources:
label: Paragraph

text: to the dense urban fabric of Ahmedabad and Jaisalmer, to the linked open
label: Paragraph

text: spaces of Rajput fortresses, and the spatial sequences of Fatehpur Sikri.
label: Paragraph

text: The complex was concerned with light, shadow, and breeze. Kahn imagined
label: Paragraph

text: that sunlight brought architecture to life, understanding architecture as a
label: Paragraph

text: canvas for the tracking sun. ‘Structure is the maker of light,’ he wrote: ‘a
label: Paragraph

text: column and a column brings light between.’ It was the prevailing wind
label: Paragraph

text: direction, though, that drove the 45-degree geometry and the design of
label: Paragraph

text: cloisters and tea rooms as breeze catchers. Kahn echoed Victor and Aladar
label: Paragraph

text: Olgyay’s 1963 book Design with Climate, subtitled Bioclimatic Approach
label: Paragraph

text: to Architectural Regionalism, which discussed the adaptation of modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture to local climates. The buildings’ various openings were
label: Paragraph

text: understood, like Corbusier’s brises soleil, as shadow makers,
label: Paragraph

text: acknowledging how shade and breeze facilitate sociability, creating places
label: Paragraph

text: for people to stop and talk.
label: Paragraph

text: While Kahn believed that this promotion of social life was central to his
label: Paragraph

text: designs, it was their imagery that primarily attracted the critics’ attention.
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn was reputedly unhappy with the Miesian elevations of the Yale Art
label: Paragraph

text: Gallery, expressed as thin planes of brick and glass. He believed he’d
label: Paragraph

text: brought monumentality to the interiors there but not the fagades. The Indian
label: Paragraph

text: Institute of Management’s elevations represented Kahn’s solution to this
label: Paragraph

text: perceived problem: plain brick surfaces with giant geometric perforations—
label: Paragraph

text: circles, arches, and rectangles. These perforations spanned multiple floors
label: Paragraph

text: with smaller openings behind, recessed in shadow. Where there were
label: Paragraph

text: window frames, these were set deep so they disappeared into darkness.
label: Paragraph

text: Alongside the shading function, this made the brickwork appear
label: Paragraph

text: monumental, recalling Kahn’s favourite Roman ruins. While circles,
label: Paragraph

text: triangles, and rectangles had become established in Kahn’s architectural
label: Paragraph

text: vocabulary by this time, they also recalled the geometries of the 18th-
label: Paragraph

text: century Jantar Mantar observatories in Delhi and Jaipur.
label: Caption

text: The Institute’s giant circular openings were understood as an arch sat on top
label: Paragraph

text: of an inverted arch. The arch represented, to Kahn, what brick wanted to be,
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrating the structural logic of the material: an inherent illustration of
label: Paragraph

text: how structural loads get transmitted to the ground through masonry. But, in
label: Paragraph

text: this earthquake zone, Kahn imagined the circle to be a structural idea just as
label: Paragraph

text: powerful as the arch. Here, the inverted arch comprising the bottom half of
label: Paragraph

text: the circle would occasionally be called upon, in a quake, to bear loads in the
label: Paragraph

text: same way that a conventional arch does in normal conditions. Earthquakes
label: Paragraph

text: also justified Kahn’s inclusion of so-called blind arches (arches infilled with
label: Paragraph

text: brick) to reinforce and animate some of the walls, and characterful concrete
label: Paragraph

text: lintels inserted into the base of certain arches to provide extra strength.
label: Paragraph

text: These lintels were a knowing reference, for architects, to the gateway at the
label: Paragraph

text: Royal Saltworks at Arc-et-Senans, France, 1776, designed by Claude
label: Caption

text: Nicolas Ledoux. They served to highlight the structural nature of the brick
label: Paragraph

text: walls, reinforcing brick’s material logic by highlighting where brick wasn’t
label: Paragraph

text: able to perform as well structurally: in tension, where the base of an arch
label: Paragraph

text: wants to spread outwards as loads push down on it. The concrete lintels
label: Paragraph

text: here were the exception that proved the rule for Kahn, highlighting the
label: Paragraph

text: masonry logic of brickwork.
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn’s geometric openings, like the Institute as a whole, illustrated his
label: Paragraph

text: distinctive idea of modern architecture. They represented an intense
label: Paragraph

text: conjunction of structure and space, combining material and structural
label: Paragraph

text: logics; engaging light, shadow, monumentality, and order; fusing pure
label: Paragraph

text: geometries and ancient architectural images through creative intuition into
label: Paragraph

text: buildings that seemed simultaneously new, archaic, and timeless.
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn’s buildings became respected for their intellectual integrity but were
label: Paragraph

text: less copied than those of Mies or Corbusier. American architect Peter
label: Caption

text: Eisenman later argued that Kahn’s work sowed the seeds of modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture’s destruction. Kahn, he claimed melodramatically, ‘murdered
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture’ through his return to monumentality and historic
label: Title

text: motifs. Whether or not this claim has validity, Kahn’s designs reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: claims to another tradition of modern architecture, in brick, negotiating
label: Paragraph

text: between the forces of global modernity and the particular sites and social
label: Paragraph

text: situations of buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: Refashioning architecture from first principles
label: Title

text: If Kahn’s work illustrated how modern architecture could remain a way of
label: Paragraph

text: thinking rather than a formula, then the Church of St Peter at Klippan,
label: Paragraph

text: Sweden, 1966, illustrated how idiosyncratic such thinking could be. There’s
label: Paragraph

text: a story about its reclusive architect, Sigurd Lewerentz, standing on site
label: Caption

text: holding a handful of nails contemplatively. Asked what he was going to do
label: Paragraph

text: with them, he apparently replied ‘I don’t know yet, but I’m not just going to
label: Paragraph

text: nail two pieces of wood together.’ Every architectural element was
label: Paragraph

text: rethought at St Peter’s, making familiar things strange again. At a time
label: Paragraph

text: when construction and building components were becoming increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: industrialized and mass produced, Lewerentz was on site almost daily,
label: Paragraph

text: inventing bespoke details with the foreman and bricklayers.
label: Paragraph

text: The church seems low on first approach, its horizontal roofline punctured
label: Paragraph

text: only by a chimney. Visitors navigate almost completely around the building
label: Paragraph

text: to find the door, their path enclosed by an ‘L’-shaped wing containing the
label: Paragraph

text: parish hall and offices: a laborious entrance sequence reputedly expressing
label: Paragraph

text: the difficulty of finding God. The interior of the church appears like a dark
label: Paragraph

text: cave (Figure 24). From inside, its windows seem just holes in the walls: an
label: Paragraph

text: illusion achieved by omitting window frames altogether and instead fixing
label: Paragraph

text: glass sheets over the outer face of the wall with bronze clips.
label: Caption

text: 24. Church of St Peter, Klippan, Sweden, 1966. Most aspects of the
label: Caption

text: church’s construction were rethought afresh, although there was little
label: Paragraph

text: attempt to be fashionable. The font is a giant reclaimed sea shell
label: Paragraph

text: continuously dripping into a gutter in the floor. Brick vaulted ceilings
label: Caption

text: were supported by a steel column and beam formed into a ‘T’,
label: Paragraph

text: recalling the symbol of the cross. And windows were formed from
label: Paragraph

text: sheets of glass simply clipped outside openings in the brick walls.
label: Paragraph

text: (Architect: Sigurd Lewerentz.)
label: Caption

text: The empty church echoes to the sound of water dripping continuously from
label: Paragraph

text: the font—a giant sea shell fixed to a metal frame—into a gutter in the floor,
label: Paragraph

text: apparently recalling life’s distant origins in water. Not only were its
label: Paragraph

text: unadomed walls, undulating floors, and vaulted ceilings made from the
label: Paragraph

text: same slim brown brick, so were certain seats, tables, and—notably—the
label: Paragraph

text: altar. This furniture seemingly emitted from the floor, giving the impression
label: Paragraph

text: that the whole church was carved from a giant block of brickwork. The
label: Paragraph

text: brick vaulted ceilings were supported by a steel column and beam formed
label: Paragraph

text: into a “T’—unmistakeably, if not immediately, recalling the symbol of the
label: Paragraph

text: cross. Its square plan rejected the traditional ‘basilica’ church plan (divided
label: Paragraph

text: into nave, aisles, and sanctuary), recalling instead a myth about the earliest
label: Paragraph

text: Christian services as a group of worshippers gathered in an arc around a
label: Paragraph

text: priest.
label: Paragraph

text: Bricks are usually laid in a regular pattern called a ‘bond’. In accepted
label: Paragraph

text: bricklaying practice, if you stand beneath a brick wall and look straight up,
label: Paragraph

text: the vertical edges of the bricks (the ‘perpends’) should line-up.
label: Paragraph

text: Traditionally, thin mortar joints are a sign of fine craft, with exceptionally
label: Paragraph

text: skilled bricklayers able to reduce the normal 10 millimetre joint to as little
label: Paragraph

text: as 3 millimetres. But the brickwork at St Peter’s overturns these
label: Paragraph

text: conventions. Here, bricks swim in a soup of thick mortar—walls are more
label: Paragraph

text: mortar than brick in places—and perpends rarely line up. Lewerentz
label: Paragraph

text: imagined the individual bricks to symbolize individual members of the
label: Paragraph

text: congregation, representing the body of the church, and he imagined them so
label: Paragraph

text: precious that he declared no bricks could be cut. It was this rule which
label: Paragraph

text: produced the unusual bricklaying logic, where mortar expands to fill spaces
label: Paragraph

text: left between uncut bricks. Lewerentz’s strange brickwork thus recalled the
label: Paragraph

text: first Roman concrete, where masonry served as aggregate in cement. It
label: Paragraph

text: appeared almost geological, like a natural formation, becoming what
label: Paragraph

text: Jeremy Till later called ‘the brickiest of bricks and the walliest of walls’.
label: Paragraph

text: Little was normal at St Peter’s. While there was scant attempt to be
label: Paragraph

text: fashionable, most aspects of the church’s construction were thought afresh.
label: Paragraph

text: Ordinary materials and details were reinvented in an attempt to imbue them
label: Paragraph

text: with meaning. Like other buildings claimed for an alternative tradition of
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture in brick, the church didn’t do this by returning to local
label: Paragraph

text: architectures of the past, but instead by attempting to update traditional
label: Paragraph

text: elements in relation to current realities of industrialization and
label: Paragraph

text: globalization. St Peter’s thus stands as a powerfully idiosyncratic
label: Paragraph

text: illustration of the idea of another modern architecture: one imagined as an
label: Paragraph

text: ongoing process of reinvention; retrieving specificity, meaning, and place;
label: Paragraph

text: reclaiming history and monumentality.

text: Deep plans and networks
label: Title

text: Brightly coloured 1950s American cars, dramatically styled with chrome
label: Paragraph

text: tailfins, provided a defining image of mid-20th-century modernity. Their
label: Paragraph

text: imagery seemed to associate modern technology with personal freedom and
label: Paragraph

text: decadence. The future they symbolized consigned the horse and cart—then
label: Paragraph

text: still a regular sight in the US and Europe—to the medieval past. Those
label: Paragraph

text: ridiculous, glorious tailfins were invented by Harley Earl from General
label: Paragraph

text: Motors (GM). And when GM sought an architect for its new 320-acre
label: Paragraph

text: research and design campus at Warren, Michigan, on the suburban fringes
label: Paragraph

text: of Detroit, USA, Earl helped them to choose Eero Saarinen.
label: Paragraph

text: GM’s campus (Figure 25) was built over eight years between 1948 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1956, at an astonishing cost for that time of $60 million. Its modern
label: Paragraph

text: buildings tapped GM’s automotive technology, burnishing the futuristic
label: Paragraph

text: credentials of what was then America’s largest corporation. A central lake
label: Paragraph

text: was completed with artworks by modern sculptors Alexander Calder and
label: Paragraph

text: Antoine Pevsner (no relation to Nikolaus), topped with a 40-metre tall,
label: Paragraph

text: stainless-steel-finished water tower. Most striking was Saarinen’s Styling
label: Paragraph

text: Dome, steel clad like the cars, glinting in the sunlight like it’d landed from
label: Paragraph

text: one of America’s newly popular science-fiction (sci-fi) movies. Earl’s
label: Paragraph

text: aerodynamically styled cars were arranged in a circle under the dome’s
label: Paragraph

text: reflective ceiling, and its visitors must have felt they were standing at the
label: Paragraph

text: epicentre of the future.
label: Paragraph

text: 25. General Motors (GM) research and design campus, Warren,
label: Caption

text: Michigan, USA, 1956. Its buildings tapped GM’s automotive
label: Paragraph

text: technology, burnishing the futuristic credentials of what was then
label: Paragraph

text: America’s largest corporation. A central lake was topped with a 40-
label: Paragraph

text: metre tall, stainless-steel-finished water tower. Prominent in this
label: Caption

text: photograph is the Styling Dome, glinting in the sunlight like it’s landed
label: Paragraph

text: from one of the newly popular science fiction movies. (Architect: Eero
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen.)
label: Paragraph

text: The majority of buildings on GM’s campus reflected modernity less
label: Paragraph

text: sensationally. Echoing Mies’s IIT campus, most comprised low-lying,
label: Paragraph

text: pared-down, steel-framed boxes set in parkland, clad with curtain walls.
label: Caption

text: Those curtain walls were flatter than Mies’s, waterproofed with neoprene
label: Paragraph

text: strips invented for another of Earl’s styling innovations: the wraparound
label: Paragraph

text: windscreen. Less immediately noticeable was the novel servicing of the
label: Paragraph

text: GM buildings. Ceilings—like at the Technical Center Studios, 1953—told
label: Paragraph

text: the story (Figure 26). Set-out on a 5 foot 2 inch grid, their dimensions
label: Paragraph

text: coordinated the placement of every element from partitions and doors to the
label: Paragraph

text: facade glazing. Their regular grids brought together fluorescent tubes,
label: Paragraph

text: electrical outlets, fire sprinklers connected to a network of pipes, and air
label: Paragraph

text: supply and extraction via concealed ducts. Air-conditioning diffusers and
label: Caption

text: sprinkler heads were placed so that partitions could be arranged and
label: Paragraph

text: rearranged along the ceiling’s grid lines. Pipes and ducts ran through the
label: Paragraph

text: steel floor decks, with the finished ceilings hung below them as a separate
label: Paragraph

text: element.
label: Paragraph

text: 26. Ceiling detail, Technical Center Studios, General Motors campus,
label: Caption

text: Warren, Michigan, USA, 1953. The ceiling grid coordinated the
label: Caption

text: placement of every element in the building, from partitions and doors
label: Paragraph

text: to the facade glazing. It contained fluorescent tubes, electrical outlets,
label: Paragraph

text: air supply, and air extract via concealed ducts, and fire sprinklers
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: This ‘suspended ceiling’—designed by Saarinen’s office with GM
label: Paragraph

text: technicians, plus consultants Smith Hinchman & Grylls—indicated a fresh
label: Paragraph

text: organizing logic for moder architecture. Most buildings had previously
label: Paragraph

text: remained relatively narrow in plan—rarely more than 12 metres across—
label: Paragraph

text: because interior spaces had to be lit by the sun and ventilated using opening
label: Paragraph

text: windows. Air-conditioning and fluorescent tubes, however, allowed
label: Paragraph

text: satisfactory lighting and ventilation to be provided artificially rather than
label: Paragraph

text: naturally. Accommodation could thus be placed further from windows,
label: Paragraph

text: enabling buildings to become deeper in plan. This made buildings cheaper,
label: Paragraph

text: because the amount of external wall—the most expensive part—could be
label: Paragraph

text: reduced in relation to the overall floor area. Various office cells at GM, in
label: Caption

text: the 1951 Engineering Group Building for example, had no external
label: Paragraph

text: windows but were instead glazed boxes on internal corridors. The
label: Paragraph

text: suspended ceiling—which since became consolidated as a global standard
label: Paragraph

text: grid, familiar from countless offices, hospitals, and schools—stood for the
label: Paragraph

text: substitution of natural light and air with mechanical provision. Air-
label: Paragraph

text: conditioning and fluorescent light thus became combined to produce a
label: Paragraph

text: deep-plan architectural logic.
label: Paragraph

text: American engineer Willis Haviland Carrier is credited with combining
label: Paragraph

text: existing technologies to produce modern air-conditioning in the 1900s.
label: Paragraph

text: Scottish chemist Joseph Black had worked out, in 1760, that heat gets
label: Paragraph

text: absorbed when liquid evaporates into vapour, and released when vapour
label: Paragraph

text: condenses into liquid, but the consequences were only later exploited. By
label: Paragraph

text: the mid-19th century, American trade in ice—shipped south from northern
label: Paragraph

text: climes for a range of uses from medical treatments to refrigerating ships’
label: Paragraph

text: cargoes—grew so profitable that inventors started experimenting with
label: Paragraph

text: turning water into ice mechanically using chemical refrigerants.
label: Paragraph

text: Simultaneously, experiments were being undertaken in theatres to circulate
label: Paragraph

text: ice- or water-cooled air—or to draw cool air from underground chambers—
label: Paragraph

text: to reduce overheating in summer, although these were mostly ineffective or
label: Paragraph

text: produced very humid environments. Carrier worked out that air temperature
label: Paragraph

text: could be controlled by adjusting moisture levels: drawing air through a
label: Paragraph

text: spray of cooled or heated vapour, supplied by coils filled with hot or cold
label: Paragraph

text: water. He used historical weather records to calibrate temperature and
label: Paragraph

text: moisture levels in order to mitigate excessive humidity. The resulting air-
label: Paragraph

text: conditioning was initially used in factory spaces processing delicate
label: Paragraph

text: materials, like celluloid film and pharmaceutical capsules. The first fully
label: Paragraph

text: air-conditioned building was completed in 1929: the Milam Building in San
label: Paragraph

text: Antonio, Texas, USA, where a network of ducts hung in corridors
label: Caption

text: introduced cooled or warmed air into offices.
label: Paragraph

text: The earliest artificial lighting systems, meanwhile, burned coal gas. Gas
label: Paragraph

text: light infrastructure became widespread in European and American cities
label: Paragraph

text: during the late 19th century. In the 1870s, however, American engineer
label: Paragraph

text: Charles Francis Brush developed one of the first viable systems for electric
label: Paragraph

text: rather than gas light, connecting a steam-powered dynamo to arc lamps
label: Paragraph

text: with copper cables. A major development was the invention and
label: Paragraph

text: improvement of incandescent lightbulbs in the 1890s, in different forms by
label: Paragraph

text: Thomas Edison and Joseph Swan. As power stations and electric supply
label: Caption

text: networks became constructed in cities during the early 20th century (Milan
label: Paragraph

text: was an early adopter), electric lighting overtook gas.
label: Paragraph

text: The precursor of modern fluorescent lighting was developed by American
label: Paragraph

text: engineer D. McFarlan Moore, who invented an electric-powered, gas-filled,
label: Paragraph

text: tube lamp. Different gases were tried over some forty years to produce the
label: Paragraph

text: best illumination. Georges Claude tried neon gas in the 1910s and, although
label: Paragraph

text: the orange light it emitted was unsuitable for lighting rooms, it made
label: Paragraph

text: striking illuminated signs when filled into glass tubes and twisted into
label: Paragraph

text: letters and shapes. Neon thus became a symbol of modernity and
label: Paragraph

text: contributed to the image of International Style buildings. The 1939 New
label: Paragraph

text: York World’s Fair spurred two American companies, General Electric and
label: Paragraph

text: Sylvania, to produce white, low voltage, fluorescent lamps. These proved
label: Paragraph

text: phenomenally successful, shipping large volumes in the US after the
label: Paragraph

text: Second World War. Four-fifths of the power of incandescent bulbs went to
label: Paragraph

text: heat at that time, and only a fifth to light, with bulbs producing around 40
label: Paragraph

text: per cent of the cooling demand in the first air-conditioned buildings. So,
label: Paragraph

text: fluorescent light, producing significantly less heat, became an obvious
label: Paragraph

text: partner for air-conditioning.
label: Paragraph

text: By the 1950s, ‘air-con’ became widespread in America, not just in factories
label: Paragraph

text: but also in theatres, offices, and rail cars, and fluorescent lighting also grew
label: Paragraph

text: more widely employed. GM’s campus illustrated an early example of their
label: Paragraph

text: integration, combined into those highly serviced ceilings which made deep-
label: Paragraph

text: plan buildings conceivable.
label: Paragraph

text: GM’s campus also illustrated the translation of ideas about highly
label: Paragraph

text: supervised, statistically analysed, mass production—like at Ford’s Highland
label: Paragraph

text: Park—from factories into offices. (Indeed, Saarinen’s architect father, Eliel,
label: Paragraph

text: knew Albert Kahn.) Deep-plan floorplates transformed office work and
label: Paragraph

text: workplaces. Single cell offices became highly glazed, and so-called open-
label: Paragraph

text: plan layouts were tested, arranging fields of desks and low partitions across
label: Paragraph

text: whole floors. These ‘office landscapes’ allowed workers to be readily
label: Paragraph

text: overseen, permitting the perpetual reorganization of people and furniture to
label: Paragraph

text: suit changing management dynamics.
label: Paragraph

text: GM’s campus was one of the first out-of-town office parks, and it illustrated
label: Paragraph

text: changing postwar relations between home and work. The lakeside
label: Caption

text: landscape was designed for viewing from a moving car, and managers
label: Paragraph

text: assumed that employees would drive to work. The site was imagined as a
label: Paragraph

text: gated compound on the edge of the city, connected by highway networks to
label: Paragraph

text: workers’ detached suburban houses. Due to employers like GM, Detroit
label: Paragraph

text: became, over subsequent decades, a prime example of the movement of
label: Paragraph

text: office work to out-of-town sites, accompanied by the movement of middle-
label: Paragraph

text: class housing to suburbs, and shopping to roadside strip malls. Such
label: Paragraph

text: changes transformed historic city centres in the US, some of which emptied
label: Paragraph

text: out, leaving dereliction and poverty behind. Thus, GM’s campus illustrates
label: Paragraph

text: broader postwar shifts—found in varying degrees in different Western
label: Paragraph

text: cultures—away from a traditional idea of civic life conducted in the streets
label: Paragraph

text: and squares of the city towards a new preference for the private realms of
label: Paragraph

text: office, car, home, and TV.
label: Paragraph

text: GM’s campus also anticipated the idea of a network society. Its office
label: Paragraph

text: workers were mostly distributed across open-plan offices, their desk layouts
label: Paragraph

text: reflecting the network diagrams of management structures. Complex
label: Paragraph

text: patterns of pipes, ducts, and wires embedded in the ceilings echoed
label: Paragraph

text: complex urban networks of power and water supply. Moreover, the campus
label: Paragraph

text: relied on its adjacent highway network, supplying goods and workers. Not
label: Paragraph

text: long after GM’s campus, Saarinen’s office designed headquarters for IBM
label: Paragraph

text: computers and Bell Telephone along similar lines. It’s no coincidence that
label: Paragraph

text: IBM’s pioneering computing, soon imagined in terms of networked
label: Paragraph

text: computers, was developed under Saarinen’s networked ceilings, echoing
label: Paragraph

text: networked urban infrastructures.
label: Paragraph

text: Historian Reinhold Martin has argued that these projects were connected
label: Paragraph

text: directly into Cold War politics via ‘systems thinking’, which understood
label: Paragraph

text: everything in the world as complex, interconnected, mathematically model-
label: Paragraph

text: able systems. Martin noted the postwar Western alliance of new military
label: Paragraph

text: technologies with commercial industrial expertise—sometimes called the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘military-industrial complex’—linking corporations with states and their
label: Paragraph

text: armies, automotive with aeronautical design, and computing with
label: Paragraph

text: innovations in warfare. Martin argued that the GM campus—alongside
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen’s headquarters for IBM and Bell—stood for the global power of
label: Paragraph

text: this ‘military-industrial complex’. He illustrated the point by referring to the
label: Paragraph

text: opening ceremony for the GM campus in 1956, dubbed ‘the Versailles of
label: Paragraph

text: Technology’ by Life magazine after the famous French royal gardens,
label: Paragraph

text: attended by GM’s executives and their guests including senior US military
label: Paragraph

text: officers and the president of Indonesia, addressed live from the White
label: Paragraph

text: House by US president, Dwight D. Eisenhower. The so-called ‘military-
label: Paragraph

text: industrial complex’, arguably represented by GM (who opened a Defense
label: Paragraph

text: Division in 1950), was criticized because it profited from warfare and thus
label: Paragraph

text: appeared perversely incentivized to promote conflict to sell technology. It
label: Paragraph

text: was also hugely inventive, directly or indirectly spawning technologies for
label: Paragraph

text: space travel, the microprocessor, and the networking of computers into the
label: Paragraph

text: World Wide Web.

text: While the postwar years saw a new deep-plan architectural logic emerge
label: Paragraph

text: from air-conditioning and artificial lighting, it had already become accepted
label: Paragraph

text: that modern buildings should look light and airy. This imagery was helped
label: Paragraph

text: by new glass technology which enabled the fabrication of bigger panes: so-
label: Paragraph

text: called ‘float glass’, formed into continuous sheets by rolling hot liquid glass
label: Paragraph

text: onto molten tin. Glass never produced its own architectural logic like steel
label: Paragraph

text: and reinforced concrete had, despite experiments to design structural glass
label: Paragraph

text: beams and columns. However, float glass did help modern architects
label: Paragraph

text: including Mies and Corbusier to devise an imagery of lightness and
label: Paragraph

text: airiness, and those terms became widespread in accounts of modern
label: Paragraph

text: buildings.

label: Paragraph

text: ‘futurologist’ Richard Buckminster Fuller (1895-1983). Nicknamed
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Bucky’ by fans, he was famous for delivering complex, charismatic
label: Paragraph

text: lectures at manic speed. Born into an aristocratic Massachusetts family on
label: Paragraph

text: America’s East Coast, he became a curious blend of geek and travelling
label: Paragraph

text: salesman, traversing the world with suitcases full of models illustrating his
label: Paragraph

text: latest ideas. Fuller lived his life as a scientific experiment, testing all sorts
label: Paragraph

text: of speculations, philosophies, and diets on himself—often at the expense of
label: Paragraph

text: his long-suffering family—recording the details with astonishing
label: Paragraph

text: comprehensiveness in a diary he named, grandly, the Dymaxion Chronofile.
label: Paragraph

text: Fuller was credited as a pioneer of sustainability, concerned with
label: Paragraph

text: humanity’s lasting impact on the planet, and its mitigation through
label: Paragraph

text: technological invention. He’s been depicted as a proto-Hippie, anticipating
label: Paragraph

text: that 1960s counter-culture through his mystical ideas about destiny,
label: Paragraph

text: ‘synergistic’ understanding between people, and unseen connections
label: Paragraph

text: inherent in ‘Universe’—which he wrote with a capital ‘U’ and without
label: Paragraph

text: ‘the’, to emphasize its all-encompassing unity. Fuller talked about ‘pattern
label: Paragraph

text: integrities’, phenomena evident in Universe waiting to be discovered. His
label: Paragraph

text: example was a knot: people usually think of knots in terms of ropes, or
label: Paragraph

text: nylon as a material, however the knot is none of those things but instead an
label: Paragraph

text: idea that becomes form: a pattern integrity. This thinking underpinned
label: Paragraph

text: Fuller’s idealistic designs, including a three-wheeled car, future-proofed so
label: Paragraph

text: it could later fly, 1933; a moulded copper bathroom, 1936; and a striking
label: Paragraph

text: ‘One-Ocean World’ map, 1943, formulated for global citizens to design
label: Caption

text: connected systems. While Fuller didn’t like architects, they admired his
label: Paragraph

text: designs for prefabricated houses—including the 4D (or Dymaxion) House,
label: Paragraph

text: 1928-9; and Dymaxion Deployment Unit, 1940—plus an improbably
label: Paragraph

text: lightweight structural system he invented called Tensegrity, 1948, and
label: Paragraph

text: super-light ‘geodesic’ domes, 1949.
label: Caption

text: Various modern architects, like Saarinen, were entranced by possibilities for
label: Paragraph

text: factory production, and so-called technology-transfer from the automobile
label: Paragraph

text: industry, fantasizing about mass-producing ‘prefabricated’ houses ready for
label: Paragraph

text: delivery to site. Fuller’s Dymaxion House fulfilled these fantasies. As
label: Paragraph

text: historian Mark Wigley has noted, Fuller became frustrated by the
label: Paragraph

text: wastefulness of houses in relation to the ‘magical efficiency’ of new
label: Paragraph

text: technologies like cars and radios. In response, Fuller argued in 1929 that
label: Paragraph

text: houses should: eliminate domestic work, exploitation, selfishness, and
label: Paragraph

text: centralized control; safeguard against flood, storms, fire, earthquakes,
label: Paragraph

text: hurricanes, and marauders; and save time for education, amusement, and
label: Paragraph

text: advancement. He invented the term Dymaxion—which he applied to
label: Paragraph

text: various inventions—for publicity purposes, emphasizing futuristic-
label: Paragraph

text: sounding words, combining ‘dynamic’ and ‘maximum’ with the scientific

text: Fuller’s proposed Dymaxion House, presented in striking drawings and
label: Paragraph

text: models in 1928-9, was to be factory made and delivered by airship.
label: Paragraph

text: Dramatically, the airship would drop a bomb to form a crater in the ground.
label: Paragraph

text: The house—centred on a mast containing staircase, lift, and electrical and
label: Paragraph

text: mechanical services—would then be lowered into the hole, like planting a
label: Paragraph

text: tree, and concreted-in, with tension wires added to secure it. Driven by solar
label: Paragraph

text: and wind power—also recycling rainwater, and packaging solid waste for
label: Paragraph

text: reprocessing—the house could exist off-grid in remote areas, or indeed in
label: Paragraph

text: cities, ready for immediate inhabitation.
label: Paragraph

text: Fuller’s house anticipated numerous future technologies, several
label: Paragraph

text: commercialized only later in the century, and numerous components were
label: Paragraph

text: thought afresh. Many innovations made novel use of air-conditioning,
label: Paragraph

text: provided to remove smells and dust, and also to pressurize air for other
label: Paragraph

text: uses. The structure was designed as a lightweight aluminium frame set out
label: Paragraph

text: on a triangular grid, infilled with translucent vacuum-sealed panels and
label: Paragraph

text: fitted with springy inflatable floors. Pneumatic silk partitions and doors
label: Caption

text: were accompanied by plug-in vacuum hoses and inflatable fumiture whose
label: Paragraph

text: firmness could be controlled by the users. The ceiling was conceived as a
label: Paragraph

text: continuous surface admitting diffuse light, with vents to control
label: Paragraph

text: temperature. Furniture would be suspended from this ceiling, including
label: Paragraph

text: glass tables on neon-lit cables. Storage would be provided in revolving
label: Paragraph

text: units. Triangular curtains, fitting the structural module, would pull out of
label: Paragraph

text: the floor or drop from the ceiling. A moulded bathroom unit, in the mast,
label: Paragraph

text: would wash people instantly with an atomized spray. A utility space, which
label: Paragraph

text: Fuller dubbed the ‘catch-up-with-life room’, would clean and dry clothes
label: Paragraph

text: within minutes. A ‘go-ahead-with-life room’ would contain a radio,
label: Paragraph

text: television (barely viable technology at the time), maps, globes, revolving
label: Paragraph

text: book shelves, a drawing board, typewriter, and various learning materials.
label: Paragraph

text: Fuller imagined residents of Dymaxion Houses as planetary citizens
label: Paragraph

text: liberated from domestic drudge by technology, freed up to dream and invent
label: Paragraph

text: as active contributors to ‘Spaceship Earth’ (a term he coined later, in 1951).
label: Paragraph

text: Fuller claimed that the Dymaxion House could be produced by an
label: Paragraph

text: automobile company and cost as little as a car. Like the cars and personal
label: Paragraph

text: aeroplanes shown parked beneath it in drawings, he envisaged that it could
label: Paragraph

text: be easily moved. When residents wanted to relocate, they could take their
label: Paragraph

text: house with them. Fuller never saw a Dymaxion House built at full size—
label: Paragraph

text: blaming the entrenched interests of the architectural establishment for
label: Paragraph

text: opposing mass production—but his models inspired diverse imagery in
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, art, fiction, and film, including interiors in sci-fi movies as
label: Paragraph

text: diverse as (the hugely sexist) Barbarella, 1968, and Star Wars, 1977.

text: Life under a dome
label: Title

text: While Fuller never saw a Dymaxion House built, deployable shelters were
label: Paragraph

text: constructed to his designs for US military use during the Cold War. One
label: Paragraph

text: memorable image shows a lightweight dome suspended from a helicopter
label: Caption

text: with a single cable. That dome was part of a twenty-year research project
label: Paragraph

text: conducted with students whom Fuller taught as visiting professor at a
label: Paragraph

text: sequence of universities.
label: Paragraph

text: These ‘geodesic domes’ were highly efficient spheres—or, more usually,
label: Paragraph

text: part-spheres—inspired by bugs’ eyes and spiders’ webs, made from slender
label: Paragraph

text: structural elements arranged in triangles. Developed through a mix of
label: Paragraph

text: complex mathematics and trial and error, they employed the least material
label: Paragraph

text: possible, arranged in the most efficient way, to transmit loads to the ground.
label: Paragraph

text: Geodesic domes seemed impossibly light and strong. An image of the
label: Paragraph

text: second prototype—made by students at Black Mountain College, North
label: Paragraph

text: Carolina in 1949—shows people hanging improbably off a lightweight
label: Paragraph

text: frame (Figure 27).
