label: Paragraph

text: Fuller led the construction of prototype domes at Montreal, Canada, in
label: Paragraph

text: 1951, North Carolina State College, 1952, and the University of Oregon,
label: Caption

text: 1953, before the awarding of a patent in 1954. He had domestic
label: Paragraph

text: applications in mind, making a detailed model of what he called the
label: Paragraph

text: Skybreak House in 1952. This showed a bubble-like alloy dome, lifted on
label: Paragraph

text: stilts, finished with a lightweight transparent insulating plastic skin.
label: Paragraph

text: Fumiture would be arranged on a platform at the base of the dome and only
label: Paragraph

text: the most private functions would be separated out into enclosed boxes.
label: Paragraph

text: Fuller enthused that transparent domes like this would dissolve the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional idea of the house, likening them to living under the sky. Wall and
label: Paragraph

text: roof, here, were to be combined into an almost-invisible layer of high
label: Paragraph

text: performance plastic. While no such plastic was viable at that time, Fuller
label: Paragraph

text: and his student collaborators tested several innovative materials including
label: Paragraph

text: Mylar, receiving free samples from DuPont and other corporations.
label: Paragraph

text: Most of the geodesic domes realized were commissioned by the US
label: Paragraph

text: military. In 1949, Fuller installed a prototype at The Pentagon, Washington,
label: Paragraph

text: DC—headquarters of the US Department of Defense—for use in conflicts
label: Paragraph

text: and disaster-relief. Another dome—a lightweight timber lattice covered in
label: Paragraph

text: chicken wire, with a sprayed-on neoprene rubber skin, built by North
label: Paragraph

text: Carolina State University students—was the one that was test-lifted by a US
label: Paragraph

text: Marines helicopter in 1951. The experiment was deemed a success, and
label: Paragraph

text: lightweight magnesium-framed domes were then commissioned from
label: Paragraph

text: Fuller’s company, Geodesics Inc., for military applications. In 1955, a dome
label: Paragraph

text: made in fibreglass was tested on the roof of the Lincoln Laboratory at MIT,
label: Paragraph

text: Cambridge, Massachusetts, to cover an experimental radar installation,
label: Paragraph

text: proving invisible to the radar, and surviving a hurricane shortly afterwards.
label: Paragraph

text: Wise to a marketing opportunity, Fuller branded this variant the ‘Radome’,
label: Paragraph

text: photographing workers balancing its triangular components on their
label: Paragraph

text: fingertips to illustrate their lightness and strength. When a line of sixty-
label: Paragraph

text: three radar stations was constructed in 1957 at the frozen extremity of the
label: Paragraph

text: Americas to provide early warning of Soviet invasion, from Alaska to
label: Paragraph

text: Baffin Island, they were covered with ‘Bucky Domes’. As Wigley
label: Paragraph

text: remarked, the geodesic dome ‘no longer simply defined just ... domestic
label: Paragraph

text: shelter’, it defined ‘domestic security for an entire continent’.
label: Paragraph

text: Fuller spent a lifetime fascinated by experimental materials, excited by
label: Paragraph

text: futuristic imagery, imagining buildings made for delivery by airship and
label: Paragraph

text: helicopter. He challenged assumptions that architecture should be
label: Paragraph

text: heavyweight, fixed, and expensive. Visiting a building designed by British
label: Paragraph

text: architects Norman and Wendy Foster in 1978, he enquired memorably:
label: Paragraph

text: ‘How much does your building weigh?’ Fuller implied: why shouldn’t
label: Paragraph

text: buildings be cheap and portable? Why shouldn’t they provide technological
label: Paragraph

text: liberations like those offered by cars and televisions? His structures went
label: Paragraph

text: beyond the idea that modern architecture ought simply to look light and airy
label: Paragraph

text: to realizing highly lightweight, almost transparent structures. Indeed, his
label: Paragraph

text: anti-architectural, anti-establishment thinking inspired a diverse group of
label: Paragraph

text: architects, critics, engineers, and ‘drop outs’ in the 1960s and 1970s.
label: Paragraph

text: Bubbles and blimps
label: Title

text: Fuller’s geodesics proposed stripping architecture back to basic human
label: Paragraph

text: shelter. In a 1960 book, Theory and Design in the First Machine Age,
label: Paragraph

text: Banham (again) argued that form never really did follow function in
label: Paragraph

text: ‘International Style’ modernism. Its buildings offered superficial images of
label: Paragraph

text: modernity, he argued, but didn’t tap the full potential of new technologies.
label: Paragraph

text: In the spirit of Fuller, and Mies’s dictum that ‘less is more’, Banham argued
label: Paragraph

text: that mechanical and electrical services—artificial lighting, air-conditioning,
label: Paragraph

text: and power supply—represented the basic components of shelter, ideally
label: Paragraph

text: supplemented only by the most minimal of enclosures.
label: Paragraph

text: A 1965 article by Banham in the magazine Art in America was illustrated
label: Paragraph

text: by artist Francois Dallegret. Together, they proposed ‘The Unhouse’.
label: Paragraph

text: Dallegret’s section depicted a double-skinned, inflated transparent plastic
label: Paragraph

text: bubble on a plinth, showing a group of greyed-out naked Banhams and
label: Caption

text: Dallegrets collaged around a central technological ‘totem-pole’. That totem
label: Paragraph

text: held lamps, a TV screen, stereo speakers, fridge, cooker, and air supply.
label: Paragraph

text: Meanwhile, the architecture became reduced to two thin lines representing
label: Paragraph

text: plastic membranes. The proposal was inspired by technologies then being
label: Paragraph

text: developed for early space exploration, for the artificial environmental
label: Paragraph

text: bubbles of rocket ships and space suits. Banham and Dallegret described
label: Paragraph

text: the Unhouse as a ‘living package’ that would do away with the weighty
label: Paragraph

text: encumbrances of buildings, and their associated social and cultural
label: Paragraph

text: baggage, indicating new ways of life. The naked figures in the drawing
label: Paragraph

text: referred to the 1960s idea of sexual liberation, supposedly occasioned by
label: Paragraph

text: the newly invented female contraceptive pill. They also referred to
label: Paragraph

text: ‘primitive man’ [sic], proposing a return to an idea about architecture’s
label: Paragraph

text: ancient origins: a circle of people gathered around a fire, as described in the
label: Paragraph

text: oldest surviving architecture book—Vitruvius’ De Architectura, 1st century
label: Caption

text: CE.
label: Paragraph

text: Several designers explored this reduction of architecture to clear, inflated
label: Paragraph

text: plastic membranes. Examples included: Michael Webb’s experimental
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Cushicle’ bubble, and his plastic ‘Suitaloon’ fitted to the human body,
label: Paragraph

text: 1967; Haus-Rucker-Co’s (self-explanatory) ‘Balloon for Two’, also 1967;
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Mobile Office’, an inflated drum where the architect Hans Hollein sat at a
label: Paragraph

text: drawing board, 1969; Ant Farm’s ‘Clean Air Pod’, 1970; and the ‘Restless
label: Paragraph

text: Sphere’ that the Austrian collective Co-op Himmelb(])au rolled around the
label: Paragraph

text: streets of Basel, Switzerland, 1971. In such projects, membranes became
label: Paragraph

text: second skins for human figures, whose blurry contours appeared through
label: Paragraph

text: their surface reflections. These architects took lightness and airiness to an
label: Paragraph

text: extreme at a time when Tange and Safdie were simultaneously designing
label: Paragraph

text: heavyweight megastructures, and Kahn was seeking a new monumentality
label: Paragraph

text: for modern architecture. In contrast, their anti-monumental projects
label: Paragraph

text: questioned whether architecture should involve buildings at all. These
label: Paragraph

text: inflatable fantasies deliberately challenged architecture’s traditional
label: Paragraph

text: associations with permanence. But their designers also diverged somewhat
label: Paragraph

text: from Banham and Dallegret’s vision of the Unhouse: they understood their
label: Paragraph

text: bubbles not as an extension of total environmental control—as proposed by
label: Paragraph

text: Banham, and as embodied in Saarinen’s GM campus where fluorescent
label: Paragraph

text: lighting and air-conditioning substituted for natural light and air—but
label: Paragraph

text: instead as a parody of total environmental control. The inhabitants of these
label: Paragraph

text: bubbles were not imagined as enclosed by technology, so much as
label: Paragraph

text: imprisoned by it.
label: Paragraph

text: A spirit of satire informed these young architects’ work, partly in response
label: Paragraph

text: to the counter-culture of the late 1960s and early 1970s. Various anti-
label: Paragraph

text: establishment movements first flourished across Europe and the US in
label: Paragraph

text: association with the coming-of-age of the postwar ‘baby boomers’. They
label: Paragraph

text: played to the soundtrack of the Beatles and Rolling Stones, relaxed with
label: Paragraph

text: (what Banham called) ‘wonder-drugs and new domestic chemistries’,
label: Paragraph

text: championed equal rights for all genders and ethnicities, and looked up to a
label: Paragraph

text: new creative class of celebrities, artists, and designers. ‘Hippie’
label: Paragraph

text: incarnations of these movements in the late 1960s reacted specifically
label: Paragraph

text: against the Vietnam War and the draft of young Americans to fight. Their
label: Paragraph

text: thinking endorsed a new environmentalism—as highlighted by Fuller—
label: Paragraph

text: acutely aware of the fragility of planet Earth and the destruction of life by
label: Paragraph

text: human activity. Student groups associated with the counter-culture were
label: Paragraph

text: highly political, imagining mainstream figures—including their teachers—
label: Paragraph

text: as a complacent, reactionary establishment. Their frustrations boiled over
label: Paragraph

text: into demonstrations in 1968—in Paris, New York, Prague, and West Berlin,
label: Paragraph

text: for example—challenging what they saw as the imperial ambitions of
label: Paragraph

text: warmongering anti-democratic regimes, championing instead freedom and
label: Paragraph

text: civil rights. These demonstrations—some violently suppressed—didn’t
label: Paragraph

text: represent a coherent global movement, but they did connect local, national,
label: Paragraph

text: and international concerns with wider protest and trade union groups.
label: Paragraph

text: Some radicals decided to ‘drop out’ of mainstream society, to reject the
label: Paragraph

text: establishment and money culture, collecting together to live communal
label: Paragraph

text: subsistence lives. In 1965, four art students—styled as Curly, Jo, Lard, and
label: Paragraph

text: Clard—founded a commune in remote southeast Colorado, USA, self-
label: Paragraph

text: building geodesic domes out of recycled components like car parts. Another
label: Paragraph

text: group—Ant Farm, whose chief protagonists were architects Chip Lord and
label: Paragraph

text: Doug Michaels—began building a so-called nomadic environment in Death
label: Paragraph

text: Valley, California, with domes and inflatables, working with the writer
label: Paragraph

text: Stewart Brand. Brand’s Whole Earth Catalog, several editions of which
label: Paragraph

text: were published between 1968 and 1971, mixed articles about self-
label: Paragraph

text: sufficiency, ecology, and radical education with reviews of building
label: Paragraph

text: products and DIY (do-it-yourself) tips. It provided a ‘how-to’ guide for
label: Paragraph

text: alternative living. Steve Jobs—who founded the Homebrew Computer Club
label: Paragraph

text: in California before founding Apple Computers—later described it as ‘like
label: Paragraph

text: Google in paperback form, 35 years before Google’. Jobs highlighted that,
label: Paragraph

text: while communes never became mainstream, they incubated ideas about
label: Paragraph

text: sharing and information economies that later informed the emerging
label: Paragraph

text: Internet.
label: Paragraph

text: Mainstream postwar modern architecture gradually became seen as part of
label: Paragraph

text: the establishment problem. It got associated with top-down comprehensive
label: Paragraph

text: redevelopment involving the clearance of settled communities—for
label: Paragraph

text: example, the imposition of housing and office blocks constructed in the
label: Paragraph

text: West in the 1960s on the lines of Corbusier’s Ville Contemporaine—driven
label: Paragraph

text: by local and national authorities. This growing perception was strengthened
label: Paragraph

text: by author, activist, and sociologist Jane Jacobs’s 1961 book Death and Life
label: Paragraph

text: of Great American Cities. Jacobs studied lively traditional neighbourhoods
label: Paragraph

text: with strong communities and a vibrant street life, including Boston’s North
label: Paragraph

text: End, then slated to be cleared, showing how they figured better in health,
label: Paragraph

text: crime, and education measures than replacement modern neighbourhoods.
label: Paragraph

text: Such perceived failures of modern architecture became symbolized by the
label: Paragraph

text: demolition of the troubled Pruitt-I[goe housing blocks in St Louis, Missouri,
label: Caption

text: USA, in 1972. Memorable images of their demolition illustrated a growing
label: Paragraph

text: disillusionment with modern architecture, which became perceived as an
label: Paragraph

text: accessory of top-down control. The bubbles of Banham, Co-op
label: Caption

text: Himmelb())au, Drop City, and others can be understood in this context as a
label: Paragraph

text: rejection of centralized planning and industrial construction; conceived
label: Paragraph

text: instead as recovering the supposed early promise of modern architecture to
label: Paragraph

text: express Straightforwardly new technologies and new social configurations.
label: Paragraph

text: Rightly or wrongly, the fantastical drawings of the Archigram group
label: Paragraph

text: became seen as defining images of 1960s counter-culture. Archigram began
label: Paragraph

text: as a group of British students and architects comprising Michael Webb
label: Paragraph

text: (whose Cushicle and Suitaloon have been mentioned earlier), Warren
label: Paragraph

text: Chalk, Peter Cook, Dennis Crompton, David Greene, and Ron Herron. The
label: Paragraph

text: name ‘Archigram’ combined ‘architecture’ with ‘telegram’, then the fastest
label: Paragraph

text: means of global communication (a kind of text message sent from post
label: Paragraph

text: offices). They used the same name for an anti-architecture fanzine they
label: Paragraph

text: published on a shoestring budget, containing memorable images that
label: Paragraph

text: mashed-up clip-outs from advertising and film posters with sci-fi comic
label: Paragraph

text: imagery and straight-laced technical drawing. Historian Simon Sadler has
label: Paragraph

text: shown how these drawings blended humour with seriousness, experimental
label: Paragraph

text: fantasies with plausible technological predictions, techno-gadgetry with
label: Paragraph

text: ideas about disposableness, and 1960s radical politics with the macho
label: Paragraph

text: derring-do of boys’ comics.
label: Paragraph

text: Herron’s drawing for ‘Walking City’, 1964, proposed giant insect-inspired
label: Paragraph

text: megastructures on eight legs: alternative communities made of
label: Title

text: prefabricated modules that could stride across the landscape. Dennis
label: Paragraph

text: Crompton’s ‘Computor City’ drawings, 1964, showed an abstract grid of
label: Paragraph

text: dwellings looking like substations and diodes, plugged-in with pipes and
label: Paragraph

text: cables, expressing the idea of the city as a connected network. Most
label: Paragraph

text: memorable was Peter Cook’s cartoon strip proposing an ‘Instant City’,
label: Paragraph

text: 1969. Emblazoned with slogans, the images illustrated successive stages for
label: Paragraph

text: the take over of a ‘sleeping’ small town. First, an airship would arrive and
label: Paragraph

text: get plugged in. Then it would lower tents and billboards to provoke
label: Paragraph

text: spontaneous events, enlivening the town’s spaces (Figure 28). ‘Square
label: Paragraph

text: becomes theatre’, the drawing proclaims, ‘yard about to become disco-
label: Paragraph

text: talkpit’, and the blimp drops projection screens. After a period of ‘high
label: Paragraph

text: intensity’, the airship would move on, leaving a town infiltrated with
label: Paragraph

text: ‘learning stations’ and ‘infocentre’ technology. Ongoing ‘counter-action’
label: Paragraph

text: would then be inspired among empowered young people, the Instant City
label: Paragraph

text: network having taken over.

text: Archigram’s drawings followed Fuller’s lead in claiming a spontaneous,
label: Paragraph

text: playful, and disposable architecture. They conceived architecture as short-
label: Paragraph

text: term rather than long-term, as the design of transient events rather than
label: Paragraph

text: fixed structures. Indeed, the combination of technology, culture, and
label: Paragraph

text: democracy they illustrated resonated afresh with a later generation
label: Paragraph

text: grappling with how to imagine the newly popularized Internet in the 2000s.
label: Paragraph

text: Skin and guts
label: Title

text: The closest anyone got to building Instant City, or something like it, was in
label: Paragraph

text: Paris’s Marais district. A competition, held in 1971, sought architects for a
label: Paragraph

text: gallery, library, and contemporary music labs. The jury—chaired by Jean
label: Paragraph

text: Prouvé, an engineer famous for demountable structures—chose a design
label: Paragraph

text: from a then-obscure duo: Renzo Piano and Richard Rogers, working with
label: Paragraph

text: engineers Ove Arup & Partners. In the spirit of the 1968 protests, Piano and
label: Paragraph

text: Rogers proposed an anti-institutional institution. The building that finally
label: Paragraph

text: opened in 1978—named Centre Georges Pompidou after the French
label: Paragraph

text: president who championed it, and often called Beaubourg after its site—
label: Paragraph

text: contained all the contradictions you might expect of an expensive,
label: Paragraph

text: permanent, state-sponsored institution trying to seem temporary,
label: Paragraph

text: spontaneous, and radical.
label: Paragraph

text: Beaubourg brought together the deep-plan logic of air-conditioning and
label: Paragraph

text: fluorescent lighting with ideas of spontaneity evoked by Archigram’s
label: Paragraph

text: bubbles and blimps. It comprised a substantial steel frame, supporting
label: Paragraph

text: broad, highly serviced free-plan floorplates without intermediate columns.
label: Caption

text: These floorplates, it was imagined, would provide maximum flexibility for
label: Paragraph

text: radical curators to stage events: combining painting and sculpture with
label: Paragraph

text: video and sound art, for example, or altogether new art forms. It was
label: Paragraph

text: originally proposed that floor segments should move up and down for extra
label: Paragraph

text: flexibility, although this was later abandoned because of cost, along with
label: Paragraph

text: digital billboards proposed for the facades. Escalators were threaded
label: Paragraph

text: through the structural frame in glazed tubes on one facade, facing a new
label: Paragraph

text: public square, offering striking views over Paris, and symbolizing
label: Paragraph

text: dynamism and spontaneity. The primary street facade, meanwhile,
label: Paragraph

text: comprised a web of brightly coloured pipes and ducts, feeding service voids
label: Paragraph

text: in the suspended ceilings and raised floors behind (Figure 29). Putting the
label: Paragraph

text: ducts on the outside helped keep the floorplates free of disruptive service
label: Paragraph

text: zones. But it also conferred the building a radically novel image—a
label: Paragraph

text: dramatized expression of structure and servicing technology—which
label: Paragraph

text: historians subsequently categorized as its own architectural style: ‘high-
label: Paragraph

text: Previous modern buildings I’ve discussed in this book questioned the merits
label: Paragraph

text: of architectural decoration, understood by their architects as arbitrary,
label: Paragraph

text: unnecessary, and morally wrong. But Beaubourg and the Sainsbury Centre,
label: Paragraph

text: by contrast, renewed concern for amplified imagery. They moved beyond
label: Paragraph

text: ideas about deriving plan form, for example, and the placement of
label: Paragraph

text: windows, straightforwardly from functional necessities. They didn’t only
label: Paragraph

text: express technology, they ‘fetishized’ it (as critics said at the time).
label: Paragraph

text: Beaubourg’s web of ducts became a kind of ornamentation. As did the sleek
label: Paragraph

text: surfaces of the Sainsbury Centre, artfully caricaturing ordinary roadside
label: Caption

text: sheds, and expensively reinventing typical components. Both buildings took
label: Paragraph

text: the expression of technology beyond, say, E.1027 or Seagram, and beyond
label: Paragraph

text: the rhetoric of functional logic. Previous modern buildings emphasized
label: Paragraph

text: technology visually, where Beaubourg and Sainsbury artfully exaggerated
label: Paragraph

text: it, engaging in technologically inspired embellishment.
label: Paragraph

text: This distinction is subtle but important. It shows how Beaubourg and
label: Paragraph

text: Sainsbury extended the functional ethos of modern design but also went
label: Paragraph

text: beyond it. Arguably, these buildings rejected Ruskin’s insistence on truth to
label: Paragraph

text: materials by accentuating functional necessities for visual effect, flouting
label: Paragraph

text: Loos’s insistence that ‘ornament is a crime’ and Mies’s dictum that ‘less is
label: Paragraph

text: more’.
label: Paragraph

text: These buildings’ complex imagery reflected the growing complexities of
label: Paragraph

text: the time. The 1973 Energy Crisis—when Middle Eastern oil companies
label: Paragraph

text: refused to supply fuel to certain Western countries because of a war with
label: Paragraph

text: Israel—highlighted connections between burgeoning oil consumption,
label: Paragraph

text: global politics, and ecological concerns. The crisis highlighted the fragility
label: Paragraph

text: of energy supply at a time when its reliability had become taken for granted.
label: Paragraph

text: It renewed postwar apprehensions about the value of technology for society.
label: Paragraph

text: And it coincided with a prolonged economic downturn causing the decline
label: Paragraph

text: of established industries, and communities around them, in the West.
label: Paragraph

text: Meanwhile, the Cold War threat of imminent nuclear destruction persisted.
label: Paragraph

text: A growing popular sense emerged that the modern promise of perpetual
label: Paragraph

text: progress—linking technology and democracy with ever-increasing living
label: Title

text: standards—had halted. Art, literature, and film increasingly reflected this
label: Paragraph

text: emerging scepticism. Meanwhile, prominent philosophers and cultural
label: Paragraph

text: theorists challenged the fundamental basis of scientific and technological
label: Paragraph

text: thinking. They illustrated how the supposedly objective realities, and
label: Paragraph

text: absolute truths, of science and technology conveniently reflected the values
label: Paragraph

text: of a prosperous, white, Western, male elite, Feminism, civil rights,
label: Paragraph

text: ecological activism, and studies of global power (‘postcolonialism’)
label: Title

text: highlighted links between global finance, political authority, and the
label: Paragraph

text: priorities of industry and military technologies, questioning the motivations
label: Paragraph

text: of the powerful global technocratic establishment. It’s now widely assumed
label: Paragraph

text: that modernity came to an end in the 1980s and 1990s because of this
label: Paragraph

text: growing loss of faith in the ideas of progress and technology, highlighting
label: Paragraph

text: the increasingly complicated problems of so-called developed societies.
label: Paragraph

text: These complexities can be seen reflected in the subtle, if fundamental, shift
label: Paragraph

text: from modern architectures which expressed technology to those like
label: Paragraph

text: Beaubourg and Sainsbury which heightened it.
label: Paragraph

text: Beaubourg and Sainsbury were transitional. They remained statements of
label: Paragraph

text: faith in the social promise of technology. But, as philosopher Walter
label: Paragraph

text: Benjamin reflected, every age dreams its successor, and their ‘high-tech’
label: Paragraph

text: imagery also anticipated the so-called postmodem architecture of the 1980s,
label: Paragraph

text: which rejected modern moralizing about honest architectural expression,
label: Paragraph

text: and re-embraced heightened imagery. While the underlying structural logic
label: Paragraph

text: of postmodern buildings usually remained straightforwardly modem, their
label: Paragraph

text: surfaces became ornamented with decoration derived from architectural
label: Paragraph

text: history, swooping or jagged ‘deconstructed’ forms or, indeed, high-tech
label: Paragraph

text: motifs. Thus, Beaubourg and Sainsbury stand both for late modernity and
label: Paragraph

text: the emergence of what followed. They conclude this story about modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. However, they could equally begin another story about
label: Paragraph

text: postmodern architecture.

label: Title

text: Bessemer steel, Portland cement, concrete reinforcement, and electric light
label: Title

text: —all key technical ingredients of architectural modernity—were products
label: Paragraph

text: of the 19th century. The distinctive architectural moralities concerning
label: Paragraph

text: ‘truth’ to materials and functions, which became associated with them, were
label: Paragraph

text: also consolidated in the 19th century, deriving from the theories of Ruskin,
label: Paragraph

text: Semper, Viollet-le-Duc, and others. Their future combination into what later
label: Paragraph

text: became recognized as modern architecture was not obvious at the time. It
label: Paragraph

text: looked inevitable only in retrospect, when historians like Russell-
label: Paragraph

text: Hitchcock, Pevsner, and Banham—with their own agendas—arranged
label: Paragraph

text: buildings and ideas into coherent stories. It took until the first half of the
label: Paragraph

text: 20th century for architects to mature their ideas, in conjunction with new
label: Paragraph

text: materials, into the distinctive imagery that’s now recognized as modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. But that imagery was only the outward sign of new ways of
label: Paragraph

text: organizing structure, space, and surface: integrating architecture with
label: Title

text: services; exploring novel logics of frames and planes; and testing free- and
label: Paragraph

text: open-plans.
label: Paragraph

text: Modem architects only gradually learnt to talk about their designs in
label: Paragraph

text: today’s familiar terms, emphasizing function, simplicity, order, space, place,
label: Paragraph

text: light, and air. That emerging vocabulary didn’t encourage them to discuss
label: Paragraph

text: what their buildings looked like. Nor did it help them to acknowledge their
label: Paragraph

text: intertextual references to art, engineering, or industrial design. Instead, most
label: Paragraph

text: modern architects promoted the myth that their buildings’ appearance was
label: Paragraph

text: merely a consequence of functional planning, and the organizational logics
label: Paragraph

text: inherent in the materials they employed.
label: Paragraph

text: Many postmodern architects, however, remembered that—just like the Iron
label: Paragraph

text: Bridge was shaped as an arch because that’s what bridges were expected to
label: Paragraph

text: look like—people maintained deep-seated preferences about how buildings
label: Paragraph

text: should appear. Despite efforts, by Mies for example, to design definitive
label: Paragraph

text: modern college and office buildings, most people’s preferred architectural
label: Paragraph

text: imagery remained premodern, and specific to familiar cultures. According
label: Paragraph

text: to postmodern theorists, notably Léon Krier, these preferences were related
label: Paragraph

text: to particular building types, like houses, schools, or hospitals. For example,
label: Paragraph

text: in Britain, the lasting popular image of the house seems to have remained in
label: Paragraph

text: brick or stone, with a pitched roof and pretty decorative porch. In West
label: Caption

text: German cities, the image of home remains flats in courtyard blocks, with
label: Paragraph

text: their particular pattern of communal living. It seemed that people were most
label: Paragraph

text: comfortable with the imagery of modern architecture only in building types
label: Paragraph

text: most closely associated with modern technologies, like railway stations, car
label: Paragraph

text: parks, and motorway service areas. In the 1980s, this thinking chimed with
label: Paragraph

text: ideas from the study of language, from ‘semiotics’, which examined how
label: Paragraph

text: the word-labels attached to things remain separate from the things
label: Paragraph

text: themselves. Why do we call a tree a tree, semioticians asked (or an arbol or
label: Paragraph

text: a $f), and not a kudfgaefjkd? Similarly, postmodern architects speculated
label: Paragraph

text: about the appearance of architecture in terms of visual languages. What, for
label: Paragraph

text: example, makes a mosque look like a mosque and not a garage?
label: Paragraph

text: Some modem architects—such as Aalto, Carlo Scarpa, or George Pace—
label: Paragraph

text: abstracted traditional architectural forms to produce modem ones which
label: Paragraph

text: nevertheless seemed familiar, making intertextual references to older
label: Paragraph

text: architectures. But postmodern architects instead frequently covered their
label: Paragraph

text: buildings with facades that pasted in traditional ‘signifying’ forms. For
label: Paragraph

text: example, big urban buildings like shopping malls were frequently collaged
label: Paragraph

text: with a variety of historic (or historic-ish) elevations to make them look like
label: Paragraph

text: traditional city blocks comprising multiple buildings. Modern architects
label: Paragraph

text: would have dismissed this as inauthentic, concealing the inherent logic of
label: Paragraph

text: the building and its materials. The engineering behind postmodern facades
label: Paragraph

text: like these usually remained stubbornly modern, however, comprising steel
label: Paragraph

text: and concrete frames optimized to suit the building’s functions. In numerous
label: Paragraph

text: examples like this, ghosts of modern architecture—in the traces of modern
label: Paragraph

text: ideas and organizational logics—have remained tenaciously persistent.

text: Ghosts of modern architecture
label: Title

text: The current strand of expert architectural practice which subscribes most
label: Paragraph

text: closely to modern values is digital design, often called ‘parametricism’
label: Paragraph

text: because it sometimes employs computer modelling to test design
label: Paragraph

text: parameters. Its architects continue to pursue new technologies towards
label: Paragraph

text: distinctive imagery, but they work with technologies of design process more
label: Paragraph

text: than novel materials. Innovative software allows such architects to model
label: Paragraph

text: extraordinarily elaborate shapes. In parallel, experimental manufacturing
label: Paragraph

text: has transformed the fantasy of mass production into a new fantasy of ‘mass
label: Paragraph

text: customization’, where elaborate shapes can be fabricated from individual
label: Paragraph

text: components mass produced digitally as one-offs. Examples include projects
label: Paragraph

text: from the offices of NOX, Jiirgen Mayer, Zaha Hadid Architects, and Gehry
label: Paragraph

text: Partners.
label: Paragraph

text: Ghosts of ideas about truth to materials and function remain—through their
label: Paragraph

text: rejection—in projects by OMA with Rem Koolhaas: extensions to IIT’s
label: Paragraph

text: Mies-designed Commons building, 2003, for example; and Casa da Musica,
label: Caption

text: Porto, Portugal, 2005. These projects matched cheap materials with crude
label: Paragraph

text: fixings, rejecting the obsessive detailing of Mies and Lewerentz, whose
label: Paragraph

text: apparently simple elements required huge effort to make. OMA did this
label: Paragraph

text: both to critique modern architecture and to illustrate how present-day
label: Paragraph

text: concerns—like increased developer profits, mass-produced building
label: Paragraph

text: components, and diminishing craft skills—mean that architectural detailing,
label: Paragraph

text: as once understood, can seem largely impossible. OMA’s deliberately ‘bad’
label: Paragraph

text: details remain as considered, however, as any they criticize.

label: Paragraph

text: Regulation and risk
label: Title

text: It might seem curious to turn to the emergence of building regulations in
label: Paragraph

text: concluding this book, but they were decisive in both the demise of modern
label: Paragraph

text: imagery, and the simultaneous consolidation of modern values in the
label: Paragraph

text: present-day construction industry.
label: Paragraph

text: Building regulations multiplied in most Western countries during the latter
label: Paragraph

text: part of the 20th century as a cultural consequence of the forces of industrial
label: Paragraph

text: production. Regulatory regimes burgeoned in a postwar context of state
label: Paragraph

text: paternalism and increasing professionalization, seeking to regularize non-
label: Paragraph

text: professionals, and to protect the public from excesses of profit-driven
label: Paragraph

text: developers, consultants, and landlords. They also responded to a loss of
label: Paragraph

text: construction skills following an increasing decline in architectural
label: Paragraph

text: ornamentation. This decline diminished cultures of craft and artisanal care
label: Paragraph

text: in building, alongside a corresponding proliferation of industrial building
label: Paragraph

text: products—including window, door, and roofing components—understood
label: Paragraph

text: as technical systems. Clients increasingly began to insist upon the
label: Paragraph

text: warranties that came with such systems, giving architects increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: fewer opportunities to invent evocative details—like Aalto did—
label: Paragraph

text: progressively rendering designers as shoppers for, and coordinators of,
label: Paragraph

text: mass-produced parts.
label: Paragraph

text: Building regulations progressively made modemism unworkable at the
label: Paragraph

text: level of detail. Increasing requirements for greater insulation necessitated
label: Paragraph

text: ever more complex interfaces between components, serving to thicken-up
label: Paragraph

text: previously simple, slender connections. Likewise, structural rules required
label: Paragraph

text: additional factors of safety in steel and concrete sizing, frustrating the
label: Paragraph

text: imagery of lightness. Also, certain accessibility regulations have dictated
label: Paragraph

text: contrasting surfaces to assist people with visual impairments, outlawing
label: Paragraph

text: visual simplicity by multiplying textures and colours—additionally
label: Paragraph

text: prohibiting the modern detail where wall materials continue as floor
label: Paragraph

text: materials, as at St Peter’s, Klippan.
label: Paragraph

text: In contrast, however, building regulation regimes have also consolidated
label: Paragraph

text: other priorities of modern architecture. They usually required the
label: Paragraph

text: submission of structural calculations, which had the effect of promoting
label: Paragraph

text: steel and concrete frames—that engineers find easier to analyse—over
label: Paragraph

text: timber and masonry. They have often specified consistent light levels—in
label: Paragraph

text: classrooms and offices for example—requiring artificial lighting even
label: Paragraph

text: where windows are present because natural light is deemed too unreliable
label: Paragraph

text: for healthy screen use. Similarly, rules quantifying the number of air
label: Paragraph

text: changes needed per hour in certain spaces have frequently discounted
label: Paragraph

text: natural ventilation as unpredictable, dictating mechanical air handling.
label: Paragraph

text: Regulations like these deal largely in technical performance and, as such,
label: Paragraph

text: their values clearly derive from modem architecture—focused on function,
label: Paragraph

text: with little to say about what buildings look and feel like.
label: Paragraph

text: These values inherent in building regulation regimes resonate with the
label: Paragraph

text: current international construction industry. Fuelled by global finance,
label: Paragraph

text: consuming mass-produced building products, resourced by multinational
label: Paragraph

text: consultants, that industry has become highly risk-averse. It tends to prefer
label: Paragraph

text: quantitative data about the timely and profitable delivery of buildings over
label: Paragraph

text: wearisome considerations about their visual qualities, cultural meanings,
label: Paragraph

text: and atmospheres. Indeed, surveyors, project managers, and engineers—
label: Paragraph

text: frequently more adept than architects in the language of reliable delivery,
label: Paragraph

text: like Paxton and Eiffel more than a century before—have assumed the bulk
label: Paragraph

text: of project management from architects in numerous national contexts. Thus,
label: Paragraph

text: innovative architectural imagery has regularly become understood as
label: Paragraph

text: unnecessarily risky. Architects—preoccupied with design ideas, frequently
label: Paragraph

text: more concemed with the qualities of finished buildings than management
label: Paragraph

text: processes used to deliver them—can struggle to get heard in contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: construction. Dominant industry values have become so unshakeably
label: Paragraph

text: modern—rooted in technical criteria, ambivalent to visual, social, and
label: Paragraph

text: atmospheric qualities—that architects, many of whom now question
label: Paragraph

text: modern priorities, can regularly feel they don’t belong.

text: Multiple modernities
label: Title

text: In retrospect, it’s easy to caricature modern architecture as symbolizing the
label: Paragraph

text: idea of modernity as an unquestioned good: promoting technology, industry,
label: Paragraph

text: and novelty as progress; celebrating the globalization of trade, finance, and
label: Paragraph

text: culture. It’s also easy to caricature, in opposition, a renewed preference for
label: Paragraph

text: traditional architectures—romanticizing a return to historical motifs, local
label: Paragraph

text: materials, and time-honoured crafts—as symbolizing a rejection of
label: Paragraph

text: modernity in favour of reclaiming a sentimental idea of the pre-industrial
label: Paragraph

text: past. However, these positions are false opposites. Modernity and modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture were always double-edged. The popular uptake of new
label: Paragraph

text: technologies was always accompanied by anxieties about the effects of
label: Paragraph

text: industrialization and globalization. These contradictions were exemplified
label: Paragraph

text: by the medieval imagery of suburban villas constructed by British
label: Paragraph

text: developers in the 1930s, which were nevertheless kitted-out with electric
label: Paragraph

text: light, radios, telephones, and kitchen devices, Over time, there have been
label: Paragraph

text: numerous global equivalents of these houses, fitting versions of Fuller’s
label: Paragraph

text: technological environments inside traditional-looking architectural cloaks.
label: Paragraph

text: Architects and critics, schooled in modern ideas about architecture as an
label: Paragraph

text: honest reflection of the age, usually scorn them. But such buildings stand as
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph
